Praefatio.	 Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	 After I completed this book for you, Sons [of], which is the last one in the science of medicine with its completion, and after I reached the end in it, through its explanations and its declarations, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this Treatise which is a part of operation, that is, surgery with hands.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	 Since operation with hands is laid low in our region and during our time, it has been entirely absent: perhaps the science of it has perished, and its trace has been lost: and nothing remains from it except small descriptions in old books, which have been changed by hand; and error and hesitation occurred until its intentions were closed off, and the force of it was weakened: It seemed to me that I should revive it with the arrangement of this Treatise according to the way of its explanation, and its abbreviation; and that I should provide with the forms of the instruments of Cautery, and the rest of the tools of work: when done by adding to its declarations, and through the necessity of it.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	 The reason why no good craftsman with his hands can be found in this time is that the art of medicine is long, and its author must exercise himself before that in the science of anatomy which Galen narrated, so that he knows the aid of limbs, and their shapes, and their connection, and separation, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, muscles, and their number, and their exits, and the arteries pulsating and quiet ones, and their locations.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	 And for this reason, Hippocrates said that name with name is much, and with work it is little, especially in the art of hands.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	 We have already spoken about him at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	 Since he who is not knowing what we have said about anatomy, cannot avoid falling into error, in which people are killed: just as I have seen many of those who are formed from this science and boast about it without knowledge, and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	 I have seen a foolish surgeon cut out a scrofulous apostema on a woman's neck and cut some arteries in the neck: consequently the woman's blood flowed until she fell dead in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	 And I have seen another surgeon who presumptuously attempted to extract a stone from an elderly man, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	 Therefore he came to him, and extracted it with a piece of bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	 Wherefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	 And indeed I was already called to extract it; and I saw from the size of the stone, and the condition of the sick man, that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	 And I have seen another surgeon who was receiving straw from some Duke of our land on account of medicine; and a black eunuch was with him, who was with him, and he sustained a fracture in his leg near the heel; and the surgeon rushed with his ignorance, and bound up the fracture over the wound with pulleys, and strong bindings, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	 Then he cured him according to his own neglect.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	 Later he sent him away for some days and ordered him not to loosen the binding; and he remained so until an apostema formed on his leg, and his own foot, and it came to ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	 Therefore I was called to him; and I hastened to loosen the binding; and peace came, and he was freed from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	 The corruption was already confirmed in the member; and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	 Stop, the corruption has ceased to roam through the member until it has perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	 I saw another doctor who pierced a malignant apostema; and after days, the ulceration was until the evil of it with its lord was manifested.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	 Because when it is a pure cancer from black bile, then it is not necessary to approach it with iron at all, unless it is in a member that can endure, so that the whole of it may be removed.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	 And because of this, O Sons, it is necessary for you to know that the operation is divided into two divisions: namely, the operation with salvation associated; and the operation with danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	 And I have already aroused myself in every place of this book, where the operation comes, in which there is fear and dread.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	 Therefore it is necessary for you to be careful of that, and separate it yourself: so that the foolish do not find a way to speak and to disgrace.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	 Receive then the measure with care and protection, and take care of your weak ones with ease and firmness, and use the better way leading to grace of God to health and praiseworthy success: and dismiss terrible sicknesses that are difficult to heal; and remove from you what makes you afraid, so that hesitation in faith and your comfort may enter upon you.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	 For it remains more to your glory, and higher in this world, and finally to the measures of yours.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	 Galenus has already said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	 Do not treat the evil sickness; lest you be called an evil doctor.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	 Now, however, I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	 Chapter one.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	 On cautery with fire, and cautery with sharp medicine, is the subject of this chapter, arranged from head to foot, and the forms of instruments, and tools for cautery, and all that is necessary in an operation. (paragraph break)
Capitulum secundum.	 Chapter two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	 On section and perforation, phlebotomy and blistering, wounds, and the extraction of arrows and similar items; and the entire subject is arranged according to the forms of instruments. (paragraph break)
Capitulum tertium.	 Chapter three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	 On restoration, and dislocation, and treatment of twisting, and similar items; arranged from head to foot, and the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	 To God alone be the glory. (in Latin: Soli Deo Gloria)
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	 The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	 Part one.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	 (paragraph break) On the benefits and harm of cautery; under which constitutions it is suitable, and at what time; and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	 Chapter one.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	 However, before I speak of the operation with it, it is first necessary to say the nature of its benefits and harm; and under which constitution it should be administered.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	 Therefore, the discourse on the nature of the benefit and harm of cautery is lengthy, subtle, full of knowledge, and secret wisdom.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	 And many wise men have spoken of it and disagreed on it; and I myself find enough from their discussions, fearing lengthiness.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	 Therefore, cautery applies generally to all constitutions, whether with matter or without; except for two constitutions, which are a hot constitution without matter and a dry constitution without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	 However, in a hot and dry constitution with matter, they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	 Some have said that Cautery is beneficial for it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	 And others said the opposite, namely that Cautery is not suitable for the disease which is due to heat and dryness, because nature of fire is heat: it is inappropriate to heal from a hot and dry disease with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	 And he said who says the opposite, that by Cautery is beneficial in every hot and dry disease which happens in human bodies, because when you compare a man's body and his humors, to the composition of fire, you find a man's body cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	 And I myself say by his words: because it has been proved to me many times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	 Nevertheless, it is not necessary for him to come upon that, unless he who has already been proven and trained in the last chapter on Cautery, and knows the differences of men's complexions, and the dispositions of diseases within themselves, and their causes, and the characteristics of them, and the duration of their time.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	 As for other complexions, there is no fear over you: and especially in cold and moist diseases.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	 Indeed, all doctors agree on these: and they have not disagreed on the benefit with Cautery for them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	 And know sons (pupils), that by secret healing with Cautery and fire, and the goodness of it on Cautery with medicine burning, because fire is simple, whose action does not reach except to the member which is cauterized: and it does not harm another joint connected with it, unless by a slight damage.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	 But the action of burning medicine reaches to that which is extended from the members: and perhaps it may cause difficult healing in the member, and perhaps it may kill.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	 Fire, on account of its subtlety and goodness, does not act except when in excess.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	 It has become known to us through experiment, due to the length of servitude and study with art, and due to its position concerning truth: and because of that I excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	 And if it were not prohibited to this book of mine, I would disclose to you the secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in bodies from which it expels sicknesses, demonstrated by philosophical discourse that would be comprehensible to your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	 And know, sons, that they themselves differ concerning the time when a cautery is to be made and consider a better time as truth permits.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	 And I say that a cautery is suitable at all times: for this reason, the harm resulting from time is submerged in the benefit that is attracted with the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	 And especially if a cautery is for pains from necessary pains, strong, urgent ones that do not tolerate delay: for this reason it is feared that from them may occur a malice that is greater than the little harm that passes through because of time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	 And may that not enter your minds, sons, the idea that is not held except by the common people and foolish physicians, that to an illness cured by cautery there is always a return: and they put it as a consequence, but things are not as they think: for this reason cauterization is not, unless in place of medicine which changes the humor and removes humidities which are the causes of the pain.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	 Nevertheless, a cautery is superfluous over medicine due to the speed of its health, and the virtue of its operation, and the violence of its dominion: and it is possible that illness may return at some hour of time according to the constitution of the sick person, and the location of his illness, and the power of his illness: and that in the body it arises from an accumulation of superfluities in it: and that it reaches him in its acquisition from foods and similar things as causes, unless illness occurs for which cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	 Subtle sickness in a member of few superfluities and moistures, as cautery for a tooth, because of pain, and similar to it, is possible that the pain will not return in it.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	 That happens in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	 However, the common saying that cautery is the last medicine is correct in its literal meaning; not in reference to what they intend by it, because they believe that there is no cure given with medication, nor with anything after the fall of the cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	 But the fact is just the opposite, and their intention that cautery is the last medicine, is not so, except when we administer modes of cure in some sicknesses, and they do not give those medications; then we apply cautery at the end, and it cures; then it comes about that cautery is the last medicine, but not according to the understanding of the common people and many physicians.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	 The ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron; and they did not say this unless due to the equality of gold and the refinement of its substance; and they said that it does not cause a place for cautery blisters.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	 But that is not absolutely true; because I have already proved it and found that the same does not cause this in some bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	 And cautery itself is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	 However, when you make the cautery in fire from gold, it is not made clear to you, when it is heated according to the amount that you wish, due to the redness of gold; and when it moves towards the same coldness, and if you add heat over it, it melts in the fire, and turns into layers.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	 Therefore the artisan falls into trouble from this; and because of this, cautery with iron is done among us more quickly and closer to the procedure, due to its straightness for the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	 I have already arranged this Chapter for cautery, according to the chapters: and I have ordered it from head to foot: that whatever they seek in it, may be found by them.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	 On the method of cauterizing the Head at the Coronal Suture.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	 Here, the cauterization is applied to the dominion of moisture and coldness over the brain: these two are causes of soda, and the flow of multiple humors from the head to the eyes and ears, and the multitude of sleep, and toothache, and throat pain; and universally all sickness that happens due to coldness, such as paralysis, soda, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar ones from these sicknesses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	 The method of cauterization is to instruct the sick person: that his head should be evacuated first with a solution of medicine cleansing it for three or four nights, according to the strength of the patient, and his age, and his custom.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	 Then instruct him to make his head warm with a towel.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	 Then make him sit between your hands in a square position, so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	 Then place the root of your palm over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	 Whenever therefore your middle finger arrives, mark that spot with something unburnt.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	 Then heat the cautery in oil: whose form is this.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	 Then put it on the marked spot with something unburnt, pressing down gradually with your hand, and you turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	 Then remove your hand quickly, and look at the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	 If you see that a piece of bone or quantity of coal has been burned from the skull, then remove your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	 And if not, put your hand back with the iron itself, or with something else from it if it cools down; until the bones that I told you are seen.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then take something from salt, and dissolve it in water, and immerse the cloth in it, and place it on the spot; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	 Then place a wet cloth on it (the wound) and let it remain until the burn is consumed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	 Then treat it with a four-ingredient ointment, until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	 It is said that the longer the wound remains open, the more it discharges pus; therefore, it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	 Some of them said that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone; and hold the cautery until something deep in the bone is burnt.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	 Then grind off the burnt part of the bone afterwards, then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	 Others say that when the cautery is reached to the end, it should be pressed onto the bone so that it falls off like a curette shape, or an instrument which women place in the vagina with a small amount of alphabet: and they think that vapors of the head escape from this place, and the wound should be kept open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	 Then treat it until it solidifies.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	 To me, these two types of cautery seem not to be at all useful except in certain people according to the path of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	 And let it be, for me it is better with his own health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	 Indeed the head is weakened by the dissolution of its natural continuity, as we have witnessed in other limbs; and especially when the head of a sick person is naturally weak, the first type of cautery is safer and better for me, and I use it: therefore work with it for safety.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	 Chapter on cauterizing the head in pain throughout the entire head.
Caput III.	 Head (III).
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	 When there is a chronic pain throughout the entire head and it lasts in the sick, using herbs, cooking, head shaving, oils, and plasters.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	 And especially if it has already been cauterized with one cautery, as I said, and does not receive anything from those (others): then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	 If the head of the sick person is strong by nature and not weak, and it finds intense cold: then cauterize with another cautery under it slightly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	 Then cauterize it on all the horns of his head with a cautery, so that the skin is not penetrated, and the amount of bone exposed as I said is removed.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	 And cauterize it with one cautery on the occiput of his head, in the place called 'vas': and it is a place where the ventous (a type of abscess) is placed: and loosen your mouth (apply suction) there, and do not expose bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	 For the sick person experiences intense pain from that (the swelling), and different from the pain of all other cauterizations of the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	 And I say that this Cautery is to be used in its place: and it must be a cautery with which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the occiput more subtly with a cautery with which the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	 Chapter on the way of cauterization for hemicania, both with hot medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	 When pain and swelling occurs in part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and it is treated with cleansing medicines on the head, and the rest of the treatment is administered, as I said in the divisions of diseases, and it does not improve completely: then cauterization in that case is according to two methods: either cauterization with hot medicine burning, or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	 The cautery with hot medicine burning is: that you take one tooth of the allium (onion) and grind it into a powder, and cut off the ends from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	 Then make an incision at the site of pain in time with a wide lancet, until there is a place under the skin where the tooth can be captured.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Then insert it into the same spot under the skin until it is hidden; then press upon it with a small piece of lint and bind it for fifteen hours, and then let it be dissolved, and remove the onion, and leave the wound open for two or three days: afterwards place a piece of butter-soaked cloth over it until a pus forms: then care for it with an ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	 And if you wish to perform this with certain burning medicines, which I have written about in the twelfth treatise on Middle Eastern Medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	 Cauterization of it with iron is performed in this way.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	 The form of the Iron Cauterization is as follows:
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	 It is called a Claw-shaped iron. The shape of its head resembles that of a nail, with a roughness on it and a small projection in the middle.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	 Then place it on the location and hold your hand steady; and you should slowly rotate the iron with speed, so that the amount to be burnt is of the thickness of the skin, as half its size.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And remove your hand so that the artery below is not burned and there is no bleeding.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Then soak the cloth in brine water, and place it over the location and leave it for three days; then place the cloth with butter: afterwards care for it with an ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	 If you wish, cauterize this half of the head with the second part of the scalpel-shaped cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	 And be careful not to make an incision on the artery in this half of the head, except when necessary.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	 Method of performing cauterization for old-age headache.
Caput V.	 Head (chapter).
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	 When you treat headache and what we have said in the previous treatment, and what we have said in the divisions of diseases, and the treatment does not help: and you see from the disease that what we said about cautery with medicine or cautery with fire is not sufficient for him, then it is necessary to heat the cauterizing iron until it turns white, after marking the place of pain with a line, whose length is half a finger or similar: and place your hand instead, and squeeze it tightly until you cut the artery, and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	 However, it is necessary for you to be careful not to burn the jaw that moves during chewing, which is located on the side or nerve that moves it, so as to avoid a spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	 And be careful of the caution and the cauterizing iron from the flow of blood from the artery that was cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	 Indeed, there is fear in the cutting of it, and especially for him who does not know what he is doing, and is not diligent, or experienced: and he first leaves the operation with it.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	 And I will come back with the reminder of the management of the flow of blood from the artery according to its own method, and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 If you see from the disease that this cautery is not sufficient for him, and you see a weak body bearing the cautery in the middle of the head as we have said, then treat the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	 And if you want to administer the cautery as we have said in the chapter on the extraction of the artery with a cautery having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	 Indeed, cauterization is better for this and more helpful.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	 On the method of cauterizing an ear pain.
Caput VI.	 In capite primum de modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	 When pain in the ear occurs due to coldness and is treated with solutions, and the remainder of the treatment as we said in the division, but the pain does not subside, then cautery by fire; and that which is called the puncture, whose shape is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	 Then, the puncture with it after its burning around the entire ear as it is rotated; or around either side, if the pain is on both sides.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	 And extend the cautery from the root of the ear somewhat, after marking places with wax; and let the quantity of the cautery be ten punctures in each ear, and as such.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	 Then, care for the locations until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in Strangulation.
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	 Strangulation that is treated with cauterization, is not other than those that occur from phlegm, according to what we said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	 And also avoid cauterization of a species that occurs due to dryness and spasm of a nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	 When treating this species of strangulation with hyssop, purges, gargarisms, and your treatment does not improve, then it is necessary to cauterize the sick person with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and the second slightly below his earlobe, and the third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	 And place your cautery on the opposite side of the weak side.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	 Because softening does not occur, unless in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	 And the form of cauterization is that you cauterize yourself with a cautery along the edge of the upper extremity of the ear, slightly below the horn of the head; and another on the earlobe; whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	 And place your hand with the cautery until the thickness of half the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	 And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a species from a knife, whose shape preceding is not too subtle, as you see; and it must be that the knife in it should be of little excess in thickness.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	 Then take care of the location, with it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	 Section on the mode of cauterization in ancient apoplexy.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	 When the apoplexy becomes ancient, and your care of it with what we said does not help, and the sick person does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries over all his skull's horns, and a cautery in the middle of the head, as we said, and a cautery on the back of the head, according to what preceded; and the mode of cauterization should be according to what preceded.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	 Also, it is cauterized with a cautery over the mouth of the stomach; and this is more final.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then it is taken care of, with what preceded.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	 Section on the mode of cauterization in oblivion.
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	 It is necessary that in a drink there are first large quantities of hysop, and cleansing pills for the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	 Then shave completely the head of the sick one, and place on his head an ointment made from myrrh described in the book of ointments; place it on him several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	 That is the method of cauterization; make it according to the same order as I have said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	 If he is cured by that, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	 If not: then make three cauterizations in the back of his head, which shall descend from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye; place a thickness of a finger between each cauterization.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then care for the cauterization, with what has gone before.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	 If you wish an addition, and the sick one can bear it: then make a cauterization in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	 What if you wish an addition: then cauterize him above two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	 Then care for it until he is cured; let the cauterization be anointed according to the shape that has been mentioned.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in paralysis and softening.
Caput X.	 Chapter X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	 It is necessary that you proceed with the cleaning of the head with hyson, and with what I have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	 Then scrape the head of the sick person: afterwards cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head, and with a cautery over all the horns of the head, and with a cautery over its posterior part, and three times over the vertebrae of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	 If, however, you need more softening of the body for illness with those [things], and the sick person is weak and the illness is strong: then cauterize him with four cauteries over the vertebrae of the back, and the last one with a cautery until most of his skin burns off, and then remove your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	 Then take care of him until he is well: and so cauterize with olive oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	 A cauterization should not be performed on an epileptic, unless his epilepsy is due to phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	 Therefore, it is necessary to clean the brain of his first with hot irons, and with the rest of the treatment as we said in division: when the patient is weak or endures well in taking medications.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	 If he is a child who does not endure medications, then gargarisma (a medicine) is administered, and cleansing chewing substances for the brain are given, before that for many days with good food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	 Then shave his head, afterwards cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of the head as it was before, and with another cautery on his occiput (the back of the head) and over all the horns of his head.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	 If the patient is strong and endures, then cauterize him with cauteries as I said in the presence of paralysis, and softening of the body on vertebrae (spinal bones) of the neck and back, and let the cautery be olive oil according to the method that was before.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	 If the patient is a child, then place a subtle cautery as follows:
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in Melancholy.
Caput XII.	 Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	 When the cause of melancholy are corrupted humors and gross phlegm, then cauterize him with cauteries as we said in the presence of paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	 And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of declivities to melancholy, and the body of the patient is moistened, then give him in drink what cleans his brain as before said in division: then shave the head of the patient, and make afterwards a decent tortellum (a small, round piece of cloth) made from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	 Then place it on the middle of the head: and the patient sitting squared should be held from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	 Then present the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	 It is more suitable from old sheep's butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	 And heat it over fire with a measured warmth that the finger can bear when it is inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	 Then evacuate it into the middle of its head in a circle, and let it go until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	 Do this to the sick person once a week with the rest of his good regimen until he is cured.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	 Or if you wish, cauterize it by making small punctures in it many times, provided that you keep your hand with the cautery; let it be smelling.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	 For this kind of cautery moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	 Then place on it a cloth soaked in sheep's butter or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	 Method of Cauterization when descending to the eye in water.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	 When you are informed of the beginning of water in the eye by the signs I mentioned in division, then begin and let the sick person drink with him, while washing his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	 And keep him away from all moistnesses, and make him sit in a bath, for some days in fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	 Then command him to shave his head, and cauterize himself in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	 Then cauterize him on two temples with two cauteries, if there is no discharge of water from both eyes at once: or from one side, if there is no discharge of water from one eye: and cut with the cautery all veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauteries be long in width as wide as the temples: and avoid bleeding.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	 If you see something from him, then cut him immediately with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting them off, and caution against bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	 And sometimes it is cauterized in the neck, under two bones, with two cauteries at the end of their production.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in tears (anciently).
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	 When the tears of the eyes are chronic and continuous, being above veins and arteries that are manifestly outside the head, it is verified that this is from excesses of cold, phlegmatic humors: then cauterize with the same cautery as I have described in the discharge of water, cauterize in the middle of the head, and with two cauteries on two temples, and with two cauteries in the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	 And if it requires addition, then cauterize him carefully on all sides of the eye, at the end of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in nose stink.
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	 When you treat it as we have said in the division, and it does not improve with the medicine: then hurry, and give infirmocochia for three nights: then shave his head, and cauterize him with the same cautery anointed with oil.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	 Then cauterize it with a two-pronged cautery, over two eyebrows just under the hairline.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	 And keep away from the artery to avoid cutting it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	 And this is the form of the claw-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	 Section on the method of cauterization for softening an eyelid.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	 When the eyelid becomes soft due to illness or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, using this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	 And if you wish, cauterize it above the two eyebrows with two cauteries in every part; and let them extend from the two temples; and let the length of all the cautery be according to the length of the eyebrows; and do not place your hand with the cautery at its end, but rather according to the quantity that is being heated for the third eyelash.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	 And this is the form of the cautery in accordance with this lunar method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	 [Chapter title] On the method of cauterizing the eyelid when the hairs turn inward and poke out the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	 The cautery is in one of two ways: either a cautery with fire, or a cautery with a burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 In the cautery with fire, order the patient to let go of his hairs beforehand if he is one who trims them, until they extend and are evened out.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	 If the hairs poke him at their base: then hold his eyes with a plaster so that they do not move until they grow out.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	 When they grow out and are evened out, then place the head of the patient in your lap; afterwards mark his eyelids with wax using a sign shaped like a myrtle leaf; let the beginning of the sign be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	 Then place a moistened pot on cheesecloth or slippery elm bark over the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then heat the cautery, whose form is as follows:
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	 Then cauterize over the shape that you have marked multiple times, until the surface of the skin is burned as if it were the shape of a myrtle leaf in its entirety.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	 The sign of the health of your work is: if you see the eyelid of the eye already contract and hairs rise at the spot of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Lift your hand then, and let it go for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	 Then place a cow dung with butter upon it until the ulcer is healed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with an ointment until it is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If any of the hairs return after an hour and the eyelid becomes soft: then apply cautery again to that place, as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	 If however the hairs are below (the spot): then cauterize it until they rise to their own place; and let it be so that the hairs do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing with a burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 It is to be commanded that the sick person let go of their hairs until they grow out and become equal (to each other).
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	 Make it from cloth into the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	 Then take from known soap and uncooked lime each a pound ounce or so, then grind them together with good grinding, and make it quickly so that it does not cool.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	 Then take the paste from what you made onto the cloth that you made in the shape of a myrtle leaf, and put it on the eyelid of one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	 And place under the eye cow dung soaked in egg white; let the head of the sick person be on your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	 Place your index finger on the medicine and press it a little.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	 And you will move it as often as the sick person feels the bite of the medicine, because its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	 While it continues to feel that bite which it has found, then let the medicine go and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	 When therefore the ulceration ceases, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	 And consider then, if you see the eyelid rising as if it is raised by contraction with fire or incision, that is good: and if not, then apply medicine on the place where the medicine does not adhere or blacken, and repeat the treatment until your operation is equalized and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	 Then place butter on top of it (the burned area), until the skin of the burn is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with diaphinicon ointment or another, until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	 And it is necessary for you during the operation that you keep the last precaution, lest anything from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If the eyelid becomes soft after days and something fights from hairs in the eye, then apply medicine on that place which becomes soft from the eyelid, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it, until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	 And this is the shape of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	 And know that human eyes vary in size and quantity.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	 Therefore according to this, your consideration should be: and do not hide the path of rightness which has concern for this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in the lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	 When you treat the fistula, if your treatment does not benefit as we said in the classification of diseases, then it is necessary to cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	 Order the sick person to place his head on your lap and hold his head with a servant between his hands so that it is not moved or shaken with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then put warm butter (infused butter) in the white of the eye or in the slime of the egg on his eye: then apply cautery iron whose shape is this:
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	 The cavity should be shaped like the form of a goose-quill pen's handle from one end, as is used for cautery; and if you wish it to penetrate to the other end, and if you wish it to extend upward in this manner.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	 However, this cavity is better suited for your task.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	 Then, if the fistula is open, squeeze it out and remove the pus from it; and if it is not open, then open it and remove the pus from within.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	 Then place upon it the cautery, which has been heated very well.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	 And hold your hand slightly on it near the cautery, from the eye to the nose part, so that your hand does not wander or shake weakly; and place the cautery upon the fat of the eye and destroy it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	 If you therefore reach at the beginning of your cautery to the bone, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 And if not: then place the cautery again once, or twice, as you need it; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	 Then place the wound with butter, and care for it with an ointment of turpentine, until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	 If more than forty days pass and it does not heal: then place on it a sharp corrosive medicine until the bone is exposed; and shave it according to what comes in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	 And there is another method of cautery for fistulas, which some of the first said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	 Focus on the location of the fistula, and puncture it; then place a fine cannula into the opening, that is, a fine needle, whose form this is.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	 Pour into it an amount of a drachma of melted lead, and hold your hand with the cannula well grasped, and let it not shake weakly in any way, so that the melted lead does not run or reach the eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	 And it is necessary that you place on the eye of the sick a cloth soaked in egg white, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	 For lead burns the place of the fistula and heals it by a wonderful healing process.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	 If the fistula heals along with what has been said from the cautery, and with treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	 And if it does not heal, then it is necessary to open the nostril opening and guide the fistula to the course of the nose, according to where it will return to its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	 On the method of cauterizing in fissures of the lips.
Caput XX.	 Chapter 20.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	 Many splits occur in the Lip, which are called Pilus, and particularly in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	 When therefore you treat these splits, as we have said in the division of diseases, and the treatment does not help, then with a small cautery tool, shape it according to this form.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	 And let its concavity be according to the subtlety of the scalpel.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	 Then put it immediately into the splits, until the cautery reaches the depth of the splits.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with ointment until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	 Chapter on Cauterizing a Mouth Fistula.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	 When an abscess occurs at the root of the gum, or in the palate, or at the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus and bursts: afterwards it becomes old, and the pus runs, and a fistula forms: then treat it, and treatment does not help, then it is necessary that you heat the cautery according to its size, so that it can catch in the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	 Then insert the heated cautery into the hole of the fistula and hold your hand until the iron heated reaches its depth and end: do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	 Then take care of it after that, as we have said in the treatment, until it is cured.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	 If therefore the pus separates and heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	 And if not, then it is necessary to expose the place, and remove the rotten bone according to where it comes out at its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	 Chapter on Cauterizing the Softened Gums and Teeth.
Caput XXII.	 Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 When the gums become soft due to moisture, and the teeth move, and you treat it with medicine, but it does not help: then put the head of the sick one on your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	 Then place the cautery tool, whose shape will come later, on the tooth and insert the hot cauterium quickly into it. Hold your hand for a short time until the weak feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	 And remove (the cautery tool) your hand; then repeat the cauterization several times as desired.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	 Then let the weak one fill his mouth with salt water and hold it for an hour, then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	 The tooth, when moved, becomes firm; the gums softened are tightened and the moisture corrupted is dried.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	 On the method of cauterizing teeth in dental pain.
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	 When the pain of a tooth is due to coldness or there is coldness itself, or worms, and healing with medicines does not help; then cauterization is done in two ways: either with butter-cauterization or with fire-cauterization.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	 Buttered cauterization is when you take cow butter and boil it in an iron pot or a copper one.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	 Then take a cloth, and fold it over the end of the wound.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	 Then immerse it in melted butter and apply it quickly to the painful tooth, hold it until it cools, then repeat this process several times until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	 And if desired, immerse wool or cloth in cold butter and place it on the painful tooth. Place hot iron upon it until the heat reaches the depth of the hollow of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	 Cauterization with fire is to be done with an iron or brass pipe (cannula).
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	 There should be something bulky in the body so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the weak bone.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	 Then, with cauterization by fire, bring the shape as it comes; place it on that tooth and hold your hand until the cauterization cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	 Repeat this several times because pain is removed either on the same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	 In the application of cauterization, it is necessary that the weak bone fills with good butter and holds it for an hour; then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	 This is the form of the cauterization.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	 Cauterize with whatever end you wish, according to what is possible; this is the form of the cannula.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization for abscesses.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter XXIV (24).
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	 When the abscesses are due to phlegm and cold moistness, and are not obedient to digestion by medicines, and you desire a rapid digestion of them; then use cauterization with a concave heated iron whose shape is as follows:
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	 Having two open ends, so that smoke may exit at the cautery from one of them: and place it (the cautery) on top of the ulcer once, and again if needed, until it reaches the depth of the ulcer.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	 If the ulcer is small: then place the cautery according to the size of the ulcer.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	 Then let it be for three days, and place a wet cloth soaked in butter on top of it until what the fire has burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	 Then care for it with tooth ointment until the form of the canal is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in laryngitis and constriction of coughing.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	 When moisture prevails over the larynx of the lung, and especially when it is accompanied by cold, then it is necessary that a sick person is evacuated first with soluble medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	 Then cauterize it (the larynx) in the neck at the root of the throat in a depressed place: and be careful not to reach the throat with the cautery, nor into the skin, unless something of that kind is necessary.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	 Then cauterize it with another cautery at the junction of the neck near the last vertebra of that vertebra's end: and let the cautery be similar to the one used before.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with what was used before until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in diseases of the lung and cough.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter 26.
