Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	 When cough and disease of the lung are from cold moisture, and the sick person does not have fever, phthisis, or chronic disease: then cauterize it with two cauteries above the clavicle in depressed, gentle, open places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	 And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between two breasts: and let the cautery be in the shape of a cannula as previously described.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	 And if your cauterization is to be by piercing with a cautery called Punctum, whose shape was previously described in the treatment of ear pain; and there should be punctures spaced about thirty apart or so.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with what was previously mentioned until it heals.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	 And now let the cautery have three branches, in this shape.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	 Because the cauterization is to be applied when you use a single cautery in place of three.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	 Title: Method of Cauterizing in Titillico, for Dislocation of the Arm.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter XXVII.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	 When the arm is dislocated due to aid assistance and does not heal within an hour of its return from dislocation, until it becomes accustomed to this act; then dislocate it slightly, as we have already testified this, at that time, it is necessary to reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	 Then the patient lies down on his back or on his healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	 Then peel off the skin that is inside Titillico towards the upper part with your left hand's fingers; and if the dislocation occurs towards the inside.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	 Then take a cautery with two forks.
Cuius forma est haec.	 Its shape is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	 Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates it on the other side, and the figure of the cauterization comes with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	 And when the cauterization is made with a cautery having three prongs, then the figure of the cauterization is that of six cauteries: and there are prongs according to the subtlety of the skin tested.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	 And this is the form of a cautery having three prongs.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	 And sometimes one is added to this method, so there are eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	 Then place upon the cautery stretched rods with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	 Then make the sick person quiet so that a limb is not moved at any time until it recovers.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	 And if a dislocation is towards the upper part, and it rarely happens, then cauterize the same on the shoulder with a curved cautery, or with many cauteries poking.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	 For union strengthens, and moisture is removed; and the sick person recovers.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	 [Paragraph] On the method of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	 When coldness and many humidities occur in the stomach until it separates itself from its composition and produces many catarrhs on it, and continues with unproductive methods of treatment: then the sick person must lie down on his back, and extend his legs, and hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	 Then cauterize with three cauteries, with a cautery under the size of one finger on the chest with a curved cautery, and two cauteries below from both sides of one cautery, until the figure of the cauteries comes to a triangle.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	 And stretch between them so they do not join together when pus forms.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	 And the depth of the cautery shall be the size of two thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	 And the figure of the cauteries shall be in this shape without addition: and if you wish to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this shape: and let the cautery that is made for this cauterization be one in the shape of a circle according to this shape.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	 And the stomach is cauterized by pricking it for those who are afraid of the cautery, and it is to be marked on the stomach with signs according to the quantity that you wish with encaustic wax; then cauterize it with the same cautery as the puncture; then care for it with the cure that preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	 On the method of cauterizing the epigastric vein (Epigastric artery).
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	 When pain occurs in the liver due to coldness and dampness, or from thick wind that does not leave by its natural discharge, and the patient is treated with what was said but it does not improve in him; then the sick person must lie on his back on his neck, and mark with encaustic wax three cauteries according to this shape, and the same quantity below in the epigastric area, where the arm reaches; and let there be a space between each cautery according to the thickness of a finger; and let the cautery be according to the length of the straight body, and do not press your hand with the cautery too much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	 And let the quantity to be burned from the thickness of the skin be not added to half of it; and let the sick person stand on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	 If he is not standing, then let him be lying down, who has already extended his legs and lifted his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	 This is the shape of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	 And you yourself can cauterize these cauteries with a surgical cautery when subtlety and wisdom are present in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	 And beware that you do not proceed too far in the cauterization, and the thickness of the skin is burned, for the body is burned entirely, and it reaches to the intestines; since the skin there is delicate, know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	 Method for Cauterizing Liver Abscesses.
Caput XXX.	 De modo cauterizandi apostemata super hepatis.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	 When there is an eruption (abscess), and you wish to know if it is in the liver's flesh or its covering: then if it is in the liver's flesh, a weak pain and heaviness without sharpness occurs: and if it is in the liver's covering, with pain there is intense sharpness: and you see that the treatment of it has tired the doctors.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	 Therefore, let the sick one lean on his neck (shoulder).
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 Then make a figure of the abscess's place with hot iron (encaustrum): then heat the cautery that is similar to a rod (cauterium).
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	 And cauterize it with one cautery until the entire skin is burned and it reaches the pus, until all the pus comes out: then treat it with cure of abscesses, until it is healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	 And it is not necessary to use this cautery method unless one's dedication extends to the art of medicine, and whose hands are afflicted by these diseases at times through experience: then let him dare on such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	 But it is better for him to be dismissed by me.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	 Chapter XXXI (31).
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	 The ancients said that the cautery with the roots of Aristolochia (a plant) should be applied to a cold pleurisy according to this method.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	 And it is to receive from the dry roots of Aristolochia (plant) a longer root, which can be found there, and let it be as thick as a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	 Then immerse it in oil: and ignite it.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	 Then cauterize it with one cautery at the point between the joining of the clavicle (furcula) and neck, and with two small cauteries under the chin a little below the jawbone.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	 And with two cauteries also in that which is between the fifth and sixth ribs, slightly towards the back; and with one cautery in the middle of the chest, and another on top of the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	 And with three cauteries from the back: one in that which is between the two floating ribs; and with two cauteries from both sides of the chest, below one that is between the two floating ribs.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	 And it is not necessary to press your hand with the cautery, rather it should be on the skin that is noticeably smelling.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	 And some of the ancients have said that there are people who use a cautery similar to an iron rod and heat it up, then push it inside where the ribs are, until they reach the apostema with it, so that pus comes out; as we said in the treatment for Epatis abscess.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	 But in this perforation with the cautery there is fear that either the weak person dies immediately, or a fistula occurs at the site, which is not healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	 § On the method of cauterizing the Spleen Head, Chapter XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	 When you are treating the sickness of the spleen, as we said in the treatment of diseases, and your treatment does not help, then cautery on it is to be used according to three methods, which are all correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	 One of them is that you make three or four cauteries in a row along the length of the spleen in the form of the cauteries of the liver (which was described earlier).
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	 And the thickness between each cautery should be the size of a finger or more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	 And the method of cauterization should be equal to that which was said in the cauterization of the liver.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	 And do not press your hand with the cautery; and the sick person should lie on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	 Another method for cauterization is: hold two rods of fire, which we have mentioned in the chapter on dislocation of the humerus; and peel off the skin that is directly above the spleen, where the invalid's elbow arrives; and let your elevation of the skin be according to the width of the body, so that the rods fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	 Then introduce two rods of fire very deeply, until they penetrate the skin from the other side; then remove the cauterization; thus there will be four cauterizations.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	 And if you wish to cauterize with a cauterization having three rods.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	 Then care for the cauterization after you have released it to emit pus for many days; for it is more effective than what has come before in treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in Hydropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	 A cauterization does not fall in Hydropsy, unless it is properly applied.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	 When you treat Hydropsy with the methods of treatment that we have mentioned in the division, and the treatment is not effective, then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauterizations around the navel, and one over the stomach, and another over the liver, and another over the spleen, and two behind the back between the loins, and one directly on the chest, and another directly on the stomach; and let the quantity of the depth of the cauterization be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	 Then release the open cauterization, so that it emits pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	 And do not evacuate the invalid from treatment after the cauterization with it; for it is necessary that two intentions are applied to him; and healing will hasten towards him with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	 The form of the cauterization with which the abdomen is cauterized should be clavilis; according to its previous form; and the one with which the back is cauterized should be olive oil, according to its previous form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	 On the manner of cauterizing Feet and Legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	 De modo cauterizandi Pedes, crura et membra inferioria.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	 When they are punctured in Hydropico and filled with citrus water: it is necessary that you cauterize on the back of the Foot in the nocrati, which is between auricularem and anularem: and lift your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then lift your hand: and do not return it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	 The citrus water will run out, and let the cautery be in this shape.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	 Then make two cauteries on each leg, and let the cautery be with the tip of a scalpel-like cautery: and let the cautery be along the length of the leg, one below the knee, and another lower than that, about half the length of the leg: and over the whole hip, two cauteries: and leave the open cautery without long treatment: so that some water runs out: then treat it with what I have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	 On the method of cauterizing in the solution of the Belly.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter 35.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	 When the solution of the belly is from cold and moisture, until it weakens the powers retained and digestive, which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is treated with methods of treatment, and it does not heal: and you see a person suffering, who can tolerate an excessive cautery due to strong powers, then cauterize it with a large cautery on its own stomach, as was done in the cauterization of the stomach with a circular cautery, and four subtle cauteries around the navel, with a subtle claw cautery: and with a large cautery over alcatin above the alhossos, or with two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	 And if you see excessive moisture, and a person suffering from it, then cauterize it with a cautery on the backbone, and a cautery over the entire pelvis: and perhaps you may add two small cauteries near the large one on the stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	 The progressing treatment whose help is not in error.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	 On the method of cauterizing Hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter XXXVI.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	 When there are many old hemorrhoids or one in the anus, and they are made of thick, cold, or corrupt fluids, and they are treated as previously mentioned, then the cure is not effective: then cauterize three cauteries on the lower part of the loin slightly triangular under the almeidate, and a cautery beneath the navel about two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 If you think that the person's stomach is chilled and food is not digested, and you observe his face turning pale, then cauterize him on the stomach with a large cautery, as previously mentioned: also cauterize on Epar (possibly the liver), and another on the Spleen of the same person, with a cautery claw: leave the open cautery for some time: then care for him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	 Chapter on the manner of cauterizing Althelul after their removal.
Caput XXXVII.	 Chapter 37.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 When you remove althelul (a type of tumor or swelling), then heat the cautery which resembles a rod.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	 Then insert the heated cautery into the removed althelul: and with your last hand, bring it to the opening of the vein from which blood flows; do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	 If therefore there are many althelul (tumors), then cauterize each one with a cautery as previously mentioned.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	 Then care for them, with the treatment suggested by their ointments, until they heal.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	 And if you cauterize him with a large cautery on his alcatin (possibly the abdomen), it is more effective for his benefit.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	 Chapter on the manner of cauterizing a Fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	 Chapter 38.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	 When the sick person does not obey the incision and surgery as we have described in its place, and is frightened by it, perhaps he will heal with a cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	 If a fistula occurs and it becomes hardened, pus runs out of it, and its moist parts are corrupted.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	 Therefore, as is proper, you should test it with a thin probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	 Then recognize the depth of its size with a probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	 Then heat up a cautery similar to a rod.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	 Then insert yourself, heated (cautery), into the fistula and observe how deep you have gone with a claw.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 And repeatedly apply the cautery to it until all corrupted bodies are burned up, either once, or twice, or three times, according to the necessity of your case.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	 And be careful not to burn the nerve or a major vein if it is there; or if the fistula leads to the bladder or the intestine, then you must avoid these places altogether.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	 And do not perform this unless when the fistula is in a fleshy place; and be aware that it does not penetrate.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	 Then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	 If, however, the place is covered and matter is cut away from it, and remains for a long time; then you will know that it is healed completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	 And if no matter is cut away from it, then you will know that it is penetrating, or that there is a rotten bone inside of it, or something similar; whose memory will come back to its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	 \* Method for cauterizing the Kidney.\*
Caput XXXIX.	 Chapter XXXIX.\*
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	 When there is pain in the kidneys due to cold or excessive wind, and it weakens the body of a sick person as a result, then you should cauterize it on top of the flanks over both kidneys with a cautery over the entire kidney with a cautery similar to a claw, whose memory has been mentioned earlier.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	 And perhaps we cauterize it (the part) in the second instance in almeidatum (almond).
Quare uenient tria lineata.	 Because three lined ones are coming.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	 Therefore, they will be more useful in healing.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	 On the method of cauterizing a bladder.
Caput XL.	 Chapter XL.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	 When weakness and softening of the bladder occur due to cold and humidity, until the weak person is unable to retain urine, then cauterize it in the lower part of the scrotum above the bladder, where the hairs of the beard begin, with a cautery on the right side of the scrotum and another one on its left. The length of this cauterization should be equal to the size of the knuckle of the little finger. Cauterize it with a lower back cautery or with two cauteries if necessary; the size of the second cautery should follow the first one.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	 Method of cauterizing the Womb.
Caput XLI.	 De modo cauterizandi Matricem.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	 When coldness and moistures occur in the Matrix (Womb), and it is prevented from becoming pregnant by this, and its menstrua are corrupted, and their provocation is delayed, and pain occurs near their arrival, then it is necessary that it be cauterized with three cauteries around the navel, as we said in the cauterization of the bladder, and a cautery on top of a lump below the back, or with two cauteries: and let the cautery be claw-shaped.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	 In the manner of cauterizing Anus in dislocation.
Caput XLII.	 Chapter XLII.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	 When the humors of the mucosa flow towards the anus and cause its expulsion from its place; and the sign of this is that the leg is extended over the other, when they are compared together: and a location of dislocation is found empty therein.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	 Therefore, it is necessary to apply a weakened cautery over the anus of itself with a similar circular cauterion: after you mark the location around the anus with encaustum, as is revolved: and so that the anus falls into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	 And let the cautery be of such a shape as that which preceded in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	 If this cautery is not present for you, then cauterize it with three cauteries, with a large oil-soaked cauterion: and let the depth be made according to the thickness of the skin in its entirety.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	 Chapter on the manner of cauterizing in sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	 Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	 When pain occurs in the ankle bone and the cause is coldness and moisture, and the patient is ill with it as we said in division, and the treatment does not help, and it deteriorates: then it is necessary that you release the patient from thick humors with fetid pills or with artificial pills, or similar ones.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	 Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	 And the method of cauterization is according to two methods: either cauterization with medicines that come forth, or cauterization with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	 Cauterization with fire is according to many modes.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	 One of them is that you cauterize on the ankle bone itself with three triangular cauteries in this shape.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	 And make a good or bad depth for them.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	 And let the space that is between every cautery be of the size of a finger's thickness; and let the cautery be olive-oil dipped.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	 Sometimes, however, the cautery is made in the middle on top of the ankle bone itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	 Why are there four cauteries?
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	 And if you wish to cauterize with a circle whose shape preceded in the cauterization of the dislocated ankle, one should be such that the entire ankle is contained within the circle.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	 Burn the thickness of the skin altogether.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	 This is the method of cauterization for sciatica when the pain is attached to the ankle itself and does not extend to the hip and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	 But if it extends to the hip and leg, then cauterize it with two cauteries on the hip, in the place where the patient indicates, in which there is pain, and your cautery four fingers deep into the woody part: let the cautery be a knife-shaped one.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	 And let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	 If the sick person indicates that the pain extends up to the toes of the foot, then cauterize it there where he indicates with a cautery, three, or four, or more, if necessary.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	 And if he indicates that the pain is turned towards the shin, then cauterize it there with a single surgical knife-cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	 And be careful with all your cauterizations that you do not burn the nerve or the main artery by doing so, nor attract bad harm to the sick person through this, or cause a contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	 I myself have already seen one and another of those who cauterized above the heel, and burned in the cauterization, and the leg became swollen until the swelling reached the foot, and it was perforated completely, and the entire foot was destroyed: then there followed a rupture of the stomach, and death afterwards.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	 If the pain is in two parts at the same time, then cauterize each one according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	 And some wise men have said in cauterizing the anus, whose cautery method this is.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	 Make a similar instrument of iron, whose diameter is the half of a palm: and place it at its opening according to its size, or less slightly: and within this instrument there should be a third instrument.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	 And let the space be which is between all the instruments according to the size of a knuckle: and let the instruments be open from two parts: and let their height be like a knuckle, or two knuckles: and make handles for them from iron properly fitted in the instruments.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	 Then it is heated in the fire until it glows and emits sparks: then it should be placed on the pillow of the sick person's anus, lying on the healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	 Cauterize him with three round cauteries at once.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then let him rest for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	 Afterwards, pack it with butter and leave the open wound for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with an ointment until he is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	 Says Albucasis to his sons, we have little experience with this kind of cautery due to its frightening appearance; and therefore, few await it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	 Nevertheless, it is one of the good cauterizations for him who endures it, and it finds its place in his case.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	 The cautery with forceful medicines is such that you should make two bands containing a perforated armillary sphere which descends from the hinge of his door made of copper or iron, the length being equal to the wall; and in their height there should be two nodes, or as if they were themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	 And let there be the space between the two of this size equal to the thickness of a finger, and be open below and above; and let it enclose each other according to this shape.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	 Then place it on an amphora of oil, with the sick person lying weakly on the sound side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	 And press your hand hard on the amphora of oil.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	 Then pour water between two circles which has been heated slightly with fire and hold it for the length of an hour; let the sick person bear its biting and burning, since he feels the biting like fire, until the biting stops.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 Then clean your hand with an instrument and wash the oil from the amphora with sweet water; then let it rest for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	 And place butter over it until the blackness of burning is removed; and let it run for some days, and pus will flow from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	 The remedy is at the end.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then, treat it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	 If the pain spreads to the hip or leg, make a cupping glass with water, as you did with the ankle, equally.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	 And this is the method of hot water: I have already written it in the treatise on the correction of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	 Take an equal portion of both alkali and unburnt lime; grind each one, and put them in a new pot whose lower part is perforated with a small hole, according to the quantity that should enter the radius; and put another pot made of clay under it; throw over the alkali and lime from sweet water, so that they are submerged by a finger's depth; afterwards, compress them with your hand; then leave the pot, until the acid water descends to the lower part of the clay pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	 Then mix that water with another lime and throw it over it; boil until it is renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	 For it will then be very strong for the sharpness required in many medical operations, and in cauterizing other parts of the body.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	 Because it performs the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	 And among the medicines for cauterizing ankles are also such as tesisie, honey from the cardamom seed, and lime with soap, so that both are mixed.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	 And Galenus himself has related a cure by an ancient man for the pain in the ankle and sciatic vein, which he highly praised.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	 And he said that it did not require any other treatment and that it was cured with a single application, until he related that perhaps the man himself entered the bath and came out already healed.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	 And it is to be taken from fresh seitaragus: and if no green one is found, take a dry one, recent: and grind much with some fat, and place on the sore, or leg, or in the hip: and tie it, and leave for the quantity of three hours, or until the patient feels sufficient heat.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	 Then insert it into a bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	 When his body becomes warm, immerse him in the sun.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	 For the pain departs, and he is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	 And know that no one should use cautery with these medications unless after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	 And Dioscorides says that goat's droppings, when they are cauterized on the sciatic vein, bring about a second kind of cautery.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	 Take wool and soak it in old oil, and place it over the deep place that is between the little toe and the heel, and closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	 Then take dry goat's droppings, and heat it in fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	 Then place it on the wool, and leave it until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	 Then do it again.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	 Do not stop doing it until sensation reaches the sore and the pain ceases.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	 This method of cautery is called "Vaccinum" cautery.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	 Chapter on the Cauterization of Back Pain.
Caput XLIIII.	 Chapter XLIV.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	 When there is back pain due to various causes, such as an accident, blow, excessive evacuation, and similar conditions, caused by the infusion of cold and moist matter: cauterization does not apply except in this one case, which is made from the infusion of cold and moist matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	 Therefore, after evacuation of the sick one, with fetid pills and similar ones, three lines should be made on the back where there is pain, each line second to the width of a nail, after signs have been marked with encaustic along every line with five cauteries, or more according to the amount that comes from the sick one's tolerance, and cauterization should be done with cauteriopuncture.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	 And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauteries along with a medial nail cautery, according to this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	 Section on the method of cauterization for a hump-like growth.
Caput XLV.	 Chapter 45.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	 This affliction often occurs in young children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	 And the sign of its onset in children is that it occurs on him during constriction at the breath-taking moment during elevation, and you find in the last vertebrae of the back and their nodes which have already begun to protrude above the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	 When you see that and wish to do it, then cauterize it with a circular cautery in this shape.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	 And the cautery should encompass all parts of the vertebrae equally: and if you wish to cauterize around the vertebrae with a pointed cautery, take two lines or three; and let the points be close to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	 Then care for the place until it is healed as we said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	 And beware not to administer cautery in a hump-like growth that occurs in a muscle spasm.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	 Section on the method of cauterization for gout and joint pain.
Caput XLVI.	 Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	 When joint pains are caused by cold humors that flow to any part of the body, then when pain occurs in the feet, it is customary among physicians to call it gout properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	 When therefore gout is treated due to a cold cause and pains do not subside, then cautery removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	 And it is to cauterize him after evacuation at the joints of the feet, with many cauteries; and let the cautery be called Oliuare.
Cuius haec est forma.	 This is its form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	 And if it is necessary to prick on the sole of the foot, then do so with a cautery point.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	 If the pains ascend to the knees or other joints, and this often happens, then cauterize it on all knees with three or four cauteries from every side, with this same cautery called Clavili.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	 If you need more of this cautery, then cauterize it.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	 And do not immerse your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be about as thick as the skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	 If the pains ascend to the knees and back: then administer what was said regarding cautery in its chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	 If the pains are only in the hands, then prick at the joints of the fingers, as two lines revolve.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	 If a pain remains in the fingers, then prick them, on every knuckle and on the back of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	 If pains ascend after days to the elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both from every side.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	 And do not evacuate a weak person due to good care or intake of medicine.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	 For if the regimen becomes good and phlegm evacuated, it will be healed with the help of God using this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	 Chapter LXVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	 If a rupture occurs in the groins and the intestine or bladder descends towards the testicle, which is beginning, then it is necessary that you order a weak person to abstain from food on his day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	 And it should be used from the softening agents, so that the feces may descend from his own belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	 Then let him sit on your hands upon his back: and command him to hold his breath, until it comes out, or appears pus, or intestines.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	 Then bring him back with your fingers, and mark with pitch under the incision on his neck, with the sign whose end is similar to half of a circle above the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	 Then heat the cautery with this shape until it becomes white, and throw sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	 Then return the intestine, or pus into its cavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	 Then let the servant place his hand on the place so that the intestine does not come out: and you have already opened between the legs of the sick man, and put a reed under him, and another servant is on his legs, and another one on his chest who holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	 Then place the cautery on top of the mark, with your hand holding the cautery straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	 Hold him until you follow the bone with it: or take another turn with it if you are not able to reach the bone with it in the first place.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	 And be careful to observe the exit of the intestine during your cauterization hour, lest you burn him and it comes upon him either death or great harm.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	 And know that when you do not reach the bone with the cautery, your operation is of no avail.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	 It is necessary that the cautery for children should be subtle, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then take care with the remaining ointments until he is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	 Let the sick man lie on his back for forty days until the wound is sealed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	 It is necessary that you place his nourishment for the duration of his treatment, which softens his stomach, so that the intestine does not come out in defecation or vomiting.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	 Then, when he wishes to operate forty days later, then administer a properly made ligature and hold it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	 And reduce from labor, and filling of food and drink, and with loud voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	 For when using this regimen, then it is cured with complete healing.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	 And I will say the cure for ruptures with incision in its own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	 When ruptures happen in the remaining abdomen and are beginning, and it desires not to add them, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautionery according to its size: and let what is being cauterized be as the third of its.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	 Then cure it itself, with what I said: and let not more be added.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	 And indeed some of the first have said that the rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautionery in this manner.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	 After it is signed with an enkaustrum, and a line is placed which is across the width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	 And place your hand in the middle with the cautery chisel.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	 But the first cautionery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing for pain due to rupture or blow.
Caput XLVIII.	 Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	 When pain occurs in certain members due to a blow or injury; and it lasts for a long time, and it does not help with medication; then it is necessary to be cauterized with the cautionery of the puncture point.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	 And let the cautionery be of all members according to its size, and its smallness, and its weakness, and its power, and the location of torsion, and pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	 If it is cured with the first cautionery, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	 If not: then repeat the cautery upon it.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	 Because by the custom of such pains it is to exchange one member for another which is nearer to it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Therefore you must pursue them with the cautery until the sick one is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in Leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	 Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	 Leprosy is sometimes benefited by cautery, with great benefit.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	 And particularly the type of leprosy caused by corruption of phlegm and melancholy: when considering to burn it.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	 If the leprosy is beginning and you have treated it as described in the division and it does not improve nor stabilize: and if you fear that corruption will affect the entire constitution of the patient: then burn him on the head with five cauteries: one in the middle of the head, known as the fontanelle; second below it towards the forehead at the end of the hairline; two above the two horns (of the forehead); and one behind on the nuchal bone.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	 And finally, with your hand (holding the cautery), press it gently onto the bone until it makes a small impression on the cheekbone and the cortex is dislocated: to alleviate the expiration of thick vapors from it; and burn also the spleen with the cautery, according to what has preceded.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	 If the leprosy is already widespread over the patient and it is apparent: then you must burn with these cauteries, which we have mentioned in the head; and one cautery on the tip of the nose; two cauteries on the cheeks; two cauteries on the spine of the neck; six on the spine of the back; one large one on the heel at the achilles tendon and one on the sacrum; two on the ankles: namely one on each ankle; two on the elbows, two on the wrists, two on the forearms, and two on the soft parts of the chest; and burn it over every joint, from the joints of the fingers of his hands to those of his feet; and burn it over every heel of his feet, and the soles of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	 Beware of burning the nerves that are above the last toe of the heel.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	 And sometimes [the cautery] is burned upon the neck of the chin, and another [upon] the stomach, and another [upon] the epigastric region.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	 And know that, the more you increase the cautery, it is more helpful, and more contributing.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	 And know that, the sick [person] does not find pain in cautery, as the healthy ones do: therefore, because his body is already numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	 It is necessary that the cauteries be of various sizes and shapes according to the limbs and joints: according to which they precede in types of tools.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then treat [the cautery] with flour of herb and honey, and the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in Fainting.
Caput L.	 Book L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	 When a member [body part] is numbed and treated with medications, oils, plasters, but does not heal, then cauterize the numbed member with cauteries, according to the size of the member or its smallness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	 And let your cautery go somewhat deep into the thickness of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with an ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	 Sometimes a cauterization is done for something related to numbness that happens in the hand and foot, in the joints of the back near the nerve exits that move that member; and the numbness is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	 But do not presume to do it, unless he who does it is wise in the anatomy of members and the exit of nerves moving the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	 Chapter on Cauterization in Albucasis.
Caput LI.	 Chapter LXI. (61st chapter)
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	 When Albaras is putrefied [decayed] and does not gain anything from medicine; then cauterize on it with a deep cautery somewhat, according to the thickness of the skin until the white part is removed and its color is changed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with a mixture of grain of wheat and lentils with rose oil, leaves of arnoglossa, blood of a pigeon and frog; each should be equal part: mix all these together, soak them on cloth, and apply to the place until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	 Chapter on Cauterization for Cancer.
Caput LII.	 Chapter LXII (62nd chapter)
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	 When cancer is beginning and you wish to stop it; then cauterize it with a circular cautery around it, as it revolves.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	 The wise ones said that it should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	 I do not see it so; because I fear that it may burn [cause blisters]; and I have already seen this many times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	 It is more correct to cauterize around it with a circle, as we have said; or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	 On the method of cauterizing in Adubelati.
Caput LIII.	 Chapter LIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	 When someone has Adubelati and it is delayed in maturation, either due to excess causing it, or due to the weakness of old age, when it is decrepitus pauci sanguinis, or due to time and the desire to hasten in the maturation of Adubelati, then cauterize around it with many small cauteries by puncturing.
Deinde dimitte eam.	 Then let it go.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	 For itself it will hasten with the maturation.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	 If you wish to perforate it with a cautery, then heat the cautery, of which this is its shape:
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	 Place it in the middle of the Adubelati, until it penetrates the skin; and let the cautery that follows be weak, so that the course of the purgatives may be alleviated.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing a corroding disease.
Caput LIIII.	 Chapter LIV.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	 A corrosive is not anything but a corruption that walks in a member and consumes it, like fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	 If you see a corrosion in a place where a cautery with fire can be applied, then apply the cautery with much fire, small and large clamps according to what is suitable for the location where the corrosion is present.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	 Then cauterize it from all sides until you have eradicated the entire corruption and nothing remains beneath it.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	 Then leave it for three days, and place over the cauterized areas powdered sulfur with oil until all scabs and corruption have been eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	 Then care for it with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	 If you see that after three days flesh is born in a healthy way without corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	 And if not: then reapply the cautery on what remains of the corrupted locations.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	 A corrosion is at times treated with an acidic medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	 It arises in the location of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	 However, a cautery with fire is more rapid in its assistance; and I myself have already said that the cauterization of it with acidic medicine is in the division; take it therefore there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing claws and warts.
Caput LV.	 Chapter LV.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	 This illness frequently occurs in the lower parts of feet; it is a thick, filtered affliction that harms the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	 The cautery is indeed in them according to two modes: the cautery with fire, and the cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	 As for the one with fire, it should be made similar to a concave cautery like that of a vulture's feather. It shall be made of iron, according to its size so that it contains a nail from all sides. It should be delicate at the edges.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	 Then place the hot one on the nail.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	 Then turn the hand with the cautery around the nail, until the cautery reaches the depth of the nail, and let it be for three days, until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	 Then apply ointment made with wild honey and salt crushed together on it, and let the ointment remain upon it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	 It will be uprooted from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of the place with a healing ointment for it to heal.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	 If they have not been converted and keep occurring on the surface of the body, particularly in hands and feet, then administer cautery with hot water. It is to be noted that you should take a cannula made of copper, iron, or from a vulture's feather, and place it on the nail or althea.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	 Then pour a little hot water into the cannula. Hold your hand and turn it with some pressure, so that the edge of the cannula is pressed on the root of the nail, and let the hot water find its way to the depth, to the root of the nail. The weak should wait for a short while under the scalding effect of the hot water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	 Then let it be, as the nail will be uprooted along with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	 Treat them one by one, until you have dealt with all of them on the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	 Then care for them after they have been excised, with that which generates flesh from ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	 On the Method of Cauterization in a Tremor (seizure).
Caput LVI.	 Chapter LVI.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	 When trembling occurs in a nerve due to cold or quartan fever or something else: then it is necessary that you cauterize it with four or five cauteries on the dorsal vertebrae, and between every vertebra with a cautery, and in its chest with a cautery, and over its stomach with a cautery.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	 The trembling quiets with the cautery of oil, and hastens the health of the cold sickness.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization by Albucasis.
Caput LVII.	 Chapter LVII.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	 At times, Albucasis expels foul things from the body, that is, pustules, which are made from corrupt matter.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	 Therefore, it is necessary first, when they appear, that they be cauterized on top of every pustule with a fine cautery and myrtle wood, the end of which is set alight with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	 Or with the root of long arista root.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	 Or with a convex cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	 And sometimes they are cauterized, at the beginning of their expulsion following this method: and they do not increase: and the superfluous part is broken off making them, and it heals from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	 Nevertheless, it should be done after evacuation with phlebotomy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in the flow of blood from an artery in a wound.
Caput LVIII.	 Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	 Often there is a flow of blood from an artery which has been cut near a wound, which happens externally, or at the incision of apostemata, or cauterization of a limb, and similar things: and it is difficult to separate it.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	 When this happens to someone, then you should promptly go with your hand to the opening of the artery and place your index finger over it: and press on it hard, until the blood is held under your finger, and nothing comes out of it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	 Then place in fire small oil-burning cauteries many in number; and blow over them until they become extremely hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.
