Then take one (of the hot cauteries), either small or large, according to the wound and the location where the artery is severed, and place the cautery upon the vein; then remove your finger quickly: hold the cautery until the blood is cut off.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	 If the blood is forced out along with your finger from the opening of the artery, and you extinguish the cautery, then take another one quickly, from those that are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Therefore do not stop doing it with one after the other until the blood is cut off.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	 And be careful not to burn the nerve that is there, and let no other harm come upon the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	 And know that when blood flows from the artery, then it is not possible to cut it (the artery); especially because the artery is large, unless with one of the four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	 Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	 Or with extraction, when it is not extracted (the blood).
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For when it is pulled out (the blood), the extremities contract and the blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	 Or it can be tied with a strong thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	 Or they may be placed upon it (the wound) medicines of which it is the property to cut off blood, and tightened with a bandage suitable for constriction.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	 Whoever administers the amputation with a ligature and tightening with a bandage or by placing on it things that burn (or similar), does not benefit him truly, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	 If that happens to someone and the doctor is not present or there is no medicine: then begin with the positioning of the index finger over the opening of the vein, as we have said, and tighten it very much until the blood is compressed by the upper part of the wound, and on the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	 Do not remove the finger, apply cold water strongly on it, always until the blood freezes and swells, then cut it off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	 Meanwhile, consider what it needs from cautery or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	 Part of the First Part Ends.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	 Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	 Chapter on incision, perforation, and phlebotomy in wounds and similar cases.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	 We have already said in the first chapter that every sickness in which it is appropriate to burn with fire using cautery and medicine, as well as its occasions, causes, instruments, and forms of cauteries.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	 And there I placed chapters from the neck down to the feet.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	 I will proceed in this chapter in the same way, to relieve the one who is seeking the sought-after thing.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	 And before I begin that, you sons should know what is in this chapter from the fear of what was in the first chapter about cautery.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	 And therefore, it is necessary that there be greater caution because in the operation that is in this chapter, evacuation often occurs with blood, which holds life when the vein is opened, or an incision over a boil, or an opening of discharge, or treatment of a wound, or extraction of an arrow, or an incision on a stone, and similar things: from all of which trembling, fear, and death occurs in many.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	 And I warn you that the danger should not fall on you, for sometimes it falls on people like you with the weaknesses of this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	 For there are those who get angry with their sickness and death is easy for him because of his fierce nature, which he finds due to the weakness of his sickness and the length of his evil-doing.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when the sickness is from fear, it signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	 And he who gives his trumpet to thee and tells thee with it that he is well, hoping for health, and his sickness is fatal.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	 Therefore, you should not agree to him who comes to you whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	 Let your caution be more violent than your greed and your avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	 And do not presume upon anything from it unless after a certain knowledge, which verifies at your place the praiseworthy outcome of its arrival.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	 And use for the cure of all your sick ones, prognostication and indication concerning that to which it is fittingly suitable for health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	 For in it there is help to you in the obtaining of fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	 May God inspire you, O sons, His understanding, and may He not take away from you guidance and inspiration; for it is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	 And I myself have arranged this chapter by dividing it into sections according to what preceded in the chapter on Cautery, from the neck down to the feet; so that you may be relieved of that which you seek from him and that for which you are in need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	 Chapter on treating the water that collects in children's heads.
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	 Know that this weakness often occurs in children at birth or when the midwife tightens the child's head without caution.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	 It also sometimes happens due to unknown causes which are not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	 And indeed, I have not seen this ailment in anyone but children; and to everyone whom I have seen from among them death soon followed; therefore it seemed good to me to abandon the operation in that case.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	 And indeed, I have seen a child whose head was filled with water and his head swelled every day until he could not sit on himself due to the size of his head; and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	 And this moisture can accumulate between skin and bone or under the bone on the cheekbone (sifac).
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	 If the moisture is between skin and bone, and there is a small abscess, then it is necessary to make an incision in the middle of the head, a split about two fingers wide; and the length of the split should be like that of two knuckles, until the moisture runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	 And this is the form of trepanation (spatulum).
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	 If the moisture has increased significantly and the abscess is larger, then make two splits in this manner (the same way).
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	 If the moisture is under the bone and there is a sign that you see the skull open widely from all sides; and water sinks when you press it with your hand towards the inside, and this does not hide from you; then make three splits in the middle of the head in this way (the same way).
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	 And after making the incision, remove all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	 Then tie the splits with cloth and wool (to prevent infection).
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	 Then pour wine and oil over it for five days (as a dressing).
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	 Then loosen the tie, care for the wound with dressings and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	 Do not release to bind the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	 Feed the sick man with dry food of little moisture until he recovers his limb and is healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	 Another method of incision is to consider where the size of the abscess appears, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	 Because it sometimes is more, either in the head, or the forehead, or on the right, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	 Therefore ascend with the incision where the abscess appears and is filled with water, and cut it as much as you are able.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	 And observe, do not incise an artery, and let blood flow out, and the sick person dies from this flow with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	 Incision of the Arteries which are after the ears.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	 When catarrhs occur to the eyes or the chest, and it does not ameliorate with treatment of medications, then the final cure is in this, an incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	 Therefore when you want to incise them, let the sick person shave his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	 Then scrape the place with a rough cloth so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	 Then let the sick person bind his neck with any cloth of his.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	 Then consider where the vein pulses.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 And the places of both are places which are depressed behind the ears and are rarely hidden except in certain people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	 Then mark with pitch on both sides: and cut one with a lancet on each side, the incision reaching the bone: and let it be made across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	 And if you want, insert a lancet under the artery and cut it from above with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	 Let the length of the incision be as long as two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	 When a vein is cut, blood comes out with a pulsating flow, which jumps to the inside frequently.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	 If an artery does not appear to sight, then it is necessary that measurements be taken from the ear of three fingers' space.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	 Then mark with wax and bind until the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	 And that which must be taken out from blood is 6 ounces, and perhaps you take more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	 Entirely it should be cut according to the quantity which appears to you due to the force of weakness and the filling of that artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	 Then consider for the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	 If there remains to the bone anything from a tendon, then cut that so that a hot abscess does not occur; then bind the wound with linen strips.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with ointment until it is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	 Chapter on the extraction of arteries located in the temples.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	 When an old-time headache or acute catarrh occurs due to acid humidity and heat in the shoulders of the temples, or an old-style sodium, severe, and similar conditions; it is treated with methods of healing medicine but does not help; then we have been accustomed to extracting the arteries from the temples, or cauterizing them as we have said.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	 And the method of operation for extracting them is as follows: shave the weak hairs on the temples and direct attention to the appearing artery in the temple.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	 It is indeed shown to you by its pulse and it is rarely hidden except in a few people, or severe cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	 If it is hidden from you, then the weak person should bind his head with any cloth of his; then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	 If a boil occurs in a place with hot water, wait until it appears to you clearly.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	 Then take the lancet that I have prepared beforehand.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	 Then scrape the skin with it easily until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	 Then insert the hook into it and pull it out towards the upper part until you remove it from the skin, and let it come out from all sides of the layers beneath it.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	 If the artery is delicate: then roll it with the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 Then cut that part according to the size where its ends extend and contract, so that there is no bleeding.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	 For if it is not cut, and if it is not separated, the blood will not rise deeply.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	 Then empty six ounces of blood until the third (line).
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 If the artery is large: then it is necessary to tie it in two places with thick thread, silk or cord, or a strong cord, so that rot and decay do not approach it before the wound heals, and there is no bleeding.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	 Then cut off any excess that is between the two ties.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	 Do this during that hour or another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	 And if you wish, burn it with the cautery up to the bone, with a knife-shaped cautery, until its ends are cut and the operation is stable at that place.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	 And it is a better procedure unless the person has a fever, or is afflicted with coldness.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	 Because the cautery is made from those things that help to stop wetness.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	 Therefore it is better to use a remedy.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	 And after the extraction of the arteries, it is necessary to fill the place with heated clay and well-made poultices should be placed on top of it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	 After solving it shall be treated with dry medicines which cause growth of flesh, and with liniments until healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If during the operation bleeding occurs from an artery, then hasten to cut it with a cautery or fill the place with wax; and tie your hand until the bleeding stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	 If nothing of these is present to you, then place your finger on it until the blood freezes.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	 Wrap the place with water of strong cold, until the sharpness subsides, and bind it as necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	 And from this it is lighter and easier to extract the artery, that is, to cauterize the vein with this cautery having two blades; let the sharpness of the two blades be similar to a garnet (almandine).
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	 However, they are much less sharp than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	 Because if they are as sharp as two knives, each of them requires cold; and they do not cut the flesh quickly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	 Since they have a certain roughness, warmth of fire must be maintained in them, and the flesh is cut quickly; therefore this is better than any other work, easier, and more convenient.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	 And let the space between the two blades be the thickness of a finger, after you mark two places with hot iron; and place both very hot until they reach the bone, and cut the vein in two places: so that what is between its extremities is removed.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	 For they do not solidify completely with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	 And this is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	 Chapter on the treatment of sharp persistent lacrimal passages from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	 When the tears are persistent and there is a course of them from the veins that are on the outside of the skull of the head; and if nothing of medicine for treatment is added to them with medicines, and you see the face of the patient already turning red, and there is a sensation of walking as in ant-like motion on the forehead; and the eyes are exhausted, moist, so that the hair has been corroded by corrosion; and the eyelids have become warm from the acuity of the tears: then the ancients needed this operation for their treatment, and they called this treatment, "The Knife".
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	 And it is to command the sick one to shave the hairs that are on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	 Then make three equal incisions in the forehead: and let the length of each incision be about two fingers, and one should be in the middle of the forehead, and the second slightly below the movement of the arms, and the third on the opposite side: and beware not to cut the arteries which are on both sides: and extend your hand from the continuation of the two jaws, and let the whole length of the incision be three fingers apart: and prepare a piece of sponge or dry cloth, with which you will absorb blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	 Then insert the handle of two sharp points, immediately following is its form.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	 From the first incision, which is near the temple, until the second incision: and scrape with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, together with what is above the eye.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	 Then do likewise from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	 Then remove the handle, and insert another tool named a sharp scalpel, blunt on one side, not sharp on the other side, into the first incision again.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	 And place its sharp side facing the attached flesh and skin, and its blunt side facing the bone: and push it until it reaches the middle incision: and remove with it all vessels that descend from the head to the eyes: except that the incision stops at what appears on the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	 Then do likewise in the middle incision until the other incision.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	 And when blood flows to an equal amount, squeeze the sites from the clotted blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	 Then place linen cloths from old boiling on all incisions, and put on top of them soaked woolen wads in wine, oil or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 Observe so that no hot abscess occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	 On the third day, loosen the ligature and administer much infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	 Then care for it with basilicon ointment, and the remedies for wounds until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	 On the care of acute tears (eyewash) and catarrhs of the eyes from internal parts of the head.
Caput V.	 Head V.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	 When anyone has acute, sharp, persistent catarrhs; and you see their eyes weakened, small, and their appearance already debilitated; and ulcerated eyelids, and hairs falling out from them, and there is acute pain deep within the head, causing discomfort and sneezing: then take, from these conditions, what those materials (catarrhs) do not come unless from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	 A better treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	 And it should be ordered for the sick to shave their forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	 Then make one incision in the middle of the forehead, or slightly to one side by width, from the left temple to the right temple; and let the incision be to the bone; and withdraw your hand from the temples which move during chewing; until the bone is exposed; and you will dry up all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	 Then separate the crack between the two lips of the incision with a heated iron or with linens made of flax.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 Then bind it from above with bandages; and moisten the bandages with wine and oil so that no hot abscess occurs.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	 And when you release it and see that the hot abscess is about to diminish; then it is necessary for you to scrape the bone until flesh begins to grow on it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	 Then care for it with dry dressing which makes flesh grow; as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of pitch; and prepare plaster from them and administer it for the growth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	 [Title: On the care of an ear wound]
Caput VI.	 [Chapter VI]
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	 Everything that falls into the ear is one of four types: either it is a mineral stone, or something similar to a stone like iron and glass: or it is from a plant such as chickpea and bean: or it is fluid like water, vinegar, and things similar: or it is some animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	 When a stone falls into the ear, or one of those not added (items) that do not grow in the ear, expose only the ear: if you see a stone then, pour something out of violated oil or sinamon thereon.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	 Then administer the extraction of it, and make him sneeze with a powdered mixture, and plug the nostrils at the onset of sneezing, after you place fragments of cloth or wool around the ear and stretch the ear upward.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	 For many times it goes out with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	 If it does not go out, then administer the extraction of it with Geista (Pizigaroli subtle), which is this form.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	 If it goes out with Geista, that is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	 And if not, then administer the extraction of it with a subtle blind hook few times.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	 If it does not go out through that, then make a tube of iron and insert the end of the tube into the ear hole many times, and plug what is around the tube with wax softened with oil so that the air goes only through the tube: then draw it out with your strong force.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	 For many times it goes out with what we have said.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	 If it does not go out in this way: then take from helkalimbat or vinegar (i.e., gluten prepared as birds are caught), a small amount of it; and place it at the end of the radius after you have placed a suitable plate over it; then insert it into the ear hole with ease, after you have removed the ear from moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	 If it does not come out with all that I have described, then hurry to cut before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	 The method of incision is that a lancet should first be applied to the sick person in the head region, and blood drawn out according to its power.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	 Then make the sick person sit between your hands and turn his ear upward, and make a small incision at the base of the ear in its fatty part at the lower side, until you reach the stone: then remove it together with it, as far as is possible for you with your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then, make the incision from your side quickly and carefully until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	 If what falls into the ear is one of the grains that grow and swell, then administer its removal.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	 But if it does not come out for you, then take a fine, delicate probe of this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	 And administer with it the removal of that species of grain which falls into the ear, and do not do this when you think that the grain is already moistened by the vapor of the ear, until you put many pieces on it: then remove them with tweezers or with a fine probe or with suction, as we have said, since its removal can be alleviated.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	 But the water which enters the ear should be used by the sick person to sneeze and cough at first: and already his ear is full with some heated old one: and it lies on top of it where the water is.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	 If it comes out through that (water), it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	 And if not (the water comes out), then take many stones of the size of a finger, soft, smooth and heat them slightly, and let the sick person insert one of them into his ear canal: let him salivate on one foot from that side, and strike with another stone upon the stone in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	 Therefore, it should not cease to do that with stone and stone until all water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	 And now the water comes out in such a way that you take one from parchment or reed, and insert its end into the ear; and light the other end with fire until it burns much of it.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	 Then take another reed and do that several times until all the water comes out; and draw it out with a tube according to what was mentioned above in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	 In the case of an animal entering it (the body), if it is small such as a flea and similar to it, treat it as I said in the section on division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	 But if it is of a large body, which appears to the sense: then administer its extraction with tweezers and hooks; and its removal is easier for all who hold it in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	 In the case of worms generated in the ear, when you treat it with what I said in the section on division and in the treatment of distillations, and your care does not help: then it is necessary that you look at the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	 If therefore something appears there from worms, then draw it out with tweezers or fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	 If therefore nothing appears there, then take a tube with this shape, narrow below and wide above; and insert its fine end into the ear according to the size that the sick one can bear; then draw it out gently with strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	 Do that repeatedly until all worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	 If they do not obey you to exit, then surround the ear with a tube filled with poppy seeds as I said in the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	 If they do not come out with what I said, then administer the distillations which the ancients have been experienced in killing worms; and you will find it in the treatment of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your outflow be oil and medicine into the ear with this instrument, whose shape is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	 As you see, make it from silver or bronze, narrow at the bottom and wide at the top, with a small hole at the bottom.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	 Therefore, let what is pressed inside the concavity of the tube be made of bronze.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	 And if you wish, take the radium and insert it at the end of it with a proper closure; then pour oil, or juice, or whatever medicine you wish among these into the tube; let it be in the ear; then insert the radium with its cover on top, and squeeze it with moderate pressure until the oil is pressed into the concavity of the auditory canal, and the sick person feels it inside; and whatever is poured into the ear should already be heated slightly with fire; and beware that nothing which distills into it is very cold; for medicines do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	 [Title] On the treatment of an aural impaction (blockage) of the ear.
Caput VII.	 [Chapter] Chapter VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	 Sometimes some infants are born without their ears being pierced from the wombs of their mothers.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	 It also happens that an impaction occurs in some people's ears as a result of a wound or flesh born there.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	 This impaction sometimes occurs deep within the ear canal, which is not visible to the eye; and sometimes it occurs near the outer ear canal, which can be seen.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	 Therefore, that which occurs deep within the ear and is not visible to the eye is difficult to treat in many cases.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	 And in that which can be seen, it is necessary to place the sick person's ear on the sun and look into it; then if you see an impaction, open it with a fine probe whose shape is as follows: its tip should have a small depression in which there should be a slight indentation, and the rest of the probe should be made of soft wood on both sides so as not to harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	 If therefore an ulcer arises from the flesh in the ear's meat: then hold it with a delicate hook and cut it with ease of great violence, until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	 If then an ulcer is in the depth of the ear: then take a delicate probe and make it warm slightly with fire; afterwards send it into the ear's meat.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	 If then you find an ulcer with it, that the patient is weak and has hearing difficulties, try to open it gently; and beware not to wound the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	 Then place linen in the ear according to the size of the hole you have closed with Egyptian ointment; do this for several days until you are sure about the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	 Or take linen, dip it in rose water, powdered with sieved asafoetida, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	 If you see the ear already suppurating: then it is necessary to remove the linen, and allow it with another piece of linen that you have wrapped in a cerate made with rose oil, until the warm suppuration settles; afterwards care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	 If there should be bleeding: then immerse a sponge or cloth in cold water, and place it on the ear; and use the remaining treatment, which removes the described bleeding in the chapter on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	 Chapter on the care of Althaea for eyelids.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	 Those Althaeas that occur on the eyelids of the eyes are sometimes moist and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	 Therefore hold them with forceps or with a hook, and cut them off with a knife from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	 Then apply powdered asafoetida.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	 If blood flows out from them, then cauterize them with a fine lentil-shaped cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	 To cauterize them is better after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	 For often they recur when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	 And when cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not recur.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	 Section on the care of grains on the eyelids.
Caput IX.	 Section IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	 Often something happens in the eyelids resembling sand in its firmness and hardness, and for this reason it is called grain; and it is an accumulation of thick moisture on the upper eyelid, and the lower one.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	 Therefore, the operation on them is to examine if it is grain coming out from the eyelid that appears, and move it to every part; its nature is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	 Find therefore a fissure above it in width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	 Then scrape it from every part with ease, until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	 Then hang it up with a hook and cut it off itself.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	 But if its removal is not prepared for you unless after you penetrate the eyelid with a small cut, then it hurts in some way when this is not done.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 If the fissure is large: then gather it together with a suture; and care for it until it heals up.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	 And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	 For unguent restores it and fills it up.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	 And if the grain is inclined towards the inner part of the ear and turns its surface inside, then turn the eyelid; hang the grain with a hook and press it from every side, as well as cutting it off.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	 If the eyelid is stretched out through an incision, this will not hurt in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Then clean the eye after the incision of the grain with salted water; and care for the place with it so that it may fill up until it heals up when weakened.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	 Chapter on the treatment of eyes.
Caput X.	 Chapter X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	 The Axeirnat is a drop that is generated in the upper eyelid; it mainly occurs in children; and it burdens their eyes, and they get cataracts in the mornings, and they cannot see the light of the sun, for this reason, because tears flow towards them, and for this you see them lying on their faces constantly, and they sleep on them, and their eyelids are always wet under the eyebrows, which has already been swollen; and the appearance of Axeirnat is evident to the eye, and when you press the place with your fingers, you feel the Axeirnat among them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 The method of his operation is that the sick places his head in your bosom.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	 Then take a linen cloth and prepare a swathing within it, and make out of this linen cloth a circle according to the quantity that contains Axirnath on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	 Then place him upon it and press with your fingers from all sides, so that Axirnath may be gathered together in the center of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	 Then find in its midst moisture with a spatula-like instrument making incisions along the length, and let there be no fissure greater than that which is made in phlebotomy in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	 Or it is necessary that you find the whole skin until you reach Axirnath, for in many cases, Axirnath proceeds out of a fissure in the shape of a white fat knot.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	 Therefore take it with a cloth, which you have moistened between your fingers to the outside, and you rotate your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed; and beware that you do not add to the fissure so as not to reach the eye with the spatula, and thus injure it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	 If, however, Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the fissure, you should add a little to the fissure with ease until it appears.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	 Then take it out, as I have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	 Then immerse the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on the place, and press it with small stones.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	 And among men there are those who grind salt and put it into the depression of the fissure, so that what remains of that moisture may be dissolved.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	 If, however, a hot abscess occurs in the place, then take care of it with soothing plasters until it is healed.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	 On the modes of Ataxmir of the eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft and causes it to weep excessively as it should not.
Caput XI.	 Of the operation called Ataxmir of the Eye, when the palpebral conjunctiva has been detached from its margins, in order to separate any adhesions that may have formed between the bulb and the upper or lower eyelid, as well as for the sake of examination.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	 When hairs grow on the eyelids beyond the normal course under natural hairs, and they turn grey: then they harm the eye, and cause the occurrence of symptoms such as constant tears, softening of the eyelids, and opacity, until it causes the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	 And Ataxmir indeed cures the eyes according to four modes.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	 Or by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	 Or with a sharp medicine, as was stated in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	 Or Ataxmir cures by incision and stitching.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	 Or with reeds, as I shall say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 You must place the head of the sick in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	 Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	 If it is turned, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	 And if it does not: insert the awl into it where there is a thread from below the eyelid, and let the awl penetrate with the thread on top, and be near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid, where the hairs grow: and draw the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it with a spoon.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	 Then find on the inside part of the eyelid under the added hairs with a blunt spoon coming from the larger tear duct up to the smaller tear duct.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	 Then draw out the thread, and place a small ball of wool or cloth under the eyelid; then mark the eyelid with hot wax in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	 However, it must be made in accordance with the size and elevation of the eyelid, because it is diversified in humans.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	 From these it is that which requires cutting according to the size of the eyelid, in accordance with the softening of the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	 Then, when you find the spur on two lines that you have marked, begin from the greater lacrimal to the lesser lacrimal, and let there be one fissure near the natural hairs, such as a tumor of the radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	 Then insert the hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	 Then scrape it entirely.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	 Then bring the two lips together with suture, with a sharp needle and fine woolen thread: and clean the blood, and make adhere what overflows from the threads on top of the eyebrows, if you wish to do so; and if not, do not cure.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	 Then release the suture and the threads for three or four days; afterward, take care of it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	 And if you wish, leave the wound without suture, and take care of it as it dries and contracts.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	 For the eyelid is raised at the sealing of the wound and the joining of it; but this will be better in the future.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	 This method of healing was taught by the ancients, Ataxmis.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	 However, there is concern for the patient in it, and it is from a good operation, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	 And another method is also in Ataxmis: and it is to mark on the eyelid a figure like that of a myrtle leaf, as we have said.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	 Then raise the eyelid with three separated or connected hooks according to the following shape, then cut what overflows with small scissors according to this shape with equal incisions.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	 If it is not possible for you to hold the hook and it does not fit; then take a point with thread, and insert it in the center of the figure: and insert another thread near the greater lacrimal, and another thread near the lesser lacrimal: and bring the threads together equally between your fingers.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	 Then loosen your hand with an equal lever: and loosen the skin over which is marked the tumor, as we have told.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then gather together two lips of the wound with a stitch: and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	 If however a boil should occur in your incision or wound: bind that boil with lint and similar materials, from ointments that soothe.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	 And sometimes it happens that the eyelashes turn over.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	 Therefore, it is necessary to use as we have said in the incision: but the suture of both is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	 On the care of Ataxir with dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	 And it is, that you turn the eyelid, and cut the cleft that is inside, as I have told.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	 Then make two dogs or two thin logs of appropriate length as the length of the eyelid and narrower than the width of the palpebra; and now you have cut at both ends of each side where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	 Then bind each one on top of the excess from the eyelid of the eye, and tighten the two dogs on both sides with a strong binding, and let it be for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	 The skin bound will die, and darken, and rot until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	 If it slows down, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	 When it has hardened, remove the eyelid and do not pluck the hairs.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	 And this is the form of two dogs which you will make according to this shape and size in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	 On plucking out painful hairs from the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	 Chapter XII.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	 The operation is to take a thin needle and insert a silk thread into it gently.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	 Then bind the ends of the threads together with a very fine knot; and the length of the threads should be one palm's breadth.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	 Then take another thin thread called Alinshat and place it under the first one for a short distance and knot the ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	 Then let the weak person place his head in your lap and bring it near to the sun so that the operation may be seen; since the operation is delicate or small.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	 Then introduce the probe sharpened (or pointed) into the root of the eyelid, and make it penetrate quickly into the eyelid until you draw out the natural hair from above.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	 Then pull the hair out up to the probe (or pointed instrument): introduce the probe into the hair follicle; if there is one or two or three hairs, do not introduce more than that.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	 Then pull your hand with it (the probe) until the hair comes out with the probe along with the natural hair from the eyelid.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	 If the probe is pulled out and no hair comes out with it: pull the probe downwards, using the thread you have tied to it, until the probe comes out through the upper opening, and you see it in the sight of the eye: then pull the probe, and the thread; extract both, and close the eye; leave it closed for two or three days so that the hair adheres to its place, and new flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	 If the hair is short, then attach a long one from the natural hairs and pull them together; or leave it (the short hair) until it grows longer, and then pull it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	 Chapter on the care of the eyelash that occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	 When this condition (eyelash problem) occurs in the eye, it is called "Leporina".
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	 And this eyelash condition may be either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	 Therefore, the accidental eyelash condition occurs from the congealing of a wound, a cut, a cauterization, and similar conditions.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	 And the method of treatment for this condition is to uncover that congealed area and separate its edges, place a clean piece of linen cloth between them, tie it in place until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	 It is not appropriate to use in the treatment of this condition substances that dry and constrict, as doing so will make it worse; instead, use substances that soften, such as fenugreek; embrocation with water, in which althea has been boiled, and linseed; and unguento dyaquilon, which has been softened with some oil; and apply the linen cloth dipped in this, and treat it with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	 Thy treasure of cure is, that thou strive with all thy skill, so that it not become consolidated, according to the form which was first.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	 This operation indeed, which we said, is nothing but a correction of Alzahraci, so that the form of the place does not return as it was entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	 On the treatment of Alzahraci that is done on the lower eyelid, and it is a swelling or contraction upward to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	 This which is below, is what is truly called Alzahraci.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	 And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	 And the accidental one occurs from a wound, or a crack, or cautery, and suchlike.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	 And the procedure in this is, that you take a needle, with which there is a double thread, and you dye it in flesh, and make it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right tear duct, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	 Then extend the flesh with the needle towards the upper part, and cut it with a broad spatula.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	 If then the form of the eyelid returns as it should be, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	 And if not, take a cautery, and place it in the crack, and turn the eyelid with it; and break two cracks on the inner side of the eyelid, and let their ends be from the two angles of the incision, until they converge and form an angle: until when gathered together, the shape becomes this shape, and it is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	 Then remove that flesh to the extent of its sharp lower side, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	 Then gather the separated parts; or gather it with a thread of wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	 Then care for them with what we said, regarding softening medications, and linen, until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	 And if Alxatrati occurs from a fissure, either by suture or cautery: then it is necessary to open the fissure flat under the eyelashes, as was previously described.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	 Then separate with linen between two lips, as we said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	 The summary of the treatment for Alxatrati, whether it is above or below, is to carry out the operation on it according to the preparation method for Alxatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	 For it is of many diverse shapes: and the skillful craftsman prepares his skill with whatever method is possible for him, until he makes it return to its natural shape or nearly so, and the sick person himself, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in various dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	 Chapter on the adherence of the eyelid with conjunctiva, or cornea.
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	 Whenever this consolidation occurs in many people, so that the upper eyelid becomes consolidated with the whites of the eye and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	 Therefore, it is necessary that you insert the tip of a rod under the eyelid and lift it up; or stretch it with a spatula; then cut the adherence with a fine spatula, not with the sharpness of a spatula's cuts, but rather bluntly; so that the sick person is not disturbed during the operation, and the spatula is removed, and does not harm the eye with its sharpness; and your incision should be like scraping off the adherence easily, until when the eyelid returns to its natural shape, and the adherence heals completely.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	 Then pour salt water into the eye, and rinse it with water; or distill it onto him from sifon made of sieve cloth soaked with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	 Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a linen strip: and place upon the eye wool soaked in egg white: and after the third day use it or with salves, until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	 On the incision of a nail and swelling of the flesh of tears.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	 Know that the nail is according to two modes.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	 Or it is horny: and it is similar to the hoof, hard and delicate.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	 Or it is not horny, similar to frozen white moisture, which when it touches the iron or you try to catch it with a nail, it breaks off and does not stick to the nail.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	 And both types do not begin unless from the greater tear, until it gradually spreads, until it covers the vision, and prevents light, and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the method of operating on it is: that you place the weak head of yours into your bosom.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	 Then open his eyes and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	 Then gather the nail with a nail of twofold length and extend it to above.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	 Then take a needle and insert it into the nail with hair from horses, oxen or sheep; and let it be thread, and double the end of the needle slightly, and fasten it in the middle of the nail; and pierce it with the needle and tie the nail with the thread, and extend it to above; and remove the scab from the side of the nail that follows the pupil, as if you are holding it with hair up to its root.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	 Then cut the rest at the root of the tear duct with a thin spatula or with small forks; and let out the natural flesh of the tear duct, so that there is no continuous flow of tears from the incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	 And sometimes a nail is extended with an uncion (a thin, curved surgical instrument) alone; or with a lancet, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	 Then it is scraped with a soft curette of this form.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	 And be careful that the curette does not touch the corn's skin, and a fracture does not occur there, and the pupil is perforated.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 Then after the incision, throw into the eye something of crushed salt or made from zinc, and leave it until another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	 Then take care of it as necessary, until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	 If the nail is not sensitive and you cannot insert a needle into it or the uncion does not fit, then this type of nail is often treated with medicine and heals as I have said in the division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	 If you want to cut it (the nail), then open the eye of the patient and take a thin, soft, weakly sharpened curette in this shape.
