Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	 And scrape the nail superficially with subtlety.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	 If you see that it is becoming rarefied and crushed, and the scraper presses on it, then distill from your hour into the eye, made of zinc, or red sulphur, or crushed salt; and close the eye until another day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 Then repeat this operation until the whole thing is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	 Unless it is a warm abscess in your eye; then leave the nail and treat the abscess until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat this operation with scraping until it heals.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	 However, if the growth of flesh from the tear duct is harmful to the eye to a great extent, it should be suspended with an uncion and cut out that part of it; and do not make the incision too deep, so as not to damage the tear ducts.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	 Then apply the milk or red colloidum, or that made from zinc, until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	 On an Alguardenic incision and the flesh born in the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter XVII.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	 There sometimes arises in the eyes of men a red flesh composed or placed upon it that covers the pupil, approaches, or contracts over the eyelids and perhaps turns the eyelids toward the outside, resembling the balustrade rose.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the treatment for it is also that the weak one puts his head in your armpit.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	 Then open his eyes and gather that flesh in its entirety with suitable forceps, and hold it with a single fork or tweezers.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	 Then make an incision in the flesh first, until it is entirely separated by the scalpel.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	 And be careful not to injure the eye during operation; and let your incision be such as that which we described in the operation of the nail, or with small forceps like those used for excision of the appendix, according to what its form will be after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	 When your incision is completed and the Alguardenic is removed, then fill the eye with brine or sprinkle a red powder and similar substances on it from corrosive medicines; and place warm cloth over the outside of the eye with egg white to protect it from hot contagion.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	 If there remains something of the Alguardenic and warm blood prevails and you fear a hot abscess, then release the eye and treat it with what cures an abscess.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the procedure until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	 And do the same with the added flesh that sometimes occurs in the eye of this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	 It is necessary that every weak eye of an alien, whether from a natural or accidental way, be operated upon with iron, and thou shalt not introduce thy hand into any of these operations, until thou seest that the member is able to bear such operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	 Collection of the Sebaceous Exudate from the Eye.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter XVIII.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	 Sebaceous vessels that weave over the eye and hinder vision are called sebels; they weaken the eye with the passage of days.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	 Therefore, you must first determine if the eye in which there is sebels, is strong and there is no other illness besides sebels; then collect the sebals of that eye.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And it should be prescribed to the weak one, that he place his head in your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	 Then suspend those vessels with a single or double hook, according to your discretion; and let the hook be subtle doubled, in this shape, or there may be two hooks graded within one body, in this shape.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	 Then collect those vessels with fine forceps with fineness and remove the blood hour after hour until you see the vessels being removed from the eye and dissolved; beware that you do not injure the eye with the tips of the forceps.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	 Let your operation be at noon in the presence of the sun, and be firm in your operation very much; so that you do not cut except those vessels.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	 And when you have finished, then pour into the eye either green or red; so that it may consume with its own sharpness what remains from the sebals.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	 If it is not possible for you to collect it all in that hour, then apply a plaster to the eye with what alleviates eye pain; and leave it for some days until the pain subsides; and it should be purified with warm poultice; then repeat over it in the same manner until it heals.
Et haec est forma forficis.	 And this is the shape of the forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	 On reducing the Aphthae to the nose.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter XIX.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	 The physician named Arissethe treats a fistula, which he cures with cautionery or with a burning medicine, according to the account that precedes it.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	 And if it does not heal, then there is no skill in it; unless to find above the abscess at its birth, and to draw out all the moisture that is in it and the pus, until the bone appears.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	 When the bone appears and you see in it decay or blackness, then file it with this tool, whose shape is as follows:
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	 The named part is Asperi of the head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	 Make it of iron and let its head be round like an azir [a type of drill], and let it be marked with the engraving of a file, or the subtle marking of aliskilfer, and place it over the corrupted bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	 Then turn it between your fingers and press your hand slightly, so that you may know if the corruption is now scraped away; and do this several times.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	 Then restore the place with astringent medicines.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	 If the place is consolidated and flesh grows there and the flow of pus ceases, and it remains for forty days without renewal, without ulceration, and no incident occurs in it; then you will know that it has been healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	 And if not, then there is no skill to be found except to reduce the fistula to the opening of the nose, according to this form:
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	 It is to be peeled off from the second bone with iron or medicine that is sharp, and when the bone has been exposed, then take the trepan [a surgical instrument] in this form: its end should be iron, triangular; and the wood of it should be a pyramid extended to the end, as you can see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	 Then place it on the bone itself: and let it be near the tear duct; and stretch your hand slightly from the eye.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	 Then turn the trepan with your hand until it enters the bone and feels weak: by this you will know that air is escaping from it when you hold your hand over his nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	 Therefore, then restore the place with astringent medicines as I taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	 When flesh grows and the place hardens: then the substance that was flowing outward returns to the nose; therefore, it is easier for that to be upon the weak one.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	 On the reduction of protrusion of the Eye.
Caput XX.	 De resecnditone cataractae oculi.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	 When the Eye protrudes completely and no harm or reduction occurs during sight: then it is necessary to loosen the patient; afterwards, let the phlebotomist bleed him; subsequently, place warm fumigations on his neck without incision, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	 Subsequently, place a poultice made of acacia, aloe, frankincense, and colophony over the Eye.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	 Subsequently, tighten the Eye upwards onto a plaster with many small stones.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	 And the method of the small stones is as follows: Take soft cloths in large quantities and fold each one over four; make many of them; then place one on top of another according to the quantity required by the Eye; subsequently, tighten them with a hard cloth strap firmly.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	 Repeat the warm fumigations with suction without incision.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	 Subsequently, remove the warm fumigations, and leave the eye tightened during the day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	 If the binding softens again, then it is necessary to tighten it strongly; subsequently, remove the binding after a day and night, as previously stated.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	 If you see that the Eye has returned to its original state, that is good; if not, repeat the poultice, the small stones, the strapping, and the warm fumigations until it heals.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	 Chapter on the incision of the eyelid.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	 When a rupture occurs in the eyelid, then it protrudes and extends beyond the eyelashes like a grain of sand, and disfigures human form due to this, and there is a desire to cut it; then the operation is done as I described: namely, insert an awl into the root of the eyelash from below to its upper part.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	 Subsequently, insert another awl into which there is a double thread from the lacrimal part, and make it penetrate; subsequently, release the first awl according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	 Then cut a place for the double thread and tie it around the vein with a needle; and tighten it strongly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	 Then extract the needle, and place linen soaked in oil on the conjunctiva of the eye; and wait until the thread falls with the vein.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	 Then care for the eye with that which strengthens it until the wound is healed.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	 And sometimes the vein is tied all around with a circle made of cloth until the eye protrudes greatly.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	 Then pierce with a fine spatula which reaches deep into the eye, and let the moisture of the conjunctiva run out, and let the eye sink down and enter immediately; then tie it until it is healed.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	 [Chapter title: Treatment of Alcomant]
Caput XXII.	 Chapter XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	 This disease called Alcomant is nothing other than pus that collects in the eye, resembling flowing water and it is not [this pus itself].
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	 The method of operation in it is, that you make the sick person sit on a prepared seat, or straight.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	 Then take the head of it with your two hands and move it, until you see pus approaching towards the lower parts of your eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	 Then shape it and do not let it fall down, and clean the eye: and let the sick person see as he used to see; and if it does not go downwards, know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	 If it is not prepared for the discharge of pus as we said, then let the sick person sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	 Then take a pointed instrument and pierce it slightly on the cornual continuation of the conjunctiva with the cornea at the crown, until pus comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 When it comes out, then pour hot water into the eye in which you have mixed honey; or hot water in which you have already boiled fenugreek and honey; afterwards clean with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	 Chapter on the treatment of water that falls into the eye or cataract.
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter XXIII.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	 We have already said the type of water in division and what suits for piercing by declaring and explaining it, then take that very same one according to health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	 Then it is necessary that you let the sick person sit between your hands, facing towards the light, near the sun; and tie the healthy eye; and press the affected eye very hard; afterwards close the eyelid of the affected eye with your right hand if the water is in the left eye; or with your left hand if it is in the right eye.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	 Then take your right hand (almad) if the affected eye is in the left; or take your left hand if it is in the right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	 Then place the end of almad near the crown by the thickness of a radial limbus on the white part of the eye that is visible as the smaller lacrimal sac; then press almad with force; and you turn with it, until it penetrates into the white part of the eye; and feel that almad has already reached an empty space.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	 And it is necessary that the measure of the journey be great for deep places, the measurement of the space that is from the pupil until the end of the blackness; and it is the eyelid's circumference.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	 You will see that within the pupil's vision of the eye, due to the brightness of the cornea membrane.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	 Then place a large one up to the place where there is water.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	 Then press it down once after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	 If therefore water comes out immediately, then the sick person sees it right away over what opens his sight immediately, and a large one in his own eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	 Then remain quiet for a while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	 If water comes out again then put it down again, except that the large one goes out.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	 When it is blocked and does not come up then pull the large one out easily; and you rotate your hand slowly.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	 Then dissolve something from salt in clear water, and wash the eye with it inside.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	 Then put outside the whole wool or flax soaked in rose oil and white egg white, and tie it to a healthy eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	 We and those of our time place on him crushed cumin with egg white.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	 If the large one does not obey you for entry into the eye because of its hardness, since it is from a man whose eye is very hard; then it is necessary that you receive a tool called "Alberid", whose form is this:
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	 Therefore drill with it only the joint itself, and do not go all the way with your hand into the opening; and there is no other purpose except to make a subtle way to the large place.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	 Then introduce the large one, as we said before.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	 For the completion of your work, prepare a well-made bed for the sick person, in which he sleeps on his back in a dark house; and let him be prohibited from all movements, coughs; and put food before him that soothes his nature; and do not move his head to the right or left at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	 And let the ligature be according to its own arrangement until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	 Then untie that in the dark house and test its sight; make it see things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	 Then return the ligature until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	 And it is not appropriate that it be done during the hour of cure or immediately after the incision; rather, let someone else do it, because water rises quickly with a strong gaze.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	 If, however, there is a hot abscess: then it is necessary to loosen the eye before the seventh day; and correct it with what calms the abscess, until it is calm; then without its sight, place it on his oral cavity to regulate his sight for some days, while he remains in that dark house.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	 Then leave the house gradually and convert himself in his bed.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	 And know that in the zaltea (operating room) the student is not excused from seeing often; then he will dare for the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	 And indeed a certain one of those from Alayrach has come to us who said that in Alayrach a magdan (stone) was perforated through which water rises up.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	 Therefore I have not seen anyone in your land who has done that; nor have I read it in any of the old books. It is possible that it is new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	 And these are the shapes and species from stone for standing on those who do not know them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	 Make them of bronze; and let their ends have the same subtle triangular shape with an acute point.
Formae magda.	 Stone shapes (forms).
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	 Chapter on the care of newborn flesh in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter XXIII.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	 Sometimes various fleshes are born in the nose, among which there is something resembling a scorpion of many feet; and from it is cancerous flesh, stone-like, dark colored; and from it is the soft flesh, not dark colored.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	 Therefore, for the soft and non-deceptive flesh, not cancerous, it is necessary that you make the sick person sit facing the sun with his nose opposite, and open his nostrils, and throw the hook into those fleshes; then draw them outwards, and cut what you have caught from them with a subtle sharp spatula on one side, until you know that the entire flesh has been removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	 If something remains from it, whose excision is not possible; then shave it off with one of the subtle instruments easily, until nothing remains from it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	 If blood dominates over you or a hot boil happens; then oppose it with what is necessary; or if it is from malignant boils, then rush to cauterize him, until the blood is cut off and all the fleshes are removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	 Then pour vinegar, water, or wine into the nose after the incision.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	 If the nose opens and moisture comes out up to the palate, then you know that he is already well.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	 If moisture does not penetrate as required, then you know that within it there is a born flesh in the upper bones of the nose, to which the instrument did not reach with the incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	 Therefore, it is necessary to introduce a linen thread with a certain thickness and many knots; and place between each knot the amount of a finger or less; and let the sick person insert one end of the filament into his nose with a spoon or as possible for him after he has made it similar to a syringe; and draw out the smell, until it reaches the cavity, and comes out on his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	 And indeed many times do boys in schools make something similar to that of Attotus; and it is an easy thing for him who desires it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	 Then place two ends of the thread, one which comes out above the nose, and the other which remains within the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	 Then the flesh is cut with a scissors having knots on the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	 Make that, until you know that the flesh is already with the knots of the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	 Then draw out the thread; and place within the nose linen that you have soaked in Egyptian ointment; do this for three days or more, until the ointment completely corrodes what remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 Then place at the end of the procedure within the nose a tube made of lead, for some days, until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	 If it requires treatment to dry it out, use that (the ointment).
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	 For the purging of the head (snuff), when olive oil and other medicines are distilled into the nose, make it from silver or brass; that it be similar in size to a small lamp, open like a snail shell; and its passage likewise.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	 And if you wish to make a closed tube, like a reed.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	 And the snail-shell instrument for purging the head should be full, pierced; having a handle at its end, with which you hold it, when heating oil or whatever you wish from distilled juices and fluid substances within it.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	 And this is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	 Chapter on the cure for Thelul (nasal polyp).
Caput XXV.	 Chapter 25.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	 Often in the end of the nose arises a Thelul (nasal polyp), and it grows and becomes larger with days until it becomes a foul sight.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	 And therefore it is necessary to cut it at the beginning of its appearance, and root out all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	 Then place upon the location, either a cautery, or a medication burning in its stead.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	 If the incision is slow to appear when enlarged, then consider if it is hard and blackish, with few senses: then do not touch it with iron; because it is a cancerous ulcer.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	 For often I have seen that when someone cut an abscess, there was great evil that befell him who had it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	 And if the abscess is soft when touched and not blackish, and you see that an incision can be made in it entirely, then evacuate the weak, and cut it without fear or trembling: and care for the place with it as it drains and constricts, until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	 Chapter on the suture of the nose, lip, and ear.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter 26.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 Know that when there is a break in the continuity of one of these cartilages, an operation will bring little benefit to it, unless in certain men.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, when something happens to anyone from one of them (cartilages), consider whether it is a recent wound with its own blood: and then apply the two wounds together with suture; then care for it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	 And if the continuity of the lips is already separated and each part has become healthy: then it is necessary to remove all layers from the visible skin until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	 Then join the two lips with suture, tighten them, and sprinkle over the blood of the dragon (alcohol) and crushed aloes: and place on top of powders a fragment of plaster called diafinicon, and some other more consolidated plaster: and leave it bound for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	 Then dissolve it (the plaster), and change the medicine; and leave it until the threads are cut off by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with an ointment until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	 The method of suturing is that you gather the solution of continuity, or with hooks, as we told you in the suture of the abdomen; or gather the solution with thread, as I taught you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	 On the Extraction of Lip Nodules.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter XXVII.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	 Many people indeed suffer from hard ulcers similar to the seeds of a plant in the inner parts of their lips; and some of these are smaller, while others are larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	 Therefore, it is necessary that you turn the lip and pierce over every nodule of it, and hang it with a hook, and cut it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then fill the place after the incision with lime until the blood is shed off.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	 Then it is washed with vinegar and treated with it on the place where there is stiffness until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	 On the Incision of Born Flesh Above the Gingiva.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter XXVIII.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	 Multitiples times grows-on flesh on gum, which ancients called abscess.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	 Therefore it is necessary that you hang-it with a hook; or hold-it with forceps, and cut-it near the root, and let-it run pus (or blood).
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	 Then place-on top of the place powdered zogia or other healing powders, dried.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	 If that flesh returns after treatment, for it often does return, then cut-it again and cauterize it; for it will not return after cauterization.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	 Chapter on the shaping of teeth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter XXIX.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	 When accumulations gather on the surfaces of teeth from both the interior and exterior parts, and between gums (hard layers), rough, rotten, and sometimes turn yellowish or green, until corruption reaches the gum, and teeth become foul because of it.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	 Therefore it is necessary that you make the sick person sit between your hands and his head in your lap, and file-down the molars and teeth, where the hard layers appear to you, until nothing remains of them; and similarly do for blackening, yellowing, greening, and others, until they are clean.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	 If that which is in them is removed from the beginning of filing, good; and if not, then repeat the filing on them on another day, second, and third, until finally the effort reaches what you wish for in it.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	 And know that the tooth requires filing instruments of various forms and shapes; according to which it is prepared for your operation; because the filing instrument with which you file the tooth from below is different from the filing instrument with which you file between teeth, according to other shapes.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	 And these shapes of filing instruments should be prepared by you, which you see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	 On the extraction of tooth pain.
Caput XXX.	 Caput signifies Chapter or Title. So this is the title of the chapter which translates to "Chapter XXX" in English. The Arabic textbook on surgery by Albucasis likely has many chapters, and this one is the thirty-third. In Latin, 'XXX' stands for 30, hence the translation as Chapter Thirty.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	 It is necessary that you extract the tooth from its pain with all your skill and not delay in doing so.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	 For indeed, there is no remedy for it when the tooth is extracted: because its substance is lofty: unless there is an excuse for not extracting it, then when one who is sick must have the painful tooth extracted, it should be firmly set, and you should be certain that the tooth causing pain has been removed.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	 Often pain deceives the sick man and he believes that it is in the tooth and extracts it himself: then the pain does not subside until the sick tooth is extracted.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	 We have indeed seen that from the operation of phlebotomists.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	 When you are certain that the tooth causing pain is indeed present, then it is necessary to make an incision around the tooth with a lancet, which contains something of virtue, until the gum is loosened from all sides: then move it with your fingers or with delicate forceps first gently, until you dislodge it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	 Then place large forceps in that location and grasp the head of the sick tooth between your knees: what you have now firmly grasped, so that it does not move: then pull out the tooth in a straight line, so that you do not break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If it still does not come out, then take one of those instruments and insert it under it from all sides with ease, and try to move it as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	 If the tooth is perforated or rotten, then it is necessary to fill that hole with a cloth and bind it with the tip of a thin radius so that it does not break during your compression on top of it with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	 It is necessary that you thoroughly make incisions around the gums from every part much.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	 Maintain your strength so that you do not break it (the tooth), and a part of it remains, and returns over the sickness from that evil which is greater in pain at first.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	 Be careful not to do what ignorant phlebotomists do in haste and their audacity regarding its (tooth) extraction, beyond what we have mentioned.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	 For many times they cause great diseases to come upon men, whose difficult it is for them to break, and all of its roots remain, or some of them; or that they extract it with certain jaw bones, as we have often testified this.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	 Then, after the extraction of it (tooth), it is rubbed with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	 If there is bleeding from the places (for many times this happens), then rub something from ashes, and fill the place with it; and if not, cauterize it with fire if ashes are not available for you.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	 The form of delicate forceps by which the tooth is moved should be long at the ends, short at the handle, thick, so that they do not split when pressed against the tooth; like the handles of large forceps, until when you squeeze with them, they do not open themselves, nor do they split: short at the end, and made of iron or well-made files, with pointed ends; and on their ends there should be teeth, some of which enter into certain ones, and constrict by a proper constriction, strongly.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	 And sometimes the ends are like the shape of a bird's beak called ciconia and they have strong constriction.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	 Chapter on the Extraction of Teeth and the Removal of Fractured Jaw Bones.
Caput XXXI.	 Head, Chapter XXXI.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	 If [the tooth] remains during extraction and it breaks, then it is necessary to place on the place a hot poultice with butter for one day, or two days, until the place becomes soft: then introduce into it algum, or forceps; whose extremities are similar to the mouth of the bird called ciconia.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	 The form of these forceps is as follows:
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	 Extremities of them are made like a chisel inwards, or scissors-like.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	 If these forceps do not obey you when exiting, then it is necessary that you be cautious on the root, uncover the entire flesh, and insert an instrument called a small plancca, whose form is as follows:
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	 Let the end be short and slightly thick; and let it not be saturated so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	 If the root exits through this, it is good; and if not, help with these other instruments whose forms are as follows:
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	 The first form is triangular in end, where there is some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	 The form of the fine triangular end.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	 Also helped by this instrument with two limbs, whose form is as follows:
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	 And also with other instruments and tools that preceded in the ratio of teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	 Also help with this instrument that resembles a large hook, whose form is as follows, triangular and twisted end, where there is some thickness, so that it does not break; and let it not be saturated.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	 And know that there are many instruments of teeth; and similarly the rest of the instruments are not counted, and the skillful artist, subtle in his art, finds for himself an instrument according to what the operation and illness itself signify.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	 Because among illnesses there are those for which no ancient instrument has been said, due to the diversity of their forms.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	 If the bone is broken from the jaw, or from other bones of the face, or it putrefies; then to examine on top of it in its place with that which suits it from the instruments and forceps that I said for extracting roots, and help with gesti whose form is as follows:
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	 Place something of some thickness gradually within it [the wound], so that the bone may be held or tied and not escape and move away, until the bone emerges; and restore the place with suitable medications for that purpose.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 If however there is a small rottenness in the bone, then scrape it off from its rottenness, and treat it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	 On locking protruding teeth on others [teeth].
Caput XXXII.	 Chapter XXXII.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	 When teeth protrude not according to their natural course, it becomes a foul formation; and especially when it happens in women and girls, namely those who menstruate.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	 Therefore one must consider [the cause of the problem].
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	 For if a tooth has been born after another tooth and it does not fit or can be locked without grinding [the tooth], then extract it; and if it is attached to another tooth, then cut it off with this tool, which has the following shape:
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	 The instrument resembles a small beak and is made from sharp-tipped iron.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	 And let your incision be one that you make over many days, and due to the hardness of the tooth, so that another tooth is not disturbed.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	 If it projects out for sharpening: then file it with the file whose shape is this.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	 Let it be entirely made of iron, and its handle small but with many pointed knobs, like a file used to sharpen teeth: with this you can grind the tooth gradually over many days with ease, so that another tooth is not disturbed, and it falls out; then smooth it with some files.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	 If it is a tooth from which a part breaks off and hurts the tongue: then it must be filed down until the roughness of that fracture is removed, and it is made smooth; and it shall not hurt the tongue nor corrupt speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	 Chapter on filing teeth with gold files.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter XXXIII.
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	 When there is a shock and commotion to the front teeth due to striking or falling, and the sick person cannot clench on what they eat to prevent it from falling down: and you have treated them with medicines that stop bleeding, but the treatment was of no avail: then, in their case, it is appropriate to clench them with a gold thread. Because silver turns green and becomes putrid after days, but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	 And make the thread fine and thick according to its quantity that it can pass between the Teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	 And the type of knot is such that you take the thread and insert it between two healthy teeth; then you weave with both ends of the thread between the moved teeth, whether one or more, until you reach the end with the needle to the healthy tooth of the other side.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	 Then repeat the weaving up to the part from which you started; and hold your hand with finesse and wisdom until it is completely secure; and let your binding that binds the thread be near the roots of the teeth so it does not go out.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	 Then cut the excess parts of the thread with scissors; and gather both ends together and twist them; and hide these beneath a healthy tooth and a moved tooth so as not to hurt the tongue; then release it in such a way that it remains tight.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	 If it is loosened or cut, bind them with another thread, and it will remain so for the entire time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	 And this is the shape of teeth and the pattern of knotting of two healthy teeth and two moved teeth, as you see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	 And sometimes a tooth or two return to their places after a fall and are held as we have said, and remain so; and this does not happen unless the skilled craftsman is both cunning and experienced.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	 And sometimes one of the bones of a cow is made like a tooth and placed in its place, where it is secured and bound as we have said; and it remains and serves for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	 Regarding the incision of a ligament which occurs under the tongue, and prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	 "De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et inhibet locutionem.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	 Whenever this ligament that happens under the tongue is natural, which is born with man, or accidental, from a healed wound.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	 And the operation on it is to open the weak bone at its head in your throat, and lift its tongue: then cut that nerve-ligament across, until the tongue is released from its grip.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	 If there is something hard and knotted, and it is from the healing of a wound: then thrust in the hook, and cut through it crosswise, until you reach the ligament, and the knot is released.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And beware that there is no deep crack in the flesh, and do not cut an artery there, and let there be a blood flow.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	 Then it is rubbed in the wound trace with rose water, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	 Then place a piece of flax from the linen under the tongue, which the sick person should hold every night: so that it does not heal again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	 If there is blood flow, then place crushed alum over the place.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 But if the blood overpowers you, then cauterize the place with a purging cautery that is suitable for it: afterwards take care of him with the rest of the treatment until he is healed.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	 Chapter on the removal of ranula that occurs under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter 35.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	 Sometimes under the tongue there occurs an aposteme resembling a small frog that prevents the tongue from performing its natural function, and it may grow so much as to fill the bone.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	 And the operation on it is to open the weak bone before the sun: and observe the aposteme.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	 If you see it black or dark, hard and insensate to the sick person, then do not touch it because it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	 If it is cut to white matter, where there is moisture, then throw in the hook, and cut it with a thin chisel, and release it from all sides.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	 If blood veins over you during your operation hour, then place a soft rag upon it until the blood is cut off; then return to your operation until you extract it with its entirety.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	 Then clean it with vinegar and salt, and care for it with suitable treatment until it heals.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	 Section on the treatment of two Molar Abscesses.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter XXXVI.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	 When glands similar to goiters occur within the throat, that is, the two amygdales: when these are not cured with what has been said regarding division, then consider them.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	 If it is a hard aposteme of dark color and few senses, do not touch it with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	 And if it is red in color and its root is thick: do not touch it even with iron, fearing the flow of blood, rather let it be until it matures.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	 Then either pierce it yourself or it will burst on its own.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	 If it is white in color, round and its root is subtle: then it should be cut.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	 The operation on it is to consider before the operation if the aposteme has been quiet for a long time and completes its heat or if it decreases slightly: then let the patient sit in front of the sun, and his head should be in your lap; open his mouth and let him take a servant between his hands, and press his tongue down with an instrument, whose form is as follows.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	 Let it be made of silver or copper, which is delicate like a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	 When you press his tongue with it and the aposteme is revealed to you and falls on top of it: then take a hook, and pierce it into the amygdale, and remove it as far as possible from within, taking with it something from the linens.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	 Then cut it with an instrument of the following form.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	 It is similar to forks; however, its ends should be curved so that the opening of each of them is directed towards the other's sharp point: ensure that it is made of steel or ivory impregnated with alcohol.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	 If this tool is not present, then cut it with a spatula, whose form is as follows.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	 The instrument should be sharp on one side, not on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	 And after you cut one almond, cut the other in the same way as this cutting.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	 Then, after the cutting, let the sick person gargle with cold water, or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 If there occurs a bleeding in him, let him gargle with water in which the rinds of pomegranates have been boiled; or leaves of myrtle, and similar ones from other plants, until the bleeding stops: then take care of him until he is cured.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	 And sometimes boils appear in the throat besides the two almonds.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	 Cut them, therefore, as I said in cutting the two almonds, equally.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	 I myself, moreover, have been healed of a woman who had a boil that was born in her throat, which drew to the swelling, few senses, which almost closed her throat: and the woman breathed through a narrow mouth, and already she had forbidden her food, and drink of water; and it had already come near to death, if it had remained one day, or two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	 The boil had risen only so far that it expelled two branches, until they came out through the two nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	 I therefore hastened and tied one of them with a hook.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	 Then I pulled it out, and a large piece was drawn out with it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	 Then I cut it off where it was seized from the nostril.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	 Then I did to it what came out of the other nostril.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	 Then I opened his mouth, and pressed his tongue; and afterwards I tied a hook to the boil; then I cut off a part of it, and no more came out but a little blood: therefore the throat of the woman was freed, and she immediately began to drink water, then she received food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	 I did not stop cutting from that ulcer for a long time; and the ulcer succeeded in the place which I was cutting, until it was extended too much and with that (it) [the extension].
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	 I have prepared (myself) and burned an ulcer at the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	 Therefore I stood still for a while: then I walked away from it, and I did not know what God had done with that (situation) after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	 Chapter on the incision of an ulcer of the windpipe.
Caput XXXVII.	 Chapter 37.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	 When catarrh goes down to the windpipe and becomes an ulcer that is long, it is then called perpendicular; and if it is thick and round in the lower part, it is then called uva.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	 When it is cured along with what was said earlier in the division, but the cure does not work; and you see that the ulcer has become warm and subtle, then it is necessary to cut (it).
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	 And if there is a round gathering from it which is not long, and it is bloody or of dark or black color, and there is no sensation in it, then it is necessary to make an incision on it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	 For there is fear over the weak (one) in it.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	 Therefore, when you see it according to the way that I said from whiteness and its length, you should make the weak one sit facing the sun; and press his tongue with the tool whose story was told earlier; then attach a hook in the windpipe and pull it down; and cut it with one of two tools that I said for the incision of two amygdalas.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	 And it is necessary not to cut from it unless that which is added exceeds its natural limit without further addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	 For if you cut more from it, you injure the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	 Then after the incision use what was said for the incision of two amygdalas; and cure it until it is healed.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	 If the patient is afraid of incision, then it is necessary to use art in the cauterization of him without fear and dread.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 The method of cauterization is not otherwise than with sharp water: it is to place the head of the sick one in your bosom.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	 Then press his tongue with the instrument that I mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	 Then take water that I told you in the chapter on cauterization and make a not-extinguished lime from it, and do not make it thick or thin, but fill the hollow of this instrument with it whose shape is as follows: (the text does not provide an image, so no translation provided for this part)
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	 Let the end where the medicine is placed be concave, like the concavity of a cochlea's ray.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	 Place the instrument with the medicine on the ulcer itself: let the sick one lie down on his side so that the saliva comes out from his mouth through the internal medicine, and let nothing descend from it to his throat, and hurt him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	 Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	 And you apply it to the ulcer for a quantity of half an hour until you see it become darkened and the biting of the medicine subsided.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	 And if you want to take the curette, and wrap it around the end of the ray, and pour the ointment with the medicine over it, and insert the ray with the ointment-covered curette on top until the ointment adheres to the ulcer.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	 Do this repeatedly until you achieve what you want from the cauterization of the ulcer.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	 Then release it: for it burns and falls after three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	 If you need to repeat the medicine, do so: and after cauterization, wash around the ulcer with ointment soaked in butter, and clean it with what is in the surrounding area of the ulcer: and rinse it with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	 And it shall be treated externally with leeches, and internally with gargles, until it is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	 This kind of treatment is healthier than surgery and further from fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	 And sometimes a vein is also cured with something more subtle than cautery and incision; it is cured with fumigation, in this manner.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	 Take calaminthe, hyssop, oregano, rut, sage, chamomile, and absinthium, and similar herbs from the plants; mix them all together, or some of them in a pot, and immerse them with vinegar, boil them; let the pot be well coated with clay; and let there be a hole in the middle of the pot, over which an instrument concave in this manner is placed.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	 Make it from silver or bronze; insert the end into the mouth of the sick person, so that the vapor reaches the vein through the pipe, until the vein is filled with a large amount.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	 Then repeat this many times, until it burns up.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	 And beware not to do this treatment at the beginning of the abscesses growth.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	 For most often pus is added to an abscess; and it should not be done unless at the descent of the heat from the abscess.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	 If this instrument is not available to you, then take a pipe and prepare the bark of an ox's horn at its end, so that the bone of the sick person is not burned; since the ox's horn bark prevents the vapor from burning the bone; and this is from good treatment with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	 Chapter on the removal of thorns and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	 Chapter XXXVIII.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	 Often a bone or fish spine adheres to the throat.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	 Therefore it is necessary to extract whatever appears from among them that strikes the sight, after pressing the tongue with an instrument under the sun, and when it is shown to you that it is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	 And what is not apparent to you and hidden in the throat, it is necessary that you make [the patient] vomit before the food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	 Perhaps it will come out attached things through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	 Either the sick person should swallow a piece of nutmeg, or the root of lettuce, or a dry breadcrumb: or he should take a piece of dried sea-sponge, soft: and bind it, then he should swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	 When it has reached the place where there are spines or bone, and it is drawn out, then it comes out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	 If it does not come out as we have said: then use an instrument made of lead in this shape.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.
