Recognition of the methods of this art is evidence of the methods of diseases: for then you will find for yourself that which is suitable to him from instruments for every ailment.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	 I am strengthening you at the end of this chapter with the number of instruments, which you shall place examples on, and proof on others.
Forma Serrae.	 Form of the saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	 Form of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	 Form of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	 Form of another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	 This form of the saw should be made correctly.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	 Make its upper part an arch, sharpen it with iron; and make its handle of boxwood, and make it pyramidal correctly.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	 Form of the rasp for joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	 The head of this rasp should be in the form of a star keycap; and its points should be according to the form of the points of the file-rake.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	 It is not suitable unless it is rubbed with it on the heads of joints when they are broken, or a large and great bone.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	 Form of the larger rasp.
Forma medii Rasorii.	 Form of the middle-sized rasp.
Forma Rasorii lati.	 Form of the broad rasp.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	 Form of the rasp with a hollow.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	 Form of another, more delicate rasp.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	 Form of another rasp with a curved tip.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	 Form of the small, delicate rasp.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	 Form of the rasp for cutting bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	 Also, the form of the large rasp.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	 It resembles a Chisel and its tip is like a saw; it is used in many places by reason of bone-files.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	 Form of the rasp suitable for filing that which has been perforated from bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	 Its tip is triangular and sharp-pointed.
Fit ex Indi.	 It comes from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	 And similarly, it is necessary that all things which we have said are made of file makers, cutters and sawyers.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	 On the incision of extremities and the setting of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	 Head, LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	 They rot at the extremities, either externally or internally.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	 If you have treated that corruption with medicinal care and it does not improve: and if you see the corruption advance in a limb which nothing has checked: then it is necessary that you amputate that limb until the corruption exits, so that the weak may pass through it from death or from the greater evil which is due to the loss of a member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	 And the sign of this (affliction) is that the limb darkens until it appears rotten; or it is burned by fire and then rots after being blackened; until the rot is amputated up to where it follows the limb, and it spreads through the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	 Approach it (the wound) then with the incision, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from a blow by certain poisonous creatures such as marine scorpions, vipers, adders, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	 If corruption or a blow occurs at the tip of the finger, then amputate the finger and do not leave any space for the corruption to spread, so that it may not advance toward the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	 And similarly if it happens in the hand, then amputate it at its root and do not leave any space for the corruption to spread, until it takes hold of the forearm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	 And if it advances in the arm, then amputate the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	 If the corruption passes through and you see that it is about an elbow-length, then there is death for the weak one.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	 And beyond that in treatment is the measure of strength.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	 And similarly do this for the foot when corruption advances in the toe; then amputate it at one joint: and if it takes hold of the ball of the foot, then amputate the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	 If it reaches up to the knee, then amputate the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	 If corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill in that except to release and leave the weak one to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	 The method for cutting a limb, or for tying it, is to tighten the ligament below where you wish to cut, and then tighten another ligament above the same place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	 Extend the servant ligament one to the lower parts, and extend the other servant ligament upward.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	 And separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments, with a wide spatula, until the whole flesh is laid bare.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	 Then it should be cut or tied.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	 It is necessary that you place a cloth of linen over all the parts and not touch the healthy place with the knife; and if there should be any injury to the weak, let it be accompanied by hot abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	 If there should be internal bleeding while you are working, then quickly cauterize the place or put some powders on it that absorb blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	 Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable ligament and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	 And I tell you what happened to a man in his foot, this same thing happens that I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	 Because blackening occurred in his foot, like burn caused by fire; and the decay first affected his toe, until it spread to the entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	 The man then moved away from himself, after he saw the decay occur in his limb with great pain, which he found by pain and burn; and he cut it at the joint, and was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	 And after a long period of time, the same decay occurred in the index finger of his other hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	 He then came to me, and I attempted to recover the shortage by applying medicine to his hand after cleaning his body; but there was no improvement, and it spread to another finger; until decay began in the hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	 He therefore called me to cut his hand; and I did not want it, hoping that there would be excess repercussion from me on him; and I also feared his death during the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	 Because a man's virtue was above his fall.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	 Since he had given up on me, he returned to his own land; and he came to me from him, because he hastened, and he cut off his entire hand; and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	 And I have not brought this narrative except as an aid for that which falls under the genus of this sickness; and it is to signify what is signified, and according to how it is carried out.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	 Chapter on Care of the Sinews, and the Quality of Cleansing with Medicines.
Caput XC.	 Chapter XC.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	 When an abscess occurs in some fleshy members and the space of the abscess extends until it makes a collection of pus; then it bursts or perforates and what is within the pus exits, and there remains a hollow place as if it were a vessel; and the skin that is above it is like a thin cloth; and it does not reach its final corruption nor presses on bone, nerve, or ligament: it deserves to be called a sinus; and it is not called a fistula; but if the space of it extends until corruption presses into one of these members, then it is called a fistula, or ulcer.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	 And the care of it is to cut that skin all around as it rolls; especially when it has become thin and made like a cloth; and you trust that it will not adhere because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	 If you hope that the skin will adhere and it does not follow that this final corruption follows; and if there is a thickness of flesh in the skin, then treat it with cleansing; and it is to consider for a sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	 Then if it is large, and the pus that is emitted from it has a foul smell: then clisterize it with medicine from Egypt, which is vinegar, oil, and zinziber, taking equal parts, and mix them in a vessel: and boil it over fire until the medicine turns red and thickens like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	 Then take what is necessary from it: and dissolve it with water and honey, and clisterize the sinus with it: and bind up the opening of it, and let the medicine remain in it for a quantity of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	 Then extract it with pressure: make this for days until the sinus is cleansed and the foul smell is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	 And at times clisterize with water and ashes, when this medicine is not present to you: and it is so that you may take the ashes of vinewood logs, or the ashes from oak trees: and pour water upon it.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	 Then cook it and clisterize with it until you are confident that the sinus is already cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	 If the patient is not able to endure the Egyptian medicine or water and ashes, then clisterize it with water and honey mixed with a little crushed ginger.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	 Or clisterize it with honey and wine mixed together, because the property of honey is to cleanse and wash: and wine makes the sinus sticky, especially when there is an excess of stiffness and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	 Whenever you do this and believe that the corruption of the sinus is already removed: then clisterize it with what causes flesh to grow in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	 And it is so that you may take from the plaster dyafinicon: and dissolve it with rose oil and stiptic wine: or clisterize it with certain medicines and other ointments, whose properties I have written about in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	 If the orifice of the Sinus is narrow and cannot take the cannula for cleansing: then widen it slightly with iron; or place linen wrapped in Egyptian ointment or basilicon ointment in it until it widens.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	 And similarly, if the orifice is also wide, then bring the lips together with suture; and let the amount go in which cleansing enters without additional quantity.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	 And similarly, if the orifice from which pus flows is elevated towards above: then cut it in a lower location within it, so that the pus flows out below; because pus when constricted in the depth of the Sinus, prevents flesh to grow in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	 If it is not possible for you to cut the Sinus about below as you wish: then try to prepare a member so that pus flows out from it with ease according to how you are prepared for it.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	 Try not to retain anything from the pus in it at all; and receive medicines that are applied on top of the wound, suitable for what you want.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	 Spread them on a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	 And let the linen cloth be of such size that it allows communication with the entire Sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	 Then cut with scissors a hole straight in the orifice of the Sinus, wider than the orifice of the Sinus slightly.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	 Then spread soft ointments over a second linen cloth according to the size of the hole; and place it on top of it at a distance from the orifice of the Sinus, so that the exit of pus is relieved; and do not remove the large linen cloth unless after several days.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	 The one who is on the orifice of the Sinus, is the one whom you remove at every hour, so that what accumulates in it from pus is expelled; and know this, whether the liquid that flows out of it is much, little, digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	 And again consider the place of the sinus, whether its lord feels pain there, or there is no pain there, and if there is an abscess there, or there is no abscess there.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	 When your treatment is thus extended, and you see the matter coming out of the sinus opening, then you shall know that the sinus has adhered or is approaching adherence; therefore dissolve it in the morning or on the third day: and when you open the wound, then change the bandage, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	 If however pus comes out of the sinus after a long time, subtle matter, then do not despair of its adherence, for healing is approaching, since there are men who delay wound healing and there are those who act contrary to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	 If however after many days pus that is not digested comes out of the sinus, then you shall know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	 If the adherence of the sinus is delayed and prolonged, then add astringents to the treatment, but let the physicians make sure that the treatments are humid in substance and dry in effect, such as ointment dyafinicon when it is made with an excess of zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	 And from the ultimate remedy, it is that you shall receive ointment dyafinicon, which is dissolved with rose oil and shaken over it equal old wine by volume in substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	 Then mix it with that and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	 And now make a similar action when you do not have ointment dyafinicon, honey, when you boil it until it thickens and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	 Or receive myrrh, aloe, and frankincense; grind all of them together, and powder it over honey while it is on fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	 Then draw a line upon the cloth over it, and bind it over the bladder; and draw with honey that you have boiled, until it thickens; and powderize the substance, and place it upon the cloth, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	 And sometimes administered in it long arsenic (Aristolochia), and roots of celestial lily, and is lily; and flour of the plant, and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	 Use them as simple ones, or combined, grind them and the vessels themselves; and powderize over honey that I mentioned, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	 If the matter of the bladder is prolonged and not cured by this treatment, then you shall know that there is corruption in its depth; or it already makes an impression on the bones, or in the other hard members, or ligaments; then cure it with fistula treatment, according to what was mentioned before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	 Chapter on the treatment of boils and scratched nails, and incision and cutting.
Caput XCI.	 Chapter CXCI.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	 Boil (Panaritium) is an abscess that arises under the nail of the thumb finger or toe; and perhaps it arises in other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	 When it is prolonged and neglected in the treatment of its abscess, and it becomes abscessed with hot abscess; or it is corrupted and emits pus until it erodes the root of the nail; and perhaps it completely corrupts it, and corruption reaches the bone, until there is a foul odor; and the tip of the finger becomes wide, and the color of it becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	 When you treat it, when as we said, your treatment does not help; then it is necessary that you cut with iron all the surplus that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	 Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	 For cauterization is very helpful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 If the bone is healthy and also the nail is sound, and empty additions press the flesh towards the interior and begin to pierce it and wound it: then it is necessary that you place subtle Radium under the angle of the nail which pierces the flesh and push it up; and cut the flesh easily, and apply on it what remains of the medicine from burning, corrosive substances until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Cure it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	 If already corruption presses on the bone, then it is necessary to cut that bone and remove it; for the bone will never heal as long as a corrupted bone remains within.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	 If you see corruption and spreading of the tumor on a finger, then cut it at one knuckle, according to its previously mentioned description.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 If however the nail is worn down or struck, and there is a violent pain, then it is necessary to bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	 Then cut the nail with a sharp instrument called Spatulium in a crosswise direction from above towards the visible part.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	 And be careful that the cut does not reach the flesh beneath the nail, for you will cause an increase of violent pain over the patient and this will lead to the growth of additional flesh in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	 Then treat that place with a remedy that soothes the pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	 A finger that is born in some human hands may be all flesh; and it may have bones in some of them, and a nail in others; and some of these are born at the root of the joint or its growth begins in some knuckles of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	 That which is born on some knuckles of the finger does not move; and that which is born near a joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	 The fleshly one among them is easily cut open.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	 To cut it at its root with a broad spatula (spatumili lato).
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	 The treatment of the one whose birth is joined to the juncture of the roots is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	 Therefore, refrain from cutting it (him).
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	 In the one who is born on the digit at the end of the knuckles, then it is necessary to cut the flesh of his round incision up to the bone first.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	 Then saw the bone with one of those saws that fit for that purpose.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	 Consolidation that happens to the fingers often occurs either from the birth of man, meaning it is born with him, or from consolidation of wounds, burns by fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	 Therefore, it is necessary to cut off that consolidation until the fingers return to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	 Then place a piece of linen or cloth soaked in rose oil between them to prevent their rapid consolidation and separate them: or place between them a thin lead plate until the location is healed according to what is necessary.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	 And similarly, if consolidation occurs in some fingers with the palm, then cut off that consolidation according to what is prepared and fits the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	 Chapter on Defects of Incisions.
Caput XCII.	 Chapter XCII (92).
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	 Chapters 92: The swellings are the veins that are twisted, thick, and filled with melancholic excesses which occur in many parts of the body; and most frequently they happen in the legs, especially in those who travel often and labor, and those who carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	 Therefore, it is necessary to administer a purgative of the body with strong emetics from black bile at times.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	 Then make a venesection (bloodletting) from the patient's basilica vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	 The cure of them (wounds or ulcers) with iron is in two ways.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	 One of these is to lance and draw out black blood.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	 And the other way is to open a vein and drain completely.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	 The lancing (of an abscess) is done in this manner.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	 Pour warm wine or vinegar over the leg first, with much hot water, until the thick, foul blood is dissolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	 Then bind the affected leg from the upper part of the hip to the lower part of the thigh with bandages.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	 Then cut the vein at one, or two, or three places, making a wide incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 Then drain (the blood) by hand, that is, draw out the blood from the lower part of the leg to the top, and it is necessary that the patient be bled first by the leech.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	 Then cut the nail to below, until the quantity of blood which you see is sufficient and that which the strength of the patient can endure.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	 Afterwards bind it (the wound) and order him to abstain from foods that produce black bile; and repeat the leeching and bloodletting when the veins are filled, and this hurts the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	 The draining (of an abscess) is done in this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	 Scrape the affected leg if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	 Then immerse it (the leg) in a bath; or pour warm water over the affected leg until it turns red and the veins swell; or exercise it with strong movements if there is no bath available for him, until the limb becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	 Then make a long incision directly over the vein; or at the end of it near the knee, or at the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	 Then open the skin with unguis (nails), and scrape the vein from all sides, until it becomes sensitive; and at its appearance, what you see is turning from red to dark purple.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	 When it comes out of the skin, you see it white like a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	 Then insert under it (the vein) radium (small rod-like instrument), until when it is raised and comes out of the skin; hang it with a blind nail, softly.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	 Then cut another section near that section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	 Then scrape the skin from the top of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	 Then lift it (the vein) with radii (small tongs-like instruments) as you did before, and hang it with another nail as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	 Then cut another section or multiple sections as needed.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	 Then lift it (the vein) and make the final incision at the heel (calcaneum).
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	 Then pull out the portion above the sectioned area.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	 Do this until you pull out the entire vein from the upper section or all sections, until when it comes out entirely; then make the final incision (cut).
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	 If it does not obey you to pull out and lift; then insert the awl with a strong thread twice, tie it and pull it (the vein) out itself; or insert under it radium; and turn your hand over all parts until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	 And be careful, do not cut (it).
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	 For if it is cut, it becomes very difficult for you to lift it and there may be injury from this on the patient.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 When you pull out the entire vein; then place on the wound site a linen soaked in wine and rose oil or olive oil; and take care of him until he heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	 If the vein is contracted with a winding shape and does not follow what was said according to rectitude; then it is necessary that you find (pierce) all parts of its winding, and the points of its winding.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	 Then suspend it with forceps until you have removed it entirely: and beware at your cut on it not to injure the vein or wound it: for it will be difficult for you to remove or extract it if injured.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	 Preserve your caution.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	 The method of healing a wound caused by a thorn.
Forma Vncini caeci.	 The procedure for blinding with a hook.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 It is not like the other hooks in hardness or sharpness at its end so as not to injure a vein: and it has a large flexibleness, gentle: because if it were subtle, it would injure a vein with its subtlety: rather, let it have an excess of bulk, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	 On the extraction of the leg vein.
Caput XCIII.	 Chapter XCIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	 This vein is generated in the limbs on warm lands, as Alizegi says, and in the lands of the Arabs, and in dry, warm lands with little softness, that is, where no plant or tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	 And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the limbs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	 Indeed, its generation is from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, as happens within the bodies of snakes and worms called ascariasis and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	 And the sign of the beginning of this vein's manifestation is that it happens when there is a swelling in the limb.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	 Then it is blistered.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	 Then the vein begins to emerge from the place of blistering, as if it were a root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	 When its end appears from it, then it is necessary that you roll over on it a piece of lead whose weight is a keil drachm, up to two drachms and the node: and release the suspended lead from the limb.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	 Whenever something comes out from there to the outside, encase it in lead, and tie it up.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	 If it extends too much, then cut off a part of it, and encase the remaining portion.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	 And do not cut it at the root before it comes out completely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	 Because if you cut it, it contracts and enters the flesh; it causes an abscess to appear, and rot in that place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	 Therefore, it should be treated gently and extracted gradually until it comes out completely from the end of it, and nothing remains from it in the body; and from this vein, in some men, there comes out what is in length five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	 And now it has reached me, because a man has come out from twenty palms (length).
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	 If it is cut during your treatment time: then insert a probe into its opening and perforate it with a long one, along with the body, until all that is in it from matter is evacuated; and administer the rottenness of the place with medications for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	 Then treat it as an abscess cure.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	 And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot or on the foot itself; and multiple openings occur to it, and a branch comes out from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	 Therefore, treat it as we have said in the section, and with what was mentioned before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	 [Section on] Surgery of worms generated under the skin, and it is called Bouin disease.
Caput XCIIII.	 Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	 This disease is called Bouin disease in a certain land among us, because it often occurs to cows and there is a small worm that is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	 And it pervades the whole body, ascending and descending; and it is shown to the sense during its movement from limb to limb, until it bursts at any place where it bursts on the skin, and escapes.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	 Its generation is from the rottenness of certain fluids.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	 As worms and snakes, that is, earthworms and roundworms occur in the abdomen.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	 And it is feared from its malignity.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	 Because when it pervades the body and rises to the head, and reaches a place; then perhaps it opens there, and escapes, and destroys an eye; and this often happens.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	 When one wishes to heal it and extract it, then this is not done except during its movement and appearance to the sense.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	 Therefore, one must tighten what is above it, and what is below it with a strong ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut above it, and extract him.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	 If it penetrates into the flesh and you do not find it; then place a cautery on the place with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	 And the greater one fears, is its corruption which destroys the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	 If you see it already reaching the head near the eye; then tighten below it with a good bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut above it, and extract him.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	 And the sick one must use his self-cleaning of the body with medications dissolving bad, rotten fluids.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	 And let him beware of foods causing rottenness.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	 Chapter on the incision due to Nakir's disease.
Caput XCV.	 Chapter CXV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	 This disease is called in our land Nakir; and it is pain which occurs in certain limbs; then it changes from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And I myself have already seen it, as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	 I was summoned to a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	 And she rolled up her arm, and I saw a smaller swelling in the vein of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	 And after staying for an hour, I saw a swelling move with a probe, like a worm, ascending to her shoulder more quickly than is possible; as quick as living silver when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	 The pain then left that place and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	 Then she sat for an hour, and ran through the rest of her body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	 Then he told me that it was turning over its entire body, as I observed.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	 I marveled at the rapidity of its change from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	 And indeed, I had not seen this illness with my eyes before in such a manner.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	 Nevertheless, I have seen many who suffer from a change of pain from limb to limb; I have not seen it with my eyes as I have seen it in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	 And I do not think that it was anything other than because the woman was from those who are from dry villages, with veins exposed; hence it appears to the sense that the windiness was changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 And it is necessary that it does not appear according to this reason in those who are well-nourished and in bodies with hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 Since you desire to cure it and the patient feels that pain; if it appears to your eye as we have said, then squeeze above it, quickly below it; cut above it until that windiness constricted emerges; and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 If, however, you do not see it with your eyes: then cure it with the expulsion of the body and with that which expels windiness; crush and expel them with foul pills and pills made from soapwort and similar substances.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 Chapter on the Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	 Chapter LXVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 The arrows are diversified according to their types and the places where they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 The diversity of arrows is that some have large tips and small ones; some are concave and others blind.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 And among them are those having three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 And from these are those which have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And among them are those which have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 Indeed, those which are according to the members on which they fall, it is according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 For indeed members are either hollowed from the main limbs, such as the brain, and heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and similar ones.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 When it falls into any one of these members and appears to you as signs of death, which I shall tell you afterwards, then it is necessary that you cut out the extraction of this arrowhead from them, for death follows it in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 And when these signs do not appear to you and the arrowhead is not hidden in the depth of the member, then extract it yourself and take care of the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 For the signs of the brain when an arrowhead falls into it and penetrates the bone and exits from what is above the brain are: because headache occurs from that, and scotoma (blindness), and dizziness, and redness in eyes, and swelling, and redness of tongue, and spasm, and confusion of intellect, and vomiting of choler.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	 And perhaps blood will come out from the nostrils or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 And perhaps speech is cut off and voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 And from the wound site comes out moisture white like pulp (of a vegetable)
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 From there it goes out something similar to liquid flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If therefore these signs appear to you, then abstain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not come out by itself.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 The signs of an arrow when it falls into the heart are as follows: it is near the left nipple and it feels as though it were fixed in a hard thing, not in something soft.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 And perhaps the arrow's movement is like the movement of the pulse and black blood runs from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 And this is followed by coldness in the limbs, cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 Therefore, know that death is approaching certainly.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 The sign of an arrow when it wounds the lung is the emission of frothy blood from the wound, and vessels that follow the neck must be removed, and the color of the sick must be changed.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 And it breathes out a great, deep breath, and seeks attraction to cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 If the arrow falls into the pleura, which is in the chest, then it is near small ribs; and there is a great shortness of breath with intense pain, with sighing, and all limbs of the shoulders are moved.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested comes out from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 And if the arrow falls into the abdomen and lodges there, something like feces or a bladder that has already been torn apart comes out from the wound.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 Therefore, there is no hope for its cure nor for the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 If the arrow falls into the bladder and urine comes out, and something proceeds to the outside and the pain is greater than the sickness; then know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 The remaining limbs, as well as the face, neck, throat, spatula, aid, dorsal vertebrae, hip, leg, and similar bones are saved according to various arrangements when the arrow does not hit an artery or nerve, and the arrow is not venomous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 And I tell you what I saw about these arrows, so that it may indicate to you regarding your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 What happened is that an arrow fell into the eye of a certain man, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 Therefore I extracted it from the other side, below his ear fat: and he was healed, and no damage occurred to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen upon his eyelid under the lower lid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not obtain anything more than a small part of it which adhered to its wooden shaft: and the arrow was large among the arrows of Turkish bows, with soft iron, in which there are no feathers.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 Therefore the Jew was healed, and no accidental harm occurred to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 And I extracted another arrow from a Christian's throat.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 And the arrow was Arabian, and it had feathers.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 Therefore I made an incision over it between two windpipes: and already it was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 I became sharp with it until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 And I extracted another arrow from a man who it had fallen upon his abdomen: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 After thirty days had passed and nothing was changed in his condition, I made an incision over the arrow: and I probed it, and extracted it: and he was healed, and no accidental harm occurred to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 And I saw a man upon whom an arrow had fallen on his back, and the wound was consolidated over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 After seven years, the arrow emerged at the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	 And I saw a woman whose arrow fell into her womb, and the wound healed upon her, and the arrow remained within her; and no change occurred in her condition, and the woman found no harm in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 And I saw another man, whose arrow fell into his face; and the wound healed, and it remained, not finding him much pain; and similar things happened many times.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 And I extracted the arrow from a man among the king's princes, which had fallen upon him in the middle of his nose and had already begun to turn slightly toward the right; and the arrow was completely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 Therefore I was called for his treatment after the loss of the arrow for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 I therefore found the wound of the arrow to be very narrow.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 Then I probed it with a delicate probe and did not feel it; but he himself found a puncture and pain on his right side beneath his ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 Therefore I hoped that the puncture was at the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 Then I applied a plaster to the place where there was an attractant and digestive virtue, confident that the wound would heal and appear to me the sign of the arrow, so that I could cut above it; but it did not happen at the expected place, showing that the arrow had missed its mark.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 I therefore remained with the plaster upon him for many days; but it did not happen as expected, and the wound healed in the meantime; and he remained weak from the extraction of it until one day he felt the arrow within his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 Therefore I put sharp, corrosive medicine upon that wound for many days until it opened; and when I probed it myself, I felt the subtle end of the arrow which was attached to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 Then I added sharp medicine to the opening of the wound until it became visible that the arrow-tip appeared to us; and moreover, he passed away from me with that time span of about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 After the wound was expanded and I had the opportunity to insert forceps into it, and move it, but it did not obey to come out; then I did not stop trying, and devising means for it with all my crafts, until on a certain day when the forceps were well made according to their form at the end of the chapter, I pulled it out.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 And indeed physicians judge that the nasal cartilage does not heal.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 I therefore restored it, and the wound healed, and the weak health became whole; nothing at all harmed him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I tell you about the quality of the extraction of certain arrows, so that you put this rule and significance upon what I have not said.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Because the parts and divisions of this art are not grasped with the narrative; neither does that book grasp it, nor a prudent craftsman compares much with little; and concerning what is present, about what is absent: and he discovers a new operation, and a new tool for descents of external things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 I say that arrows do not come out from the members to which they are fixed, unless in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 Or by being drawn out from the place where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Or on the contrary, by the other part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 And that which comes out from where it entered is either a projectile in a fleshy place; and it is drawn, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 If it does not obey to come out from the hour when it fell; then it is necessary that you leave it for some days until the flesh around it rots; and the attraction of it will weaken, and its coming out will take place.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 And similarly, if it is incised in the bone and does not obey you for discharge, then release it even for several days; and repeat it with attraction and movement every day, until it discharges.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 If it does not obey you for discharge after several days, then it is necessary to bore holes around the bone with a fine lancet from all sides until the splinters are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 Then draw it out and remove it (the foreign body).
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 If the arrow is fixed in the skull bone and has already penetrated one of the ventricles of the brain and there appear some of the symptoms I mentioned earlier, then refrain from drawing the arrow out and let it be for several days until its state has become equal (with the body).
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 For if the arrow reaches the spinal column, then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 And if the arrow is not fixed except within the body of the bone itself and does not penetrate as far as the spinal column, and the man remains sick for some days without any of the mentioned symptoms occurring: then apply skill in drawing out the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 If it is fixed deeply and does not obey you for drawing out, then administer a lancet around the arrow as I told you; then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 If the arrow is already hidden in the body's location, and it is concealed and hidden from sensation, then search for it with probing (exploration).
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 If you feel the arrow, then draw it out with certain instruments suitable for its drawing out.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 If you cannot draw it out due to the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow in depth, and there is no bone, nerve, or vein there: then pierce (make a small opening) above it until the wound is enlarged enough for the arrow to be extracted.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 If there are ears to which he is holding, then free the fixed flesh in them from every side, with every artifice you can, and if not possible for dislocation of the flesh beyond the fracture of the ears, then twist until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 When you administer the extraction of an arrow, wherever it is, then use twisting with your hand, along with forceps to all parts, until you make it come out: and subtlety of last subtlety, so that the arrow is not broken, and its attraction and removal becomes difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 If you cannot do it from one hour, then leave it for some days, until what is around its circumference putrefies.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 Then repeat it: indeed the tunica will become loose. But if the counteraction makes bleeding for you, then administer what we said in the cure chapter of it: and keep your strength from cutting a vein, or nerve, or tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 And administer artifice in every way as possible for the extraction of the arrow: and it should be with ease, calmness, slowness, or firmness, as I told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 And it is necessary that when you pull the arrow, you make him weak according to the figure, according to which the arrow was at the time of its fall in him.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 But if it is not possible for you, then administer what is possible according to the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 The arrow that goes out from the opposite side of another part, or already proceeds something towards the exterior: or makes humpiness at the end of the arrow by sensation from the upper part of the skin nearby, and you see it projecting: cut therefore above it, and the cut should be according to the amount so that forceps can catch in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 Then draw it out, for it becomes easy to expel.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 If it is retained in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness, until the arrowhead impresses on the bone and dilates itself; then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 And if not: let it be for some days; then attempt it again until it exits.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 If the arrow shaft is in it, then push it out along with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 If the arrow shaft fell off and you wish to administer force: then insert a concave instrument into it so that its concavity enters the tail of the arrow; then push it out along with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 If the arrow is concave, then push it out with the instrument inserted into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 The arrow is pulled by that (instrument).
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to cut all the flesh where the venom is; if it is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 Then care for it with whatever suits that (injury).
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 If the arrow is falling into the chest, or in the abdomen, or in the bladder, or in the side, and it is close to where you touch it with your probe, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and beware not to cut a vein or nerve, and remove it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 Then suture the wound, if you see it, and care for it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 And this is the form of forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 The ends should be similar to a bird's beak, which have been made thus of iron; when they grasp the arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 And they are made in many different sizes, large, small, and medium, according to the size of the arrow, its narrowness, and the width and constriction of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 Form of a lever concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 The form of a deafening thrower (or projectile).
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 This is the end of the bowstring-like instrument similar to a radius (for) its passage into the concave arrow, and it is propelled with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 The end of the lever's concave form is concave, like a bird's feather: for its passage into the arrow and the thrust from it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 Chapter on Phlebotomy of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	 Chapter XCVII.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 Veins to be bled, whose course is established within the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	 From the head there are sixteen: two pulsating veins behind the ears, called the two herbs; and two arteries which appear at the temples; and two veins that are found at the inner corners of the eyes of both eyes, called the 'Aspicientes'; and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead; and a vein at the tip of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	 And two jugulars, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	 And two veins that are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	 And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	 And these are the veins called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	 And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	 The veins that are bled in the arms, there are five veins on each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	 One of them is called the Cephalic and it comes from the side of the wood; and the people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	 Et Fusca means "And black" in English.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	 And it is the middle vein, and it is composed of a branch from the Basilica, and a branch from the Cephalic: and the people call it the body's vein.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	 And Basilica, and it is placed on the domestic side: and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	 And the people call it the vein of the liver.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	 And the string of the arm, and it is placed on the elbow: and that is where bloodletting is done, and that is which appears above the thumb in a visible manner.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	 And Saluatella: and it is the vein that is between the ankle and the smallest bone: and there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	 And in the leg and foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	 One of them is which is under the bend of the thumb from the side of the forest.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	 And the second is Saphena: and its place is at the heel on the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 And vein of Nessus: and its place is at the heel on the forest side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	 And in the other leg there are three veins similar to these.
