¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	 [Section on bloodletting of two veins after the ears]
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	 Indeed, bloodletting of the two veins that are after the ears is a help for old catarrhs, and for hematoma, and for scrofulas, and for old ulcers of the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	 And the quality of bloodletting it (the vein) is according to what I have described.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	 And it should be shaved (the head of the sick person): and the back part of his head should be rubbed at the place of two veins with a rough cloth for good rubbing.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	 Then the sick person should bind his neck with bandage until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	 And their places are after the ears, in two depressed parts of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	 You should seek them with your finger, and where you feel a pulse from them under your finger, there mark it with wax.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	 Then take the lancet, and it is called Incisor.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	 Then introduce it under the vein into the flesh until the lancet reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	 Then slide your hand with the vein and skin upward, and cut the vein with an incising cut.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	 And let the length of the incision be the size of two joined fingers or approximately that, and make as much blood come out as you want.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	 Then tie it with threads, and release it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	 And now the incision of them and their cauterization has been treated at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	 Chapter on phlebotomy of two Arteries in Time.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	 The help of phlebotomy of two arteries which are in the two times is for the old hemigraine: and the sodam pruam, and obtalmiam assiduam: and the course of superfluous effusions acute to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the quality of phlebotomizing them is as I told you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	 Let the sick person tighten his neck much until two veins appear to the senses with clear evidence and it will be shown that their pulse is felt under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	 Then mark them with wax.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	 Then slide the skin over the vein upward with your index finger and introduce the lancet below incising it, and slide the vein upward.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 And cut it as you did with two other veins: and make the blood flow according to your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	 Then loosen the constriction of the sick person, and place your finger over one vein.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	 After placing it on the affected part and applying small poultices, tie it tightly above: then let it remain until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	 And now recalls the reminders of those (things) to be cut and those to be extracted, at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	 Chapter on venesection of the forehead vein, after venesection of the cerebral vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	 But the benefit of venesection of the forehead vein is after venesection of the cerebral vein, for the ancient pains in the face; and for hemicrania, and redness; and for foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the quality of this venesection is as I have told you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	 A weak person should bind his neck with a bandage until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	 Then take the instrument called Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	 Here is its shape (description).
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	 Place the pointed end of the Fossorium on the vein and strike it with a mallet or another tool in its manner; then let the blood flow according to the quantity you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	 Then heal the puncture of the weak person, and tie it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	 And sometimes it is opened with a broad lancet during venesection.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	 However, the venesector should not be one with a sharp point, as are the other venesectors, but rather one with a broad point.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	 The venesection should be made across (transversely), because the bone is close; and possibly the venesector will break it if it is too sharp.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	 Chapter on venesection of veins in two Lacrimal sacs.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	 But the benefit of the two veins that are in the two Lacrimal sacs of two eyes is for the eye affected by scabs and redness; also for swelling in the eye, and the pains of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	 The quality of phlebotomy for them is to tighten a weak neck with a bandage.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	 Then [the assistant] for the phlebotomy: and thou shalt stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	 And let the phlebotomy be made across the width rather than length, with a small cutter and wide slightly, for there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	 For if the phlebotomist is subtle at the extremity, perhaps it breaks.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	 Then let run from the blood as much as it necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	 And place upon them a cloth, and tighten them at night, and loosen them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	 [Section] On the phlebotomy of Nasic Veins.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	 The veins of the nose, phlebotomy is for acute fever, and violent swelling, and ailments of the face, such as hemigraine and redness which occurs on the face; especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	 And the quality of phlebotomy for them is to tighten a weak neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	 Then hold his nose with your left hand, and take a subtle, long cutter; and fix it in the middle of the tip of the nose, between that which separates the nose according to straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	 For the vein is not visible there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	 And it is necessary that you hold the end of your hand with the cutter slightly; and let run from the blood according to your necessity.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	 Then tie it at night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	 For it heals quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	 [Section] On the phlebotomy of Guidi veins.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	 Indeed, two of the phlebotomies of Guidi are for the constriction of coughing, and the beginning of leprosy, and melancholic ailments, and impetigo and bad ulcers, and those that are corroding; that is, herpes or meningeal.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	 And the quality of phlebotomy is that it binds the sick one under both neck with a ligature; and the craftsman stands over the head of the sick one, and the sick one sits on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	 Then phlebotomy vein to the length of phlebotomy shall be somewhat less.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	 Then draw a measured amount of blood, or according to what you see for the necessity that is for it.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	 Then do the same with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	 Afterwards loosen the ligature, and bind two veins tightly together: so that the sick one does not faint.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	 And let it (the vein) be until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	 For the wound heals.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	 [Title: On Phlebotomy of Veins by Albucasis]
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	 The veins, according to Albucasis, are useful for phlebotomy because they help with alcoholism in the mouth, and corruption of teeth; and with sores, fissures of the lips, sores (also) which are in the nose, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	 And the quality of phlebotomy for those is, that you make the sick one sit before you; and bind his neck with a linen cloth.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	 Then roll back his lip, and look at the two veins; one of which is from the right side of the lip, and the second from the left of it; and the demonstration of each is by blackening both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	 And that is true because around them (the veins) there are small, black veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	 Cut therefore each one with a cutting instrument.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	 If there is doubt on you and you do not know which one it is; then direct your attention to the larger one of them and that one more clearly.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	 And do the same with the two veins that are in the upper lip; and most of all is custom with it (the phlebotomy); and cut two veins which are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	 On phlebotomy: Vein under the tongue after cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	 Of the two veins which are under the tongue, phlebotomy is beneficial: because phlebotomy of the cephalic is for affections that are in the throat, and for diseases of the palate, and for diseases of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	 And the quality of phlebotomizing these (veins) is that the sick person should sit before you in the sunlight; and loosen his tongue, and look beneath it on one side for a vein, and on the other side for a vein; and the color of both should lean towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	 So, phlebotomize each (vein), and be careful not to injure your hand while phlebotomizing them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	 For beneath these (veins) are the arteries, and possibly there will be bleeding from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	 On three veins in the elbow:
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	 The three veins that are phlebotomized in the elbow are those whose phlebotomy is customary in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	 And phlebotomy of these (veins) is made according to two modes.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	 Or by puncturing with a broad-bladed phlebotome (myrtine): or by applying oil to the point of the vein for softening: or by cutting with a phlebotome of a knife, and this is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	 This Alnesil (instrument) is for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	 And from these (veins) there are broad and narrow forms according to the size and constriction of the veins: The form of the phlebotome myrtine is broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	 And it (the phlebotome myrtine) is suitable for opening curved veins, full, projecting, visible, thick, and those that contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	 This phlebotomist is smaller in size and more subtle in cutting.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	 It suits for the venesection of fine veins containing subtle, citron-colored blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	 Chapter on Venesection (Phlebotomy) from Basilica.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	 Among the three veins of phlebotomy, the Basilica is helpful.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	 Because it draws blood from ailments that are under the throat and neck, as it follows the chest and abdomen; it is suitable for the phlebotomist to perform phlebotomy on it, so that he may be careful, and it should be done with caution because below it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	 If the phlebotomist makes a mistake and adds in the prick, he will cut that artery and there will be bleeding.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	 Therefore, it is necessary that neither the phlebotomist nor the phlebotomee pricks (it); instead, it should be cut with a lancet (Alnesil).
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	 If the Basilica does not appear in a clear manifestation, then it is necessary that you search for another or change to another; or look for one of its branches; or use the arm as replacement for phlebotome (Funem brachii).
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	 It is indeed clear and should be cut with a lancet (Anesil) as we said earlier.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	 If you wish to perform the venesection of that (same) one, then it is necessary before tightening the arm, so that you touch the place, until you know the location of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	 Then mark the place with a hot iron, afterwards tighten the arm, and cut the vein with a curved incision using a lancet (Alnesil) as we said earlier.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	 And be careful that the blow does not fall into the space from the location of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	 And when you see, as you tighten the bandage, an expansion (inflation) at the place which you marked with hot iron, then that expansion is an expansion of the artery; avoid it therefore.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	 If you see blood rise during venesection, like the urine of a boy, and it is thin, red: then you know that it is from the artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	 Then hurry up, and place your finger over it at a longer space, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	 If the blood is cut off (for it is often cut off), then tie the arm, and let it be; and let the weak avoid moving it; and let there be fear of it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 And do not move it for some days until it heals.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	 If the blood does not flow off and presses you, and medicine is not present to you at that moment, then cut the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For its extremities contract, and the blood flows off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	 Or take the bark of a fig tree and pound it; take half of it, and tie it over the appropriate place of the vein's narrowing, with a ligature and pledgets until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	 If the blood flows off, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	 And if it does not: then cure the place with the memory of the one who went before, by removing dust that stops the flow of blood; and the removal of its blood is not difficult in many positions due to the small size of the wound and the possibility of a ligature from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	 Chapter on venesection of the femoral vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	 The help of the femoral vein venesection is that it draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower body; therefore, because it is composed of a branch of the Basilica vein, and a branch of the Cephalic vein, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	 And it is fitting for the venesectionist that he fear that place from venesection because a nerve is beneath it.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	 If therefore nerve is touched in the puncture of phlebotomy, and faintness occurs, difficult will be its healing, and it may not recover fully.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	 And this nerve often appears to sensation.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	 If however it is hidden in some people and it is delicate and not shown: then it is necessary that you place your phlebotomy where you can phlebotomize it, a section with Alnesil, and avoid the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	 If the vein is between two nerves, then pierce the vein in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	 Chapter on the Vein of the Head.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	 The phlebotomy of the Vein of the Head is beneficial because it draws blood from the head, and contributes to diseases of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	 And it is proper in this vein, if you wish, that when phlebotomizing it with the oil phlebotomy or the myrtle phlebotomy, it is oiled with oil of olive or myrtle: because it is safer than all veins, because it is not below an artery, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	 Nevertheless it is suitable for you at the phlebotomy, that you avoid the head and arm only, and seek a softer place: and it will not hurt it, if it is not found with the first blow, that you repeat over it with the phlebotomy several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	 Nevertheless perhaps it may be bled when not phlebotomized in the first blow, but it will not harm it that bleb in some.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	 Chapter on the Usefulness of Phlebotomy, and Cautions to be Observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	 The quality of phlebotomy, and its effects from which you should consider correcting it.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	 First of all you should know that phlebotomy is not administered unless for the conservation of health, and its maintenance, and caution against the onset of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	 And let phlebotomy be performed on one of the three veins that are in the elbow, namely, the Cephalic, the Flexor, and the Basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	 And let phlebotomy be done at the beginning of spring while fasting, and during summer and autumn after eating, when signs of fullness appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	 Let phlebotomy be done on the first day or third day after passing three hours from the previous day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	 However, phlebotomy administered for illness does not have a fixed hour; it is done whenever the situation and necessity requires it, whether during the night or day, and at any hour and time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	 And it is not appropriate to perform phlebotomy on boys until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	 A pregnant woman shall not be subjected to phlebotomy from the fourth month until the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	 Elderly persons who have surpassed sixty years shall not be subjected to phlebotomy.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	 Therefore, when someone wishes to undergo phlebotomy for any reason, it is necessary that they clean their intestines before the procedure with a mild clisterium if there is much feces retained; so as not to attract unhealthy putrid waste from the intestines near the veins during the phlebotomy, harming the main organs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	 A patient suffering from toctina (satiation or nausea) shall not be subjected to phlebotomy; nor one who is intoxicated or drunk, until that condition has been removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	 A person with dropsy should not be subjected to phlebotomy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	 And beware of phlebotomy after suffering from colic, vomiting, diarrhea, excessive sexual activity, labor, exercise, wakefulness, fasting, or anything that weakens the body's strength in any way.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	 Then consider in subtlety of humors before that, if the blood is thick with foods and drinks, and medicines: if it can be done to him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	 Then enter the bath, if it does not forbid him something: or exercise with some exercise, so that blood may be made more subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	 And place phlebotomy in his chest on the third day, as we said before: and try to evacuate his chest that day with all its bad conditions such as tightness, anger, fear, and with all bodily conditions such as labor, punishment, excess, and similar ones.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	 And let him sit with those things present which custom of men has run with respect to aromatics, smell, joy and similar ones according to the possibility of quantity.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	 Then let the phlebotomist sit on the pulvinar that is higher than the phlebotomy pulvinar: then he should pull out his arm and rub it with his hand twice or thrice.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	 Then tie the ligature with a cord and wrap it around twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	 And let the ligature be moderate because when the ligature is uneven or too tight in the ligature, then it prevents the flow of blood; or in softening, it also prevents the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	 Then after the ligature it is necessary that the person to be bled rubs his hands together until the veins swell and are felt.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	 Then the phlebotomist cleans the puncture site with a little oil, old oil specifically.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	 Then place the index finger of his left hand on that vein where he wants to do the phlebotomy a little bit, so that the vein does not escape and the blow is not scattered.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	 Because veins are like fleeing cords during phlebotomy; and some of them are full of wind; and when you put the phlebotomy on it, it shrinks under the phlebotomist, and the phlebotomist is deceived, and he does not open the vein; and if he opens it, it is narrowed; therefore for this reason it is necessary that the phlebotomist should be firm and attentive to all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	 Then let him lay down (the) leeches.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	 If a vein is opened from one side (of the body), it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	 And if not, then repeat that with another side at that place or above it with haste; unless there is no need for cautery (cauterization).
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	 If (the vein) is cauterized or the sick person frightens, then let him go on the day or two days; and do not tie the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	 Perhaps it draws a boil hotly.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	 Do not enter (the) bathhouse.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	 Then let him repeat the leeching, if (there is) blood (flow).
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	 If the opening is small or blood flows finely; and beware that the amount of blood does not leave what you want; then repeat the leeching in the same vein according to correctness, and add a little more in the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	 And do that with haste before cauterizing the place; because cauterized places are many among people during small operations.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	 If you see that (the boil) is already cauterized, then do not repeat on it at all, because it does not excuse anything from you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	 And place something from oil paste on it; because it encourages the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	 And it is better in this place than oil itself and other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	 And similarly administer oil paste in all your leeching of the veins, where leeches stop the flow of blood; and this is made by Tyriacans and Alfarachs, when it is put on one of them (the oils).
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	 Blood becomes fine and dissolves when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	 If it happens at the site of leeching that a large boil occurs, for it often happens, especially to him who is not a leecher except in that place or the opening of the vein is small; then hurry and place on the spot a sponge soaked in water and salt, heated a little; and tie it for an hour; because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	 It is necessary that you do this after the exit of blood from the vein itself, when it completes itself, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	 If something remains in the place after several days of blackening or greening, it does not harm; and if you wish, place on top of it some alcohol, or myrrh dissolved; or something from the juice of mint, that is, camphor or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	 And often abscesses and protrusions occur at the phlebotomy of the basilica (large vein in the arm).
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	 Place your hand upon it (the abscess), then if you find softness under your pressure on it, then that protrusion is evil.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	 Be careful, therefore, that you place something on it (the abscess) from what was said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	 For perhaps blood from the artery will flow out of it.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	 But make a plaster for it (the abscess) with that which contains the hardening substance, so that the place may become solidified.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it (the patient) with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	 It is necessary that you draw out blood from every man according to the strength of its virtue (the power of the bloodletting instrument).
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	 And what appears as a purple color above the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	 For if the blood is black, then let it flow out until it becomes red; and similarly if you see it thick, then let it flow out until it becomes thin; and similarly if it is sharp (acute), then let it flow out until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	 It is necessary for him who is full, strong, and needs bloodletting to be done once, that the phlebotomy of the vein be amplified, and that the bloodletter (the person performing the bloodletting) should be on the side; and for him who is weak, it should be the opposite.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	 It is necessary that he draws it out at the veins and that there be a narrow hole: and it is better what is administered in venesection is, that it be a transverse section, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	 This method of venesection is healthy against blood flow and nerve cut, and it is more commendable and safer than venesection by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	 He who usually comes upon venesection with fainting, it is necessary that he be given small bread soaked in water of pomeranate juice or wine before venesection: or dried, if he is heated: and draw out from his blood in three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	 If she is of cold constitution, then let her receive before venesection bread soaked in syrup of myrrh or in syrup of honey scented with spices, or in fragrant scented syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	 If fainting occurs during venesection and the cause is a large outflow of blood, then it is necessary that she drink meat water and subtle scented syrup: and use aromatics with algae, and let her be swaddled on her chest with this: and use the rest which we said in the division in the chapter on fainting from bleeding.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	 He who wants to reduce his arm and release his blood in the second degree: it is necessary for him whose venesection is for great evacuation and whose strength is weak, that he releases blood gradually by the quantity of his strength in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	 But he who wants to reduce his arm and release his blood in the second degree and is obese: then let him do it after seven hours, or nine, from his first venesection.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	 But he who wants to draw blood from his body against the opposite part to which he leans: it is necessary that it be reduced to him on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	 In whose body there is much heated blood, which becomes sharper and causes fever: it is necessary that blood should exit from him once, and a large quantity should be drawn out of him; and the opening should be enlarged until fainting occurs; after you have observed all the conditions of venesection, and placed your hand over his pulse at the flow of blood, so that death does not occur instead of fainting.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	 Many times this happens when the venesectioner is unaware and falls into negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	 And it is not appropriate when you wish to release the arm and draw blood a second time, if the orifice of the vein is already closed and the exit of blood becomes difficult, that one should press on it with force and the affected area be extended quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	 For this is very bad indeed, rather let it go until it can be venesected a second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	 Or remove with the sharpness of the venesectioner that which has congealed from blood in the vein's orifice and place something dissolved in salt water on it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	 And put upon it some turmeric or alum, or sage root, and place it under gentle compression until blood exits.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	 But if the vein has already been cut, then let it be and do not cover it up until the tumor settles down.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	 If necessity demands that blood be drawn a second time and there is no excuse, then either venesection should be done on the same spot, or on another vein in the other arm.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	 The band of the arm is venesected at the place of Fuscus and Basilicus, as they are not found and hidden because they are composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	 And the quality of venesection is that a weak hand should be inserted into warm water until it turns red and the vein appears clearly manifest.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	 Then tie a moderately loose ligature over it.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	 Then perform the venesection gradually, neither longitudinally nor transversely, but slightly curved; and let the opening be wide, and the incision for venesection be made near the joint of the hand.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	 If the flow of blood is prevented, then immerse the hand in hot water, and let the blood run into the water until your need is met.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	 But if you are in summer days, then excuse yourself from immersing the hand in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	 Above all, it is advised to let the flow of blood run into hot water during winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	 This venesection is safer than any other vein as it is neither artery nor nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	 The venesection of the cephalic vein in the right hand is beneficial for diseases of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	 The quality of this venesection is that you should tie the cephalic vein with a ligature or your hand after inserting it into hot water until the vein swells up and becomes very sensitive.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	 Then perform the venesection across [the vein].
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	 And if you cut it completely, it will not harm him at all.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	 Preserve, do not harm your hand with the venesection.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	 For under it are the nerves of the fingers exposed from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	 Then immerse the hand again into hot water and let the blood run into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	 For if you do not immerse [the hand] in hot water, the blood will coagulate at the opening of the vein and prevent further flow.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	 When you have extracted the required amount of blood, then place oil and salt on the vein to prevent it from coagulating quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	 And similarly, it is necessary that you do with every strict branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	 The remedy for phlebotomy is from the left hand. Because it is akin to sickness of the spleen; and similarly do with phlebotomy as you did in the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	 The remedy for saphenous vein phlebotomy is for the sicknesses which are in the lower part of the body, such as the illnesses of the womb, and retention of menses, and the weaknesses of the kidneys, and ulcers of the hips and legs that are old, and similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	 And the quality of phlebotomy for this is that a weak person should immerse his foot in warm water; and make friction on it until the veins appear; and tie above the ankle joint with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	 And indeed the location of the vein is at the heel, visible towards the thumb; and they branch out from it on the face of the foot in many branches.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	 Therefore phlebotomy should be done in a larger branch of it or at the heel in its gathering; because it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	 If phlebotomy is done on the face of the foot, then beware of the nerves that are beneath it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	 And place your phlebotomy instrument as if you want to cut it transversely; and let the phlebotomist be Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	 If there is a prohibition of the outflow of blood, then immerse his foot in warm water; and let the blood flow into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	 If the phlebotomist misses the vein in the first instance, then he should move it slightly upwards, because it is safer, and do not worry about ill-effects when you are careful of the nerves, as we said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	 And likewise with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 The location of the sciatic vein, as we have said, is at the calcaneum side on the forest-side (lateral side).
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	 And the aid of phlebotomy for it (the vein) is for pain in the ankle when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	 And the quality of phlebotomy for it (the vein) is that an invalid should enter the bath and hurry: and bind the leg from the side of the ankle up to the calcaneum four fingers, with thin ointment long: for it does not appear unless for that reason.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	 When it appears, then phlebotomy should be done according to whatever skill is possible for you, or according to a crossing (transverse): and it is better, or as if you make an incision in it with an incision, or cut it with a section (ligature).
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	 Its location is safer, and it is hidden very much in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	 If you do not find it (the vein) and it does not appear at all to the sense: then phlebotomy should be done for one of its branches, and there is one that appears on the back of the foot, turned towards the ear: and be careful about nerves, and let the blood flow according to the amount you want.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	 Then loosen the ligature, and place skin over the site of phlebotomy, and bind the site.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	 It is quickly cured.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	 On ventosation and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	 Chapter XCVIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	 Bladders are made from horns, and from copper, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	 And bladdering is done in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	 With incision and bloodletting; and another kind of bladdering without incision.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	 And this kind of bladdering without incision is done in two ways as well.
Aut enim est cum igne.	 Or it is done with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	 Or it is done without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	 And the places in the body where bladdering with incision and bloodletting are administered are fourteen.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	 One of them is the bladdering of Alnocrates, which is at the end of the head; and Alkehel, which is in the middle of the neck; and the bladdering of Alhagdahim, which are two plates of the neck from both sides; and the bladdering of the mind, which is under the jaw in the lower part of the mouth; and the bladdering of the two spoon-shaped places; and the bladdering of Alachosos above the end of the tail; and the bladdering of the two testicles, and they are in the middle of the arms; and the bladdering of the two legs; and the bladdering of the two calves.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	 And bladdering indeed does not draw blood from the veins that are scattered throughout the flesh, and therefore it does not have the same effect as the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	 It is not necessary to administer bladdering whether with fire or without it in any disease that comes from congestion until the entire body has been evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	 If necessity requires bladdering due to a disease or custom, we administer it at the beginning of every month, at its end, and in the middle of it, and at any time.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	 This is because there are some people who when their blood multiplies, until it requires extraction through bladdering, find a headache and pressure in their heads.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	 And from these (cases) is he who finds distention and redness on his face, on his head, and on his neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	 And from these (cases) is he who finds itching on his face and forehead, and darkness and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	 And from these (cases) is he who scratches a site of his wind-inflammation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	 And from these (cases) is he whose laughter increases.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	 And from these (cases) is he who finds the taste of blood in his mouth: or who spits out the blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	 And from these (cases) is he whose sleep increases.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	 And from these (cases) is he who sees in his sleep blood and redness, and the dead, and wounds, and things similar to those.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	 When we see something from these (cases), and properly if it is during the third month (trimester): we then command that the wind-inflammation should be made, after two or three hours have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	 The remedy for wind-inflammation of the neck is: because it (wind-inflammation) contributes to heaviness in the head and because it discharges to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	 But indeed it must be that this (the wind-inflammation of the neck) is after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	 And this (wind-inflammation) certainly is in the place of a cephalic phlebotomy (venesection).
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	 And it is not allowed to use this (wind-inflammation) for one who has a cold constitution, or in whom there is catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	 Because it does great harm to him.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	 And because of this (the great harm), it is not necessary for the elderly, and in one whose head there are cold diseases, to use this.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	 He who frequently does it (wind-inflammation) generates confusion over him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	 And because of this (the confusion generated), it is necessary to command the wind-inflator to lower his hand with the wind-inflation a little towards the lower part, fearing from the generation of confusion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	 Ventosatio or Alkehel, is in place of the phlebotomy of Fuscus, and of the phlebotomy Basilicae, and for that reason it resembles coughing, constriction of breathing, fissure of instrument breathing, coughing, and filling.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	 And it is necessary that the Ventosatio Alkehel should be pushed a little, since if it is placed lower, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	 Ventosatio alhagdahim, resembles pains in the head, migraines, ophthalmia, perforations, and pain in the roots of teeth: and is in place of the phlebotomy of Basilicae.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And it is necessary that you warn the Ventosator not to press his hand during scarification, so as not to cut an artery and cause bleeding.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	 Ventosatio however under the chin causes alcohol in the mouth and decay of gums, and similar diseases that are in the mouth: and it remains in place of another phlebotomy which are on both lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	 Ventosation of spatulas causes alchafacham, which occurs from compression and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	 However, the ventosation of the internal parts of two testicles gives help to the phlebotomy of the three veins: Basilica, Fuscus, and Cephalicus, since it attracts blood from all those fine veins that are in the flesh: and these fine veins attract blood from other larger ones until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	 And it is necessary that you warn the Ventosator not to proceed too far in scarification, since the place is stripped of flesh and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	 The ventosation that is done over alchausos causes hemorrhoids in the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	 It is necessary that you command the one who applies the cupping glass, that it should be a strong vacuum and that it should be made of glass: because the place requires strong suction, and perhaps the fine cups may break; and it shall be incised by large incision.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	 The cups for the legs are diminished by obvious reduction: because they draw blood from the whole body, and they cause ancient pains in kidneys, uterus, and bladder; they provoke menstruation, and they cause swelling and water retention; and they stand at the place of phlebotomy for two saphena veins and alhorcoben.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	 However, they weaken the body greatly, and they cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	 And the help of the cups for the legs is near to the help of the cups for two legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	 The quality of the positioning of the cups is that you should place the cup first in an empty space, and suck with moderate suction; and do not prolong the positioning of the cups, but place them quickly, and remove them quickly, so that humors come to the place at equal speed; and do not stop repeating this and continuing until you see the place become red and swell, and the redness appears to be blood; then scarify, and continue with suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	 Then consider in the arrangement of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	 For the one who is from humans with soft flesh and rare pores, it is necessary to scarify him only once, not more: so that the place does not ulcerate.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	 And command the one who applies the cupping glass, to enlarge the incision and not to dig too deep; and regulate the suction in ease, speed, and gentle motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	 If there is thick blood in it, then it is necessary to scarify him twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	 In the first instance, the way for subtle bleeding and its thinning is opened, and in the second instance, an examination of a precise extraction of thick blood is performed.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	 If the blood is extremely foul, then make a third incision so that it may follow its course to the end.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	 And finally, when we wish to extract blood little by little or in small amounts, one incision is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	 If we wish to make a multiple extraction of blood, let there be many incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	 And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it is necessary to incise deeply, and the end of the incision in depth is equal to the thickness of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	 What is that which should be administered from oils for the position of Ventosas (a surgical position), and what should be avoided in ventosing.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	 In a thick person with tough, dark skin and narrow pores, it is necessary to anoint the places for Ventosas with open, softening, resolving oils such as alkeiri oil or camphorated oil or sweet almond oil or cucumber seed oil during summer.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	 And if it is winter, then use narcissus oil, or lily oil, or chamomile oil, or soapwort, and similar.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	 If the superfluity is thick and cold, then use amaracus oil, or balm of Gilead oil, or white oil, or anise oil, and similar.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	 If the ventoser has large pores and tender flesh, then it is necessary to prohibit oil and to wash the places for Ventosas with rose water, cold water, salty water, cucumber water, or portulaca water, and similar.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	 The man whose blood is of great moistness, wash with vinegar or water of myrtle and sumach; and similar to these.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	 Whose excretions are thick, wash the fecal matter with old wine or water of cumin, or a concoction of anise or chamomile; and similar to these.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	 It is necessary to avoid fecal matter in the bath or near the bath, rather it should be administered after leaving the bath for an hour or two.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	 Nor should anyone sleep after the fecal matter has been expelled.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	 [paragraph: What is necessary to control Ventosandus or Phlebotomatus before fecal matter expulsion.]
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	 [after it (the fecal matter expulsion) is necessary to consider first: if Ventosandus or Phlebotomatus is choleric and the sharpness and inflammation prevail over his blood, then it is necessary that he receives cooling agents such as musk melon; also endive with vinegar and lettuce, secaniabin, and iuleb; and similar to these.]
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	 [and place his food with young chickens, roasted mutton sheep, cooked foods with vinegar; and similar to these.]
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	 [and for the one whose complexion is cold, it is necessary to drink syrup made from honey or almonds or secaniabin made from seeds; and drink moderately scented wine that is between old and new; and it should be prescribed that he eats sparingly.]
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	 [and place his food with young chickens, roast capon; and sparrows, that is small birds; and quails (columba issidae)]
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	 [and it is necessary that the drink on the day of fecal matter expulsion and venesection should be more than food; and it should be given in drink to certain people with tyriaca alfaroch or medicine made from musk (muscata), or aleselithe before fecal matter expulsion; and before or after venesection, in order to strengthen the main limbs and refine the blood.]
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	 It is not fitting for them to take it in a warm drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	 On wind-puffs without incision.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	 Wind-puffs that are without incision are those placed upon the liver, spleen, podagra, abdomen, umbilicus, places of kidneys, and pox on the anus: because these members do not endure incision on themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	 Nor is it sought through them, unless it is an attraction from one member to another: just as we place the wind-puff on the breasts in the illness of flowing blood of the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	 And we use them to dissolve cold wind-puff in a member from a member: just as we place the wind-puff on the abdomen and umbilicus.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	 For it makes the member rarefied, and warms it up, and removes pain for this reason, because it dissolves that wind-puff.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	 It is also placed upon the kidneys when there occurs obstruction or stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	 By its virtue of attraction, perhaps it opens obstruction, or excavates the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	 And similarly when it is placed upon the liver and spleen for crushing wind-puff in both of them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	 These wind-puffs are administered empty, with incision only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	 And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	 And sometimes they are administered full of warm water in diseases of pleurisy: and this is, that the wind-puff should be filled with warm water alone, or water in which boiled herbs agree.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	 On the form of a wind-puff administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	 Let the width of its orifice be two fingers open, according to what we have fashioned: and let its depth be half a palm: and there should be on its side in the place that is about the middle of it, a small hole, according to the quantity that enters into it with an awl: make it from brass, or citrine, of equal thickness, smooth, polished: so that it does not hurt the member under its position upon it: and let there be in its middle a crossbar transverse from brass or iron, where the candle is placed with fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	 And now it becomes this swollen large one, greater than we have said, and somewhat smaller than that (one), according to the illnesses and age of the person who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	 For boy's swellings and those of consumptives are different than man's swellings and fat bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	 The quality of placing this swelling with fire on a limb is to kindle a linen cloth or a small candle from wax and place it over the middle of the swelling that is in the middle of the swelling: so that the fire may be kindled around the lower part of the swelling, so as not to burn the body of the weak.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	 Then place it on a limb: let the finger be over the opening which I said, until we hold the swelling: while we need to press, remove the finger, and the vapor will come out through that opening, and the swelling will immediately dissolve.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	 Then kindle a linen cloth with fire according to its manner, and repeat it if you need it.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	 In swellings that are administered in the illness of pleurisy with water, there is no crossbar or opening: and it is not administered unless because it is filled with water, and placed on a limb only.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	 And this swelling, the larger it is, so that it can hold more water, is better.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	 Chapter on Suspension of Sanguesugars.
Caput XCIX.	 Chapter XCIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	 Sanguesugars are not administered in many places except where the position of swellings is not possible due to their small size, such as the lips, gums, and similar areas.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	 Or in a naked member without flesh, such as fingers, nose, and similar areas.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	 And the quality of using them is: that you come from Sanguesugs which are in sweet waters, clean of decay.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	 Then let them be kept day and night in sweet water until they are hunger-stricken, and nothing remains in their belly.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	 The body should first be evacuated with phlebotomy and cupping.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	 Then clean the sick member until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	 Place them on top of it afterwards.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	 When they are full and fall down, and it is possible to extract the juice of the place with cupping, then it is more beneficial for healing; if not, then clean the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	 Then wash it with much water, rub it, and squeeze it out.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.
