If the flow of blood persists after bleeding due to Sanguisugum (leech), it should be removed by dipping a piece of linen cloth into cold water and placing it on top until the drainage stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If blood multiplies, then sprinkle powdered zega (calamine), oyster shells, and similar substances derived from chalkstone on it until the bleeding stops.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	 Or place halved and peeled fava beans on the spot, leaving them until they adhere to the location; for the blood is drained away as the beans stick.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	 And it is necessary that if repeated bleeding with Sanguisugum (leech) is required, to change them when possible.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	 If leeches are forbidden from being suspended, then clean the place with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	 Or insert a needle into the spots until something comes out of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	 Then place them, for they will stick as soon as they feel some blood.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	 Whenever you want them to fall, sprinkle something from crushed aloes, salt or ashes on them; they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	 § Second Part Ends.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	 Chapter III of the Surgical Book of Albucasis begins here.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	 Discourse on restoration, dislocation, and treatment of torsions, and similar matters.
Caput I.	 De causa torsionis, et quibus partibus corporis apud homines frequenter accidit.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	 This chapter is often necessary in the art of Medicine; it is a restoration of broken bones and dislocations of joints.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	 Know ye, O sons, that foolish physicians and the common people boast about this chapter, and those who have never examined an ancient book nor read a letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	 And for this reason, this method is lacking among the known people of our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	 And I have never come across a good example of this method, nor have I mastered it except for the length of reading ancient books and my persistence in understanding them until I extracted knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I attached myself with determination and diligence throughout my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	 Now I have explained to you all that my knowledge contains about this chapter: and whatever my experience exceeds, after abridging it for you, and liberating it from the constraints of length, and abridging it to the point of abridgement, and showing it to the point of clarification: and I formed many shapes of instruments used in it, since it involves addition, as I did in the two preceding chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 Summary and collections of fractures in bones, from which a premise is necessary before we begin the remembrance of the broken limbs, and of various ones, if of each.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 It is necessary to say in the preamble of this chapter the main topics and headings, to which understanding is essential for the craftsman on the truth of them: namely, so that you, and those who are quick to learn, may know or learn this noble art from each other.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 I say then that when a fracture or dislocation, or twist, or fall happens to someone, it is necessary to hasten first to bleed him and dissolve it, or both at the same time: unless something prevents it, such as weakness of power; or it is a child who has happened to one of these things, or an old man weakened; or it is a time of intense heat, or intense cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Then let him be content with his food, cold vegetables, onions, and beans; and forbid wine, fatty meats, and filling with foods and all food that fills veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	 Until he is safe from a hot purge and is not afraid of the flow of matter to a limb; then let the sick one return to his own diet first with which his habit was accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When a broken bone begins to heal, then the sick one should be fed with nourishing foods in large amounts, heavy and thick ones, with viscosity; such as food made from cooked wheat with water, rice, heads of cattle, feet, livers of sheep, eggs, fresh fish; also thick wine and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 For this regimen makes the setting of the fracture faster and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And know that fractured bones, in men who are in the first age of old age and decrepit, it is not possible to be held together and consolidated according to their nature always, due to the drying of their limbs; they consolidate and hold together those which come from them at the end of gentleness, like the bones of small children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 Nevertheless, nature connects something similar to glue around the fractured bone from every part, in which there is thickness, by which it adheres and tightens it until they are consolidated together, and bound together until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was at first, until it does not prohibit it from its operations; and for this reason, it is necessary to place the nourishment of the sick with foods that have thickness, viscosity, and heaviness, as we said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	 And know that the species of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of limbs; since a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the skull bone; and a fracture of the chest bone is different from a fracture of the backbone; and similarly all other limbs are different from each other; and I come with the reminder of all the species of fractures exposed in their respective chapters.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 The species of bone fracture are also diverse within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 Since the fracture of it is arched, in addition to which stars occur within it. (The 'it' refers to the bone.)
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 And sometimes the fracture of it occurs along the length of the bone: there are fractures called stars, that is, astellae, and extensions arising from them, such as in a reed when it is sharpened with a knife to write. (The 'it' refers to the bone.)
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 And not extending: and there is a fracture with a wound and splitting at the head, and it is a small split fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And every kind has its skill or appropriate tool for its restoration, according to the memory of it, divided in its places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from the fact that a bone fracture is known, its curvature and protrusion appear, and its appearance becomes noticeable to the sense, and its sound when it is compressed by your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 Therefore, if there is no apparent curvature in its place, nor a sound when you touch the bone with movement, nor does it cause a strong pain to the affected person: then there is no fracture there, indeed it may be a curvature or a small split fracture: therefore, do not move or compress it completely by hand, instead lay medicines on it whose memory comes to mind, after the appropriate time: then it should be bound with a narrow bandage.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 And know that if the place is arched and split into two, in addition to which stars occur within it, however, all parts are moved away from their origin: then you must begin from your hour for its correction, aligning it before a warm abscess occurs on it.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	 If, however, a warm abscess occurs on it, then allow it to be for some days until the abscess subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then, cut it equally according to whatever manner can be done with gentleness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And know that its restoration and equalization is easier than the bone, wherein complications occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then bind it, according to whatever recollection comes to you.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 If there are complications in the bone, then it is necessary to extend this broken member from both parts, if it is a hand or foot; or with your hand, if the member is small; or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 Let your position be such that you place the member on a level surface according to its natural shape, until the parts of the broken member extend; then try with all your skill and ability to bring back these additions in their places: and be careful not to cause pain or injury by your operation, nor damage; and try with all your strength to apply one bone to its companion, according to the best forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 It is necessary that at that time you try and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 If then you see something unusual there, correct it, and adjust it to an equal state according to your ability.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And beware of excessive extension and strong compression, as many foolish people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 For many times they cause abscesses or contractions in the member through their operation, as we have already seen from their operations.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then join after adjustment and proper operation, and binding of this member, and rest, and calmness; and warn the sick person about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 And let him take care not to move it during the time of his vigils, and sleep, during his turning and agitation, and during his hunger, and all its movements with utmost strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 And so that it may be avoided, let there not be a position of a member followed by pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 Whenever one feels pain or injury in the position of a member, it is then necessary that you change its position to another where there will be no pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 And be careful that its position is equal and straight, so that there does not occur a twisting in the member when it is being restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 And the quality of the binding for the broken member, as I have told you.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 Know that the broken members are classified according to their size and magnitude, and also by their shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 Those that are small, such as the arm, the finger, the toe, and similar to these, then it is necessary that there be a soft, delicate wrapping of cloth.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 But those that are large, such as the thigh and leg, it is necessary that there be a broad, hard wrapping for them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 Because a wide binding holds together a large member and compresses it equally from all sides with an equal pressure, thus preventing any spot from being infected.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 Then, after your evacuation, begin to place the appropriate poultice on it in a soft woolen cloth over the site of the fracture.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 Then begin to wrap the binding over the site of the fracture three or four times, according to what is deserved by the member; and bind your hand slightly with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 Then go to the upper part away from the site of the fracture and bind it less than your previous binding that you used on the fractured site.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 Then pull the wrapping away from the site of the fracture slightly and soften the binding gradually until you take a large amount from a healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 Then take another poultice and wrap it again over the fractured site with more wrappings.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 Advance with a reduction towards the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 Let your operation be in the constriction of the reduction and its softening, according to what we said in the first reduction above.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then place between the reductions from soft linen cloth or fabric that matches the curvature of the fracture, if there is any curvature in it; and if not, do not place anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then reduce over another piece of meat.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Then place evenly stars well made astels immediately over these reductions, if there is no swelling or warm abscess in that place.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 If there is a swelling or abscess in that place, then place over it what sits on that abscess and remove the swelling; and leave it for some days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then tie over these stars.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 Let the stars be from the middle parts of wide reeds, shaved and shaped wisely; or they may be made of wood from which cribra are made, namely pine or oak, or calingi; and let the width of each star be in this form and this same shape.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 Nevertheless, the star that is placed over the traction should be somewhat larger and wider than the other stars; and the length of the star should be according to what is possible for the member due to its size and smallness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then tie over the stars with another piece of meat, according to the first reduction.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then tie on top with cords evenly, according to what we said about the reduction; and let your reduction over the fracture be more; and the greater the distance from the fracture, the smaller the reduction.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 It is necessary that the cords be medium in thickness and fineness, and be made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 If threads are thick, as I saw from the operation of foolish people who place their threads twisted from horsehair strings, it is a great error: because the constriction falls out with them beyond quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 Fine threads do not suit again: since you will not achieve with the constriction what you want.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 It is not suitable that there be less than a finger's breadth between the needle and the embroidery.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If a sick person is harmed by the tips of the embroidery after a constriction at healthy places: then place under them from soft wool or camel's-hair wool until nothing is harmed from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 When there is a fracture with a wound, and a break occurs in the skin, I will come with a reminder of this in Chapter 2 under special cases.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every broken member must be sutured with needles from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 It is because when a member is large, it is not necessary to place the threads above until five days or seven or more, according to your safety from the occurrence of an abscess of heat.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 This is the method of plasters, which the ancients placed on a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	 Shortened common method of plasters, restoring a fracture, suitable for multiple constitutions, particularly women and children: since it is from that which heat does not prevail, nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	 And it is to receive from the flour mill dust, and it is the marrow of the wheat that hangs in the walls of the mill near the motion of the millstone: and make this as it is, except you sift it with egg white: and place the mixture of it not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	 Another method of plasters, restoring a fracture, dislocation, and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Prepare alms (almess), laudanum, acacia, enula, and mugath. Crush all of them together, sift, and mix with twenty times the amount of myrrh, five times the amount of aloes, and twenty times the amount of alethil. Or mix with sheep's white grease if the patient's condition is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Then apply this poultice.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For this is a good composition, it restores broken bones quickly and benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another method of poultice for fractures and dislocations.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Prepare mugath, mess, white alteae, all of them crushed together with ten times the amount of myrrh, five times the amount of aloes, six times the amount of acacia, twenty times the amount of Armenian pounded berries, and grind them well. Then sift and boil in water or sheep's white grease. Administer them.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 Another method of poultice for unions and bones separated from their places. It relieves pain in those places, cuts, and fractures.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Take boiled wool, immerse it in vinegar and cooked oil, then place it on the location.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 In this poultice there is no virtue of restoration, but it is good for the sedation of hot abscesses and it drives out pains specifically.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 Another method of poultice that restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take the leaves of wild fig and papaver (opium poppy) and grind them all together to make a poultice from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 Another short method of poultice for restoration of bone fractures and when you wish resolution of remaining abscesses.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Prepare the root of alteae (althea), camomilla (chamomile), flowers of viola (violet), and herb flour, all in equal parts. Crush them all and boil with wine if the limb is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If it is heated (the wound), then make that (compress) with water of coriander boiled, or with water, and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 Another stronger method of plaster for resolution, stronger than the first, when a hard abscess happens during restoration of a limb.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Prepare the root of althea, linseed seed, boxwood, lentil, samphire, violets flowers, chamomile, all crushed equally, grind everything, and make it with water of willow, or sweet water, or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 Apply the entire thing according to the heat of the member, and the quietness of its warmth.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 Hippocrates, however, did not say in his book that it should be placed on a fractured limb during its restoration unless it is made of wax and oil: nothing else: and he narrated that it should be of a medium between thickness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 Galen, however, considered that things containing heat-dissipating properties should be placed on a fractured limb during its restoration, such as myrrh, aloes, and frankincense, and similar substances from those we mentioned earlier.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 Method of plaster for injury and pain relief.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Prepare mugath, chickpea, human hair cuttings or bird feathers, althea, and salt in equal parts: crush them, sift them, and make a plaster out of it.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 The amount by which the bandage should remain, then be loosened, is such that you consider it: if no weak pain or itching occurs, nor does the broken bone move from its place: then do not loosen it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If itching occurs intensely at the site, or disturbing pain, or swelling: then go and loosen it within an hour, and remove the plaster from there: and take a soft cloth or sponge, wet with warm water, and wash the place with it until the itching subsides and the pain settles.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then let the member rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Place upon it a piece of scented linen, soaked in vinegar and oil or rose oil; bind over it at night until you are confident that the hot inflammation has subsided, and let the swelling of the member rest, and remove its pain.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then return to the delicate tightening and a small plaster; do not bind it tightly at first with your tightening, but apply delicate ones until it heals.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling, and all signs of inflammation have completely disappeared and you need a plaster and tightening, then do so as you did at first equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 If nothing from what we said occurs in the member, then do not loosen it before three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	 And when it is allowed for twenty days as appears to you from the resolution of the member, as we said, until when a fracture adheres and the coagulation of flesh attaches to it; add also more in tightening than your first entire tightening; add also in the thickening of weak food, according to its preceding memory.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 If you see the location of the fracture has already dried out and weakened more than it should; then know that nutrition is prohibited from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Therefore pour warm water over the entire place where you loosen it, and let this be in all three days; relieve the tightening a little.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 By this operation, nutrition reaches the member and heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 That which foolish restorers do in place of a fracture of the member when it is not restored first, as required, and restored according to twists, is an error from their operation, and great fear; and if it were correct, they would have said this in their ancient books and operated accordingly.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I have not seen anywhere their trace in it at all, and it is more correct that it is not done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 On the making of a head wound.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 The types of fractures are diverse and their shapes are many; the causes of them are differentiated.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 For from the fracture is that which occurs by blow with a sword; and the blow removes bone completely until it reaches the siphac, which is under the bone, as does an axe in wood, and for this reason this type of fracture is called Axial Fracture.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 Or the sword strikes something of the bone and cuts its face, but does not penetrate through the cut to the end of it; and this type of fracture is called Calaan, that is, an Absolute Shatter.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And there is a wound for two types of fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And from the fracture is that which is compression or grinding; and its cause is a blow with a stone, or falling on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 And this type of fracture is also penetrating, which approaches the padding (which is under the bone), or it is on the face of the bone; and it is a wound for these two types of fractures and it can be either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 And from the fracture is that which is hidden in the bone in the subtlety of hair; and it is a small crack, and for this reason this type of fracture is called Capillary Fracture.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 And from these [fractures] is a fracture that occurs from a fall or blow by a stone and similar things, which cause the lamina (plate) of the bone to enter the interior, and it forms an indentation; as happens with caldrons of brass when they are struck, and part of them enters the interior.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 Most certainly it happens that way in moist bones, such as those of children's heads.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 And all these types of fractures of the sternum are separated, and I will come with the recall of the whole one in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 And we recognize all these types of fractures by examination over it and investigation of them with the probing sticks, and removal of corrupted flesh that is over them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 The Capillary type is recognized by this: that it protrudes over the bone and is scraped off and burned with a branding iron; for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In the treatment of fractures, consider first the state of the patient: then if you see from the conditions that it indicates fear, as for example cholera vomiting, stretching, loss of intellect, disappearance of voice, fainting, acute fever, eye problems, redness of eyes and similar ones from other conditions in various dispositions, without doubt it will not heal: and if you see the conditions that do not frighten you and hope for health: then begin its treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 If a wounded person comes to you first with the wound: and this is during winter days, then it is necessary that you should study the removal of the bone before the 14th day in every condition.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 And if it is during the summer days, then it is necessary that you rush to remove the bone before the 7th day, before what is under the bone from the flesh corrupts, and those conditions occur that we mentioned.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 If the bone fracture has already reached the flesh touching the brain and is accompanied by minute particles and attraction: then it is necessary that you cut the crushed and smoothed part, according to what I told you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 And it is that you shave the head of the wounded person: and scrape over the bone according to whatever method is possible for you: and according to the shape of the wound, and what is light for the patient.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If it happens to you during the discovery of a bone that there is bleeding or a warm abscess, then apply what is necessary to it.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 And fill the place with linen soaked in wine and rose oil, let the wound rest until the abscess settles down, and be cautious of bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin in the treatment of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 One method is to cut the bone with a straight-edged saw and this is its shape.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 And then administer another saw, broader by a little, after the first one: and this is its shape.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then also administer yet another saw wider still than that.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 And the second method is that you have a number of different saws; some of which are wider than others, and some narrower; and let them be at the sharpest edge of their extremities, and made of Indian iron or copper; and use them with ease in striking upon the saw, so as not to fracture the head and injure it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 If the bone is hard, then it is necessary to bore around it before you administer the saws with drills called trebrirs, which are not deep-drilling; and they are called thus because they do not pass through the bone into the meat that is behind it; for this reason, the end of a trebrid is rounded above what is under its head, sharp at the bottom like an edge or small circle, preventing immersion and passing through the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 And it is fitting that you take a number of trebrirs from among these, each one appropriate to the thickness of the bone until you have before you all the trebrirs for every bone; whose sharp ends in length and width are according to the thickness of the said bone.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the form of three kinds of drills or trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The quality for perforating around the bone of a broken limb is as follows: place the drill on the bone and rotate it with your fingers until you know that it has already penetrated the bone.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then change the drill to another position and place a rod of size equal to the diameter of a finger or approximately there in every hole.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with the chisels what is between every hole in the bone and do it more finely than you can on that part of the surface as we have said until you have removed the bone or by hand, or with some other instruments which you prepared for this purpose such as tenons and fine forps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And you must be careful to avoid touching the drill or chisels with any part of the splinter.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you perforate around the bone and it is separated from the splinter, if it is continuous with it and you extract it, you must plane and smooth the end that remains in the bone with another similar chisel.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 Nevertheless, it should be thin and delicate more than other chisels.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If some small bones or splinters remain, take them out easily with the tool you have on hand.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then take care of the wound after that with linen and the unguents as mentioned before.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 And another method of operation is simple, far from fear; which Galen described and praised highly; and this is his speech.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 First, you must begin to expose the bone from the place where the fracture is more severe and clearer until when you have exposed that part and placed under it the end of this concave chisel, which has this shape.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 And the concave part of the lens, smooth, does not cut anything; and the sharp part of it, in its two sides, extending along its length as you see: so that the concave part of the lens is fixed to the siphoid, with its sharp end incident upon the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike upon the Incisorium with a small hammer until you cut through the entire bone easily, as is customary; and be careful that no part of the linen cloth, which you fear might slip, should come into contact with it.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 And if the healer were not more foolish than men, and less ignorant of his art, nor asleep, then if something remained attached to the bone from the linen cloth in certain places, it would be cut away by the sharp end of the incisorium lenticularis itself, and would free it easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 For it is freed from it without harm, and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 If the fracture of the bone does not penetrate as far as the linen cloth, and what is cut off from the bone is the surface of it, and roughnesses and subtle shavings remain in it: then you should plane away that roughness, and grind out those subtle shavings with finer scrapers which you have prepared for this purpose, so that you may be able to administer them more conveniently and more correctly at every place according to what the operation requires, and the fractured bone itself, and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 And you should administer it according to your judgment, by first planing the bone more widely with those scrapers.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use a finer one after that.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 And do not cease doing this in continuity until you reach administering it more thinly and more finely of all of them.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 In each of the remaining small cracks and subtle fractures, it is necessary to administer care according to what leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And it is a thing that cannot be concealed over all, to which in this art there is any study, and it stood on what we have written, and it was shown in large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If the flap is adhered and retained when you excavate the bone: then it is necessary that you take linen cloth according to the size of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another piece of cloth doubled or tripled and immerse it in wine and rose oil and place it over the first cloth; and do that as easily as possible over it, so that it is not too heavy on the wound.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then administer a broad ligature over it; and do not tighten it, unless by the amount that holds the wound only; and leave it with this care for one day or two days, until you are secure from hot inflammation.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then dissolve it, and administer afterwards medicines with which excessive dryness is superfluous; such as the roots of garlic, and the flour of herbs, and the powder of frankincense, and aristolochia, and similar ones; and it is to be made from these medicines a powder that will be sprinkled over the wound like dry ones.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And administer universally in it every medicine of the property which is to cleanse and not to bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 And be careful according to your virtue that the wound in your cure is clean; and let there not be dirt of ointment in it, nor filthiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 Do not leave the wound to collect pus in it at all; because when pus gathers on the brain cloth, it corrupts it and makes it putrefy, and afterwards a great mischief happens on the weak person after that; and it already happens in the head of the wound, when the bone is cleaned from it, especially when the care of it is neglected, the blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 If the ailments mentioned occur in the sick person, know that it is certainly fatal.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 If the discoloration does not occur except from the medicine applied on him, and it is within the power of that medicine to cause the discoloration: then, take a part from honey and three parts from rose oil, and wash with them a cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 Then lay him on a sow's bladder; afterwards care for him with appropriate medicines until he is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 Chapter on the Repair of the Nose when it is broken.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 Know that the nose is not broken except when both of its upper parts are broken simultaneously or only one of them: because there are two bones in it; since below it is cartilaginous and does not break, but instead, it is subject to attrition, curvature, and deviation.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of the two parts is broken, then you must insert a small finger into the nose opening, and straighten the fracture with your index finger and thumb from outside until the nose returns to its natural shape; do this carefully with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 And beware that you do not cause pain during the operation on the sick person.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and a finger cannot reach it: then, straighten the tip of the radius that has a small bulge.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If the fracture is in both parts, then do the same: and approach with the repair on the first day of the fracture if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day, in a warm room of sweat baths.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert a piece of linen cloth from a flaxen cloth into the tip of the nose if the fracture is in one part; or insert two pieces of linen cloth if the fracture is in both parts: and let there be a thickness in the cloth equal to the size that fills the nose opening.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 And some of the ancient restorers said to infuse linseed in butter and change it every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 That does not seem right to me, rather it is necessary for linseed to be infused into butter made from milk, with flour of the mill ground.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then let the linseed be removed when the bone hardens and the cartilage becomes hard.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And at times a feather of a goose is inserted into the nose instead of linseed, once it is covered by soft cloth; and this makes the broken nose hold more tightly, so as not to hinder the sick from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you want, do it; and if you want, do it with linseed.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 If the nose happens to develop an abscess again when treating it with a lancet, pack the nose with hot plasters, or with plaster soaked in rose oil, or with a little javelin juice.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 But if an abscess does not develop, then pack it with plasters made from flour of sesame and incense powder mixed with butter of milk.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place a soft wadding over it, but do not bind the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If the nose bones are broken slightly or crushed, then it is necessary to cut through them and remove them with instruments suitable for that purpose.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then let it heal by itself and take care of it with suitable plasters or ointments for that purpose.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If an injury occurs between the nostrils, then treat it with linseed; and administer a lead tube until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 Chapter on the repair of the lower jaw when it is broken.
Caput V.	 Chapter 5.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is broken and there is no wound associated with it; then observe if the break is on the outside only and not split into two, and if it bends towards the inside; then its diagnosis is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 Therefore, if there is a fracture on the right part, introduce the left index finger into the bone of the weak: similarly, if the fracture is in the left jaw, then insert the right index finger: and push with it the swelling of the fracture towards the outside with ease using your other hand from the inside part of the bone correctly, and with it equalize it.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 If the fracture of the jaw is already separated into two parts, then it is necessary that you administer an extension from both sides, according to rightness: until it is possible for its equalization.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 If however it has already happened that the teeth are moved or dislocated: then bind them with a thread of gold, silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place on the fractured jaw a piece of wood.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place on it a double cloth and on the cloth place a large cross, well made: or an equal fragment of shoe leather, in length of the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then bind it above, according to the preparation of its binding and the fitting of its application, until it is not destroyed: and order the sick one to rest calmly and quietly: and place his food as softened.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 If you estimate that something has changed in its shape by some means: then rush and loosen it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then correct what has been changed from it and plaster it with lime made from millstone powder, with egg white, or with sifted flour, after you have removed the wood: and place over the plaster a soft woolen cloth.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 While the plaster remains attached to it on top and the bone arrangement does not change, leave it as it is, without loosening it, until it heals: or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 This fracture is frequently tightened within three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 If during that time a hot abscess occurs, then administer the remedy we have said multiple times for its suppression until that abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if the fracture is accompanied by a wound, be mindful of it.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 If it is already separated from the bone as a shard or splinter, then apply delicacy to this matter, so that you remove those shards of splinters together with what suits you for their removal using the appropriate tools.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If, however, the wound opening is constricted, then expand it with a leech according to your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you remove the splinters and nothing remains of them, or if the wound opening is wide: and if not, place on it a dressing that suits for this purpose and let it heal until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 Chapter on repairing a fork when it breaks.
Caput VI.	 Chapter 6.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 The fork is broken most often from the front part by the shoulder and its fracture is made in one of three ways.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 Or it breaks and splits into two, besides the fact that shards may occur in it: and it is easier to repair this type of fracture.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 Or such that splinters occur in the bone: and it is more difficult to repair this type of fracture.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 Or when the fracture occurs with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 And the operation in this case when there is no wound, is to have two assistants present, one of whom holds the broken fork and the other stretches the neck towards the broken part.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 Then bend the fracture with your fingers until the shape is formed as it should be: and there should not be a prominence or hollow in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 If you require further extension, then it is necessary that you place under the patient's wound ball made of cloth or wool; and let its size be according to your need; and extend and lift up the lever, and shape the ball with your hand until it matches the fracture, as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 If you cannot pull the extremity of the lever outside, because it has reached deep: then the patient should lie on his neck; and place under his shoulder a beam of appropriate size; and press the minister (assistant) to push down on the patient's upper arm until the bone of the lever that is in deep rises upwards; and then straighten the fracture, and make it even with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 If you feel a splinter in the lever and it moves: then it is necessary that you apply pressure on it and easily extract the splinter.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 If it is retained in the bone, then heat the incision with one of the instruments you have prepared for this purpose, after you place under the lever the tool that keeps the splinter (sifach); and the tool is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 It resembles a snail shell without a hollow cavity.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 And let its width be according to the bone you need it for and its size.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 The length, however, should also be as possible for you in the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 And it should have two ends, as you see; and one end should be wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If the break in the wound that you made when you extracted the splinter of bone is wide and you are afraid of infection from heat: then gather the lips of the wound with sutures.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 And if the break is small or you fear hot infection: then fill the wound with cloth and wool according to the size of the wound's cut.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If a hot boil occurs, then pour linen into rose oil, vinegar, and wine on it, and place it upon it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 However, a fracture of the bone without wound or incision is such that you place plaster on the bone made from milled flour and egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 And place soft wool upon it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place a small sphere under the affected area if needed.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take a leech, that is, the round one held by Saracens, which should be very long: and its width should be the size of one palm or approximately that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place a double layer of wool over the soft wool and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take an awl from fine wood, whose width is three fingers, and likewise in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then insert it into a linen cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then insert the linen cloth with the awl at the place of the leech that falls on the fracture and the wound.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then place the leech on the fracture as it is rolled [around], and insert it over its neck, at the healthy end and at the weak end: and bring it over all parts, so that you see that the leech holds the fracture properly: this is what is meant by a suitable leech for a fracture, and it should not be concealed beneath you nor removed from above the fractured bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 And therefore, one must look at the weakened part every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 How often then is the ligament softening and you see the leech being removed? Then straighten it and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the sick person's pillow under his back, and place a small cushion under his head at night, so that when he is raised from one side, assistance may be provided to him from the other side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 Fracture of the neck (of the clavicle) is to be treated by lifting (the arm).
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Either tie the arm to the neck itself and do not loosen the bandage unless it happens in a place that is affected by itching or from a boil, for twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see its face (the wound) at that place.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add a string and let it be until it heals and coagulates.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 Indeed, a fracture of the neck (of the clavicle) is to be bound and strengthened as much as possible for twenty-eight days; sometimes it happens in some people in lesser time.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 Chapter on the healing of a clavicle fracture.
Caput VII.	 Chapter 7.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 Clavicles rarely break, and when they do, it is at a wide place; however, only the edges break from it.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When the clavicle breaks at that place and splits in half, it can only be known by touching; then prepare for its treatment according to its shape (of the fracture).
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 Restore it to its natural shape in any way possible that is within your ability.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then place on the site a flour of milling with egg white, and soft wool, and cover it with a small cloth (doubled).
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place on top of it a wide bandage made from thin wood, according to the size of the clavicle or slightly larger.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If there is a hollow under the bandage at any place on the clavicle, then fill that hollow with soft wool until the bandage descends evenly.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then bind it tightly on top with long thread, in a suitable constriction and the firmness of the bandage, until it does not move from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 Check the bandage every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever the ligament is softened, tie it and if the awl is removed from its place, let the weak one lie on his healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 And the spatula is restored within twenty days or within twenty-five days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When that number is completed, then untie the ligament; and you will be safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 For it is from bones whose fracture is not feared nor their dislocation.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 If the splinter comes out of a bone and pierces beneath the skin, then cut through it and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do as we said for a broken neckbone with abscess from hot poultice, if something happens from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 Chapter on the restoration of a breastbone fracture.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	 A breastbone sometimes breaks in the middle of it and it happens rarely.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	 Its extremities indeed break more often and are usually crushed from accidents.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.
